These developments sound like they could have a very positive impact for that particular region, but will probably have a neutral impact on Lancaster Ave, which is fairly isolated from that shopping strip. More work would need to be done to connect the two commercial strips in order for there to be a residual effect. Lancaster Ave will attract Drexel students from campus and nearby housing and more work needs to be done to attract stores and in-fill empty storefronts.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI live near (and am fortunate to be able to afford) Mariposa food Coop for my day-to-day grocery needs, which cuts down on my need for drives to the grocery store. Unfortunately, as a new homeowner there is no way for me to avoid the majority of shopping trips that require a car/truck for building supplies and large home supplies.
[[[39.954782235111374, -75.20859914398193]]]\nI was not aware of any concerns about single family home availability in the area.

This would have a marvelous affect! This is exactly the kind of zoning that should be in place in that region. Businesses should be encouraged to utilize existing building stock, if possible and further in-fill could be encouraged through favorable tax schemes. The affect would be a change from inaccessible, blighted space to an exciting business district that is already very accessible via public transit and vehicular transit (via 76 and Grays Ferry). Increased access to the riverfront would also encourage more use of the area for recreation. All of this would increase property values and decrease blight in the area.
Why would we rebuild that complex? The park space on the corner is inaccessible. An effort to bring that park space to grade should solve the aesthetic problems caused by the complex.

Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nIncreasing access to - and connectivity between - the green space on the west side of the river from 49th to 58th would be an incredible asset for Southwest Philadelphia!

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nThere is NOTHING more important than physically separated bike lanes for improving bicycle safety short of removing cars from the road.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit, Other (explain in comment)\nI would add that if a bus-only lane was to be added to Chestnut Street, it should be a physically separated lane (Bus Rapid Transit style) or else this would be no more than a nice idea that will turn into a 4th car lane. Alternatively, I am in favor of removing a parking lane and converting to bike lane while using 3rd vehicle driving lane for bus and HOV only traffic.

Yes\nI have experienced the poor bicycle parking situation at 30th Station when traveling by bus or rail from the station. Parking is a very real consideration when you are departing for multi-day trips. Keeping bikes safe and out of the elements should encourage more bicycle travel to the transit hub. A big issue that still stands in the way is bicycle access to 30th street station. Currently, Market Street bike lane ends short of 30th street and a safe bike route is not very clear. http://goo.gl/maps/4Zd3d

I think that the city should do more to promote these local commercial corridors to attract the already large customer base in the area. Yes, encouraging more residents to live above these retail establishments would help, but there is already a lot of residential development surrounding Lancaster Avenue. If you go back to the previous challenge, promoting residential use in the former school sites along Lancaster Ave will also add more residential. The key is attracting people to these locations and that is something that needs to happen organically.

Yes\nAs an organizer of a running group, I would utilize any new trails available for recreation with the group. I would also us the trail for biking for leisure and for my commute as an alternative to the Grays Ferry Bridge.

[[[39.959946841010485, -75.21078782653808]]]\nI have never been in the high rise "city in the park" development over next to the Drexel Vidas Athletic field. The limited access development, mixed with way too much media coverage (not to metion personal experience growing up in NYC) about the issues revolving around this type of public housing development - drugs, theft, assault, etc. - have kept me out despite living within 0.2 miles of the development for years.

The Drew School parcel which fronts on 38th Street is a good candidate for continued large-scale commercial development that already exists along the 38th St/University Ave corridor, if there is a demand for that kind of development. At the same time, this section of 38th street could accommodate another retail development to provide another grocery store, retail, restaurant, etc. The U City HS location should be converted to residential use.

Why is the 46th St. El Station so lifeless? That's the first question to ask here. This is a unique situation and not just a question of zoning classes and selecting the appropriate use. Developing in this area requires addressing the atmosphere created by the elevated rail lines. Ongoing efforts must be made to provide pedestrian lighting and other elements that enhance the feelings of security, like plans already underway to improve lighting going north along 46th Street to the station. Moreover, new development needs to be considered in the context of development happening across the street and up to Haverford. This Hidden City article lays it out well http://hiddencityphila.org/2012/03/the-more-things-change/There is a lot of new development happening in the area, including the possible relocation of the PPD offices to the old Mutual Trust building at 46th and Market, which would bring a lot more human traffic to the depressed area. Given this new activity, the realistic potential of corner stores and small breakfast/lunch restaurants increases tremendously. New housing stock will have to contend with the constant noise of the El and will therefore be less desirable for private development, but makes sense for public housing.

The efforts of commercial corridor development groups, such as Lancaster Avenue and 52nd Street, are already moving in the right direction. The problem requires community input as to what kinds of services are missing and provide the appropriate incentives to bring in that type of retail at the right scale to meet the demand. No, the answer is not more transit connections to giant stores. The answer is restoring grocery store and small retail establishments within walking distance of dense residential areas along corridors.The solution is already at hand and more resources should be invested in groups already doing this work.

Kevin lives in a township connected by regional rail directly to 30th street station, which is conveniently located to USW district public transit options. This is likely Kevin's fastest, lowest-stress commute option. Removing single-occupancy cars from roads is critical for our region. Kevin's complaints about too many cars on the road are a bit absurd when he is contributing to that problem. Hard for urbanites to really sympathize with suburbanites commuting into the city.

Not Sure\nSo long as studies are conducted to ensure that elderly travelers do not have to walk further, possibly eliminating every other stop would work. Unfortunately, unless you take cars off the road, I don't see this speeding up travel times during rush hour.

USW has a great public transit system with trolleys, subways, and bike infrastructure. The main challenge that I find is traveling north/south from my home. For example, travel to Fairmount park is not easy to do by bike or rail. I find bus service to be slow and unreliable.

Several places jump out. The redevelopment of the old West Philly High School would help alleviate some housing needs. As well, the Apple Storage building is a good candidate for retrofit. There is a lot of vacant land and this could be used for multi-family housing, which is much easier than redeveloping the existing Victorian homes for multi-family use.
Groceries, Clothing, Antiques

RSA-2 thru RSA-5 are good uses as they represent a lot of USW existing stock. Semi-attached and detached may help alleviate noise disturbance issues presented by students. RM classification is also good for concentrating students. If locating on commercial corridor, CMX classification is probably ideal with mixed retail/residential use.

There's a ton of vacant land and blighted homes just a couple of blocks south of Baltimore Avenue, at the beginning of Southwest Philly. Developers probably can't get away with condos in those areas just yet, but some higher end new construction apartment rentals would certainly find an audience with people just like Sarah.

Groceries, Hardware, Electronics, Big Box Store (ex. Target)\nThere are plenty of corner stores in the neighborhoods, but I have to go all the way to South Philly or Jersey to go to Target. Wouldn't it be great if there was a Target in West Philly?

RM-1 for smaller, privately developed student housing developments. This will allow multiple apartment houses by right, preventing situations where six people are sharing an entire house.CMX-3 for larger developments with a commercial aspect, either privately developed or built by educational institutions. This will allow plenty of apartment units and allow commercial use to benefit residents and the community.

Making capital improvements to Lancaster Ave., especially for making it more appealing to foot traffic with safer sidewalks, better lighting, etc. is an excellent start.  Increasing the density of the housing stock (especially for students) would certainly create more foot traffic in the area.

Yes\nAbsolutely!  I already love running down the Schuylkill River trail from Spring Garden to Locust, and then have to run through Center City.  Having the trail continue down to Bartram's Garden would be amazing for running, biking, skating, etc.

Septa is very slow, takes a long time, and requires many transfers to arrive at any major shopping center.  Increasing density of housing would encourage more retail in UC neighborhoods, which would allow residents to easily walk to nearby retail.

The new Powel Elementary school, coupled with the Science Leadership Academy Middle School and a high school that offers a high-performing alternative to University City high school, which is there now.  Aside from a new school, utilizing the space so that it can become a hub for the community, with a park similar to what Clark Park offers residents on Baltimore and Chester; a place that flourishes with farmer's markets, flea markets, kids soccer leagues, and concerts in the warm weather.

This area has virtually unlimited possibilities, being so close to a major transit stop.  However, the vacant land contributes to more crime in the area, particularly under the El.  Increasing safety around the El station first would be paramount, as no one will want to be near the area if it weren't safe.  Coupled with increased safety should be a high-density development, one that moves many students/young professionals in the area and has attractive retail that has a continuous flow of patrons to greatly increase foot traffic in the area.

DON'T DRIVE IN!!!  There is almost no reason for commuters to have to drive into University City to access their jobs in Eds. and Meds.  With Public Transit hubs so close (30th St. Station and University City Station for Regional Rail commuters) and the trolleys and El on Market St., along with frequent 21 and 42 busses, there is no reason for people to have to drive to their workplace in the area.  Use public transit and further reduce parking option to discourage people from driving in!

Yes\nAbsolutely!  Stopping at ever numbered street, or in some cases, half-way between numbered streets greatly slows down this service.  Fewer stops would certainly increase efficiency and help in more accurate scheduling.

The city should certainly encourage walking and biking in University City.  Having dedicated bike lanes on some streets has been helpful, but more could be added.  Crumbling/displaced sidewalks can be treacherous for pedestrians, so making sure they are repaired/replaced/are safe is also a priority.  Making sure that subway stops are safe (particularly 46th st., which is notoriously dangerous) would further encourage use of the high speed transit.

There are many vacant lots the further west you go on the trolley route (and not even that far west on some).  New housing stock could help revitalize struggling blocks/streets, while rehabilitating vacant homes would also be very beneficial for our neighborhoods.

What's not to like?  Many parks, lots of outdoor activites.  Lots of easy access to late night clubs.  A growing sense of community.  Great Arts (like Philadanco).  To love Philadelphia, you need to explore it.  Try something different.  Rather than going to a restaurant, give a new chef a chance at the Restaurant School and help someone learn their craft. Go to Bartram Gardens and be surprised that it exists at all.
No, but as a resident I am trying to stay involved with my local schools.

This is a difficult question.  I think in the most general terms, there is a lack or limited sense of opportunities.  One major (and the main) issue is the lack of good public education options.  The one area of growth (non-student oriented) is where the public school is supported by Penn.  I think the lack of education options (for our children) forces lower and middle income families to places where they can both afford the taxes and send their kids to public school.  If we continue to ignore our public schools, we will continue to see unequal population growth (and decline) that is dependent on non-government institutions.  I think we will continue to see this unequal growth/decline no matter how we slice the community population (economically, racially, or politically). A second issue is job opportunity.  Yes, our major educational institutions are sources for jobs.  But there seem to limited start-ups and young businesses.  The technology center along Market should be competing with other cities like San Francisco, Seattle, New York etc.  We have many of the same resources, magnets for young people, and old neighborhoods with diverse and good housing stock.  I'm not sure how to tackle this issue, but it seems to be a blend of zoning, taxing, and general city-wide policy.  I remain optimistic, because there is discussion and progress on these fronts.  I just wish it could happen more quickly.
The El\nThe El is fast, generally on time, and dependable 95% of the time.

Yes, almost every day\nI use the Market/ Frankford.  Door to door it takes the same time as the trolley, but I enjoy the extra walk.  I do hope SEPTA comes out with a card system soon.  The whole process of getting tokens is inconvenient at best and painful at worst.  Why, why why does SEPTA accept cash only at the stations and some places don't even make change?  What a waste to resources to have someone sitting in a booth all day and they are not "allowed" to make change.  Minor complaint: I wish the trolley was less noisy inside the tunnel.  We do live in the 21st Century, this should not be too much to ask.

[[[39.943571724687835, -75.21088438606262]]]\nWe need to find a place that is large enough, easy access to local farms (i.e. major roadways) and walkable for most of us.  What about the corner of 47th and Woodland?

Yes. I am an interested to learn more about food options north of Market and south of Lancaster.  We used to buy our food more locally and were willing to pay more and visit more places.  With children at home there is far less time for this.  Since having children and buying a car, we usually shop at larger grocery stores with more selection to insure we can get what we need without making it an all day event.  That said, we still enjoy the errands to the local store or market to get a special item or a last minute ingredient.

The University of Pennsylvania is the second largest employer in the city.  The universities including Drexel, U. Sciences (and others) are a magnet for people.  This is a transient community, but it makes for an interesting and diverse community.

[[[39.947704940320065, -75.20984100675582]]]\nClark Park always has something going on.  From exercising, playing rec soccer, the markets, the farmers market, the concerts, the plays, seeing friends, and getting outside.

None\nNone of the above.  We go to Clark Park, Cedar Park, Malcolm X Park, Taney Park - or Fairmount Park.  Frankly, I either wasn't aware of the rec centers, found them to be uninviting, or had no reason to go there.

The hidden spaces that we stumble upon are most beautiful.  In the alley between the 4600 blocks of Pine and Osage, you will find a huge weeping cherry tree that blooms bright pink and red.  It is an explosion of color to signal the end of winter and beckons all of us out of our houses.  During the summer it shades the residents and I enjoy hearing the hidden and whispered conversations that occur in the decks under the tree.   In the winter it is a silent "wooly mammoth brushing the ground, reminding us and waiting for us to return in the spring.
replies: The biopond off Woodland Walk on Penn's campus is a similar "hidden space."

response: Penn Park\nI've spent a little bit of time in Penn Park, but not in Drexel Park or Shoemaker Green. I'm not a fan of Spruce Street Plaza...the space feels awkward and uninviting to me. It's just one loop without much active space for running around or playing.

A new park along the Schuylkill River near Bartram's garden\nI would most like to see a trail and park along the Schuylkill connecting Center City to Bartram's. I know that there is already a lot of momentum and energy behind this project, and it's exciting to think that it could happen so soon and benefit so many people. As people have said in past comments, Bartram's Garden is a truly beautiful and unique destination, and an easier/faster way to get there would be fantastic.

[[[39.94698524411093, -75.21241860961914]]]\nI don't know the entire area well enough to pick one point, so I just picked a spot that seems close to green space and close enough to a commercial corridor.

Bringing light industrial jobs to post-industrial areas will bring new life into these dead spaces, and a trail and greenway along the river will serve as a great amenity for the employees working in these new facilities. The greenway will also serve as an important buffer to protect these properties in case of flooding. I think this is a good idea all around.

It would be nice to modernize the housing complex, without making it flashy and high-risey so that it sticks out like a sore thumb. I live in Kensington and I'm not a big fan of the cheap looking pre-fab rowhomes that are popping up all over my neighborhood. A nice courtyard in this space would be nice, and lots of windows to let light in.

Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit, Other (explain in comment)\nAnother idea: I moved to Philly from Baltimore last year. Baltimore has a new, FREE hybrid bus called the Charm City Circulator (http://www.charmcitycirculator.com/) that has done extremely well there and has really improved connections between Baltimore neighborhoods, universities, attractions and other transportation. These buses are better for the environment, can be used by anyone and everyone, and move faster because no one has to take money out and pay. I would love to see a similar bus system in Philly.
replies: Great idea, Zoe! DC has a similar network of Circulators, which provide frequent service to major corridors and only cost one dollar to ride (makes it easy to pay). Both DC and Baltimore's systems are funded by area business improvement districts, kind of like University City District and Center City District and their chambers of commerce; perhaps we could get these organizations to chip in some funding as well?

response: Yes\nYes! I will definitely be biking to work more often in the spring and summer and would use this facility often. I've had my bike stolen in the past and would rest easy knowing it were stored securely.

No\nI don't have a problem with the number of trolley stops, but as I mentioned during the last mission, I wish the El didn't have A and B stops. I think this is an okay idea in theory, but it just doesn't help much in practice and usually adds to my commute time.

Independent of specific design, I'm enthusiastic about quality housing built with sustainable, ecologically sensitive and quality materials. Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nWhile a Kingsessing Recreation Center redesign is attractive, ultimately I'd like to see accessible parks and trails along the river. I think the trolleys'  service need to be improved.  They often do not run to schedule and there are often back ups in the tunnels.  Sometimes two or three trolleys will come in a row after waiting for a long time.  I'd like better automated systems that would allow trolleys to run on time, modern light rail cars with more room and seating, low floors to be ADA accessible, and fewer stops - instead of every block  - every two to three blocks.  Plus priority at traffic lights.  This would also speed up vehicular traffic that often get backed up behind trolleys.  Hell Newark, NJ has light rail.

Some gateways for the neighborhoods onto the bike paths would encourage more people to bike to work. I've heard talk of making the grays ferry bridge have one side for car traffic, and one for bike traffic, with a median in between. I'm not sure this is the best option, but it would create a safe way across the river for cyclists. I'm also a big advocate for a bike connector between the Woodlands and Bartram's- our two largest open spaces, with a shared history. I do think there are options. There are several vacant lots and parcels along Baltimore avenue. These parcels would be great as commercial first floors spaces, with residential units above. Making the residential units in some of these buildings condominiums rather than rentals would attract people who want to put down roots in the community rather than a transient student population. The single family housing stock in the neighborhood is typically too big, even for a single family. Many of the third floors of these houses are in-law apartments. Making these types of units legal would offer more housing options, likely with owner occupied units in the same building. This would give more people opportunities to live in the neighborhood, without making drastic changes to the housing stock.

Student housing, especially undergraduate housing , should be on or as close to campus as possible. This keeps neighborhoods more intact with long term residents. In addition, rehabilitating existing buildings is always preferred to demolishing existing infrastructure to accomodate new housing. The victorian architecture is part of what makes this area unique and gives it character.

I suspect they will have a negative impact.  We need to develop a new economic model for the country other than raw greed.  It needs to consider the 99% that have been left out of the mass concentration of wealth and power in the few.We need to consider people, quality, and quality of life in the model.  A few years ago I rode a train from coast to coast.  Every town had become the same--same chain stores in the same style.  Why bother to see the USA when everything is the same.Therefore, suggest some model where the local district businesses could open a branch around 30th Street station to participate in the growth and to impart a local flavor to our city.  We need to find a way to strengthen these local businesses so they can compete against the giants.  Perhaps group purchasing, perhaps membership in some sort of "partnership" that could handle the accounting, taxes, payroll, etc so that each small business did not have to struggle with factors not directly related to their product/service.  Possibly also coordinated local advertising.Also, of course,is the need to offer high quality goods and diversity of goods.  Where is the nearest camera store, hobby shop, etc.?

[[[39.96001262965289, -75.20332055664062]]]\nFirst of all--why does the map open to the Eastwick wildlife area--when did that become part of USWWest Powelton and Saunders Park are being totally over-run with out of town and even out of country absentee owner apartments--totally destroying the neighborhood.  It is important to try to get families to reoccupy the houses so that the neighborhood can regain its greatness of years gone by.

Unless there is some incentive for the employees to live in USW, the effect is likely to be more suburban commuter car traffic through the USW neighborhoods.There needs to be some sort of a package that includes incentives for living within so many blocks of the area--such as no city wage tax.  There also needs to be provision of public schools for those (and everybody in the City) equal to the best suburban schools so that people will live in USW.  Then the proposal would result in many of the vacant and low quality rental properties being replace with families which would greatly improve the neighborhoods as well as increasing the prosperity of the City.There also needs to be job training provided for existing USW residents so they can also work in the new jobs there--the idea should not be to displace them, but more of a rising tide raises all boats idea

I do not want it to look more modern--it is already modern.  Modern is the same as thousands of newly-build places around the country, as well as boring. Instead, convert one of the existing traffic lanes.While changing the lanes, on one way streets put the cycle lane on the left so that cycles are not interfering with people boarding the buses.As I explained previously, reducing the number of stops has been proved to slow the service in Philadelphia--that requires some fare system that enables passengers to board through all doors without anything to slow the process.It requires more than just US employees to change.  Is not much of the traffic just passing through?  Therefore incentives are required city or regionwide.  The best incentives might be more frequent service so that passengers did not have to stand--a big disincentive, more comfortable seats, windows free of advertising, priority for transit vehicles, courteous operators, 24 hour live information service, etc.

No\nConvenience is being able to get on close by.  Also this was tried on the Rt 47 and was a disaster.  When the bus stops at every corner people can get on and pay their fare while the bus goes to the next corner.  When there are few stops, people line up and it takes a long time to get on--in fact during the wait more people arrive to add tot the problem.  Timekeeping became a disaster on Rt 47 and many people had difficulty getting on as the buses became totally packed.Time would be saved by putting on a few more trolleys at busy times to reduce the dwell time at stops and by giving them priority at traffic lights.

Public transportation, but it needs to run frequently.  Often I have to walk because the service is so infrequent--one can go quite a distance in 20 or 30 minutes.  It also needs to start earlier.  I often have to get up hours early because only the MF night owl runs and go far out of my way on the few night buses.  The Rt 40 and 38 start way too late, as do many of the regional rail lines--even worse on weekends--they should run 24x7 every 30 minutes.Poor frequency means that trips involving only a little actual travel time can require hours of time because of the long wait at each transfer point.The traffic lights do not allow enough time for walkers.  Often the timer has run down before I am even 1/2 way across.

That is a small loss, almost accountable by difficulties counting accurately.I think most of them left because the jobs have left.  Our country's shortsighted politicians and business owners sent the jobs to China and other poor countries.  Pennsylvania is not a good place to locate--the state government is too busy being Applachia to attract any real economic development--we do not invest in infrastructure like other countries, states, and regions do.  SEPTA is falling apart, while about 20 cities in France have built brand new light rail systems in the last few years.  Even the bus lines have disappeared--it is no longer even possible to make a day trip to Reading--just a few miles away--without an automobile.  Successful cities know how to get good things done! In addition locally Philadelphia has a lack of civic minded politicians and civic leaders.  We have lost the company headquarters that used to make the city important to the national and world economy--we have become just an over size backward small town.

[[[39.95178855887008, -75.23705201721191]]]\nI would guess this area is dangerous and does not have many amenities (shops, parks, entertainment options) that I would normally visit.

This is a tough one. I think SEPTA offers special senior/disabled transportation options, perhaps she could take bettter advantage of that. I don't think Kingsessing is going to change anytime soon...

Again, mixed-use commercial/housing would be great. The parcels are near public transit and the increased supply could lower housing costs for everyone in the neighborhood. I would NOT suggest a type of housing oriented at a specific demographic (retirement, students,etc.) as some people have suggested. Having a diverse population could really start to liven up that side of Walnut/West Philly.

Mixed use housing/commercial is probably the best for this area. I know the police headquarters are going in nearby, so perhaps some businesses that contract with them will want office space in the area. Additionally, this could be a good place to put an urban Target or larger shopping complex, if the demand is there (I don't know if it is). It's between Center City, 52nd St. Corridor, and Upper Darby, so it might be a good place for some TOD to serve the shopping needs of the USW community without detracting from those other areas.

Connecting buses that arrive at 30th St. station or UC station when regional rail arrives would ease a lot of suburban commuters' journeys. If they would circulate throughout the UCSW area, they could deposit commuters at their doorsteps relatively quickly. Also, allowing bikes on SEPTA regional rail during commuter hours would be helpful-- perhaps have a separate car just for bikes? Bike share at regional rail stops and popular work destinations could also be helpful.
Yes\nThey're so slow! They could stop every 3 blocks, speed up quite a bit, and hardly inconvenience anyone!

Biking and public transit, while good in this area, could be improved. As the population of USW grows, we will need these types of transit that allow more and more people to move through the same amount of space. It simply isn't feasible to accomodate more cars in the area. It's difficult to get to South Philly or Fairmount/Art Museum area using public transit.

We should prioritize dense housing and building along trolley routes, for exactly this reason. This will bring down the cost of living (increase supply), while expanding the user-base for SEPTA's trolley routes. The Baltimore Avenue (34 trolley) corridor is very vibrant, and some new mixed-use housing options to replace some of the decaying ones could really open up some nice places for young professionals or small families. I can definitely picture new housing along the 10, 13, and other trolleys, too.

Groceries, Bodega, Hardware, Hair Salon\nUniversity City is definitely swamped with drug stores and convenience stores-- not really in need of more. A decent hair salon or smaller food stores (bodegas) would be nice. There's a great hardware store on 45th and Walnut, but I can't think of any others.

I would recommend one of the denser, commercial and residential mixed use zoning districts. Density and mixed-use allows for more efficient use of space and resources (transportation, waste, etc.) and lower living costs. I wouldn't worry about how tall buildings should be or whether they "fit with the character" of the neighborhood. Giving developers more leeway with such issues should add to the eclectic nature of urban living and attract more development.

Drexel Park, Penn Park, Shoemaker Green, Spruce Street Plaza\nWe spend time in all of these parks.  We play beach volleyball near the Drexel Park and the little court near Locust Walk... and some more beach volley courts would probably be used quite a bit (especially if they drained better than those at Drexel- and had real sand- unlike the makeshift court in Clark Park).  There is a big beach volley movement in Clark Park- even though there is not a space- and I can see this user-group expanding to other areas where there are facilities! We pass through Spruce street plaza- but it hardly a park just because it has grass.... there's nothing functional you can do there.  And  Shoemaker Green is a suntanning spot in between classes- but not much more.Penn Park is where we play tennis at night- but if you are not a student- you have to pay to play (bummer- maybe something could be worked out to make better use of the courts for the registered public during off hours?)

A new park along the Schuylkill River near Bartram's garden\nIf I had to rank these, I would choose the new park and then the 40th street portal as a close second.  This neighborhood hurts for park space and long running trails.  It gets a bit old to do laps in the cemetery or Clark Park- and it is a long schlep down to MLK and Kelly drive.  A nice park connecting us to Bartram's Garden and all the great energy with the new horticulture center out there would be a fabulous asset- and one that could easily be expanded to connect our neighborhood better with Cobbs Creek... which, which a little more traffic and motivated users could become a great recreation area.

[[[39.95001202970043, -75.18821435546874]]]\nI would not use a bike share... the only time I have used one is when I was a tourist visiting a new city and I did not have my own bike.  For this reason, I think a bikeshare hub at 30th street station (or the art museum) would be a great way to promote daytrippers wanting to see the city- or commuters who need to get to work at CHOP (heck, maybe it would help that empathy question guy who commutes in from Radnor).
replies: Much better than my thought. I'd like to change my comment and use yours :)

response: I tend to be pretty snooty about shopping local over shopping at chains- but who knows if Marcel is competing or complementing the traffic that would already come from the big stores??  Not me.I can say that I would rather see big, vacant buildings re-purposed (like Manakeesh did on 44th and Walnut, http://www.manakeeshcafe.com/)- than greenfield development where we could have some much-needed pocket parks, dog parks and greenspace.  The dog park at 48th and Chester in Squirrel Hill is another brilliant use of a vacant lot that ensures eyes on the street and builds community (http://www.chesteravenuedogpark.com/Default.aspx?pageId=708038).  And there are loads of old churches and cathedrals that could re-purpose to be daycare centers or have street-level retail.  Calvary Church at 48th and Baltimore has a thriving daycare in the basement- as well as a theater group.  It would be wonderful if that same multi-use creativity could be applied to some of the giant, beautiful, well-built and largely empty churches through-out our neighborhood.  Perhaps Marcel could approach one of these churches about setting up his business in their building- with a lower rent?

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nDoing shopping by trolley is a pain only because there is so little room on the trolleys and buses.  If we had new trolleys or new buses, we should aim to have more space for people to take their strollers and grocery bags.  It would be great to have a raised curb/platform so that we can wheel these items directly onto the bus and will not have to negotiate trying to heft the stroller or bags over the awkward handrails and onto a bus/trolley with no storage space (see image).  Also, it would be great if dogs were allows on public transit- if we want to go to the riverfront trails with our dog, we have to drive.  If we could take the above-mentioned style of bus/trolley to IKEA- we would.

[[[39.88773858623304, -75.2543039855957]]]\nHomes near natural amenities tend to have a higher value- and would give the city more in property taxes.  Also, personally, I would like to live on or very near a nature reserve.... the same goes for Bartram's Garden.  I know there is a public housing project there now, but I feel that if the schools were better- middle-income people would flock to that area- and that would only benefit the public housing families and public schools.

It is bizarre to even have allowed residential housing along the railroads and highways- those houses suffer from the noise and poor view and have become dilapidated, weighing down the rest of the neighborhood (eg. houses on Linmoore ave compared to their counterparts across the street and not over-looking the rail lines).  It would be far better to encourage businesses to locate along the rail lines (see DuPont and FedEx center near the highways- they look okay).Because the area south of Grays Ferry Ave is not near the rail lines or highway- I would keep it in residential uses... particularly if you could inch it toward high-income residential uses and amenities... Keep Wilson School - and other schools.  This neighborhood is improving by leaps and bounds- and you will want the amenities of schools and stores in the area to help aid the rejuvenation of the residential fabric.Further south and east of Grays and Linbergh Avenues is an area sandwiched between rail lines- and though I have not visited the site or walked it extensively- it is probably a great candidate for the types of job spaces you want to create.If the waterfront access is kept intact and wide enough for paths, parks, and art installations- it will only help improve the residential neighborhoods that are connected to it.
replies: I think you mean the area north of the west side of Grays Ferry Ave, up toward Woodland Ave, when you talk about Wilson School, etc., right?\\ Also, someone should build a dog spa somewhere around Grays Ferry and Lindbergh Ave. It's the perfect location... :-)

response: I actually like the way that it looks now- but think that that corner could get more use with a farmer's market (or outdoor movie screening/theater... something to make use of the mini-ampitheater space).  I think that the affordable housing complex needs an amenity in a area- not necessarily a facelift.  Or it could work to turn the complex into a mixture of fair market value housing, public housing, and transitional housing in order to create a more mixed-income neighborhood in a place where there is clearly demand for it.

Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nThe Kingsesssing Rec Center is fabulous as is - it just needs a soccer field and some nets on the tennis courts.  Honestly, there are fabulous tennis courts all over Philadelphia- and many (including the heavily used court  at 46th and Spruce) just need to be re-paved/levelled and have lights.  Additionally, Drexel has courts over by the public housing projects- and they are hardly ever used- even by Drexel students... And Univ of the Sciences has courts by Woodland Cemetary- that are rarely in use.  If the city could partner with Drexel/US to allow registered/ no-fee membership access to those courts- you would probably see a lot more use and foot traffic out there.... and a lot more use of nearby businesses... thereby expanding the coffee shop culture.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nI bike frequently- and with a toddler.  It would be great if the bike lanes were better shielded from car traffic and car doors opening.   I would definitely use a designated bike/walk-only lane to Bartram's- and that would probably make trips to Four World's Bakery and the Kingseesing Rec Center easier and more frequent.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nI take the bus often, and would love to see a lot of the single-driver traffic in the city converted to public transit.  That means that public transit has to stay clean, get better organized (provide maps and time tables at each stop) and extend service- ie- I would love to be able to get from West Philly to Ikea/Society Hill on the weekends.

Yes\nI lock my bike at 30th street frequently - and would do so even more if there was a covering over the bikes to protect them- and yet keep them in visible place to prevent vandalism and promote security.  I think these bike-parking stations would be heavily used in many other locations throughout Philadelphia (ie- outside every post office and septa/El stop).

There is a train stop right outside CHOP- if he could park and ride from Radnor- that would save him a lot of time... maybe at the Radnor-end, they could expand parking, train frequency, and route information.  On the CHOP-side- they could subsidize with train tickets to save on building more parking garages.

There are a lot of cyclists in USW- and this is a relatively cheap and easy mode of transport to encourage and support.  If we could more easily bike from the 47th El stop to Gray's Ferry- and across- this might encourage connection between these two sides of the community.  Ideally, designated BIKE ONLY paths are the best - and some of the wider streets could we revamped so that cyclists do not have to bike amongst the cars or risk being doored (see image).  If a bike-only path were developed from Bartram's Garden into USW along the rive- this would also lengthen the MLK/Kelly Drive recreation area and bring it to us- encouraging more weekend traffic on this side of the river for joggers and cyclists on their way to brunch and out to enjoy the sights.As for car traffic- create more mixed-use parking garages like that at 40th and Market in Fresh Grocer.  The giant parking garage still has street retail at its base and is relatively non-disruptive of pedestrian traffic.  The large parking garage at 48th and Spruce is also privately owned- but spaces can be rented- and it has a giant green-roof on top and is flanked on all sides with street-level shops.  If more parking has to be built- it need not be asphalt lots- but can be woven into the urban fabric with first-floor shops and green roofs with a view on top.Public transit could be fixed by not having trolleys and buses stop EVERY block- that would save a lot of time and energy for everyone.

There are already several large condo buildings at 47th and Spruce for rent or own.... They are located on the spruce street bike path that goes directly into Center City where City Hall is about a 15-20 minute bike ride away.  The Garden Court condo building at 47th and Spruce has a block-sized greenroof- an excellent place to get outside and play with kids (pictured)- and very spacious units.  Alternately- the condo across the street has an indoor gym, pool, and billiard room... There are already many great family-housing options... but the support services for rearing a family in most of the district is lacking.  The Old West Philadelphia High School is also set to become a mixed-use condo building- and I would love to see the adjoining church (currently only used on the bottom two floors, where the top floors have broken windows) similarly transformed into a mixed-use residential space. Another section of West Philly High at 50th and Spruce is near Barkan Park and has great greenspace around it- right now the building is vacant, windowless, and covered in graffiti- but it would be an excellent space near transit.   The Provident Mutual Building would also be a wonderful place to turn into a mixed-use residential/office/school because of its location right next to the 47th street station- and the spacious grounds filled with old oak trees and overgrown rose gardens.The main thing missing in this neighborhood is a good school - and the community is working really hard (sometimes WITH and sometimes AGAINST) the school district to transform Lea Elementary into a place that neighborhood parents- like yourself- will want to send their kids.The good news for Sarah is that even on a PhD salary - she can afford to rent or even put a down payment on a place in SWU.  To avoid crime, Sarah should make sure that she buys or rents in the area that is serviced by UPENN bike police (all the way to 48th between Baltimore and Spruce??).  She can get a walking escort home any time she feels unsafe- and they are generally on every block within this zone.  If the city decided to double its bike-cop force and create a similar program- that would probably help home sales in whatever area they choose- and also property tax returns....

response: Yes- it is more dangerous than Boston.  But- there are amazing restaurants, Chestnut street and Old City have fabulous shops, and there is a great night life with the Electric Factory, clubs through the city, hipster dive bars, NPR's world cafe live, and NYC not too far away.In USW, try Marigold for a romantic dinner BYOB, Grilled Fish has fabulous calamari and knock-you-on-your-ass lemongrass martinis, the hipster dive bar Fume above the ethiopian restaurant is wonderful. Second Mile thrift store can be surprisingly good sometimes... and Marakeesh is nearby for great Turkish coffee.  But also- Earth Cup off Pine is wonderful too.  The farmer's market in Clark Park is fun- mainly for people watching (sometimes girls will hoolahoop fire or there will be a grindcore band in the bowl).  And Four World Bakery has fabulous bread!(image: summer office set up outside Earth Cup coffee shop- very dawg friendly)

I am the mother of a two year old. We live half a block outside of the sought-after Penn Alexander catchment and across the street from Lea Elementary. I am reading tutor for Lea Elementary.  In order to become a tutor, I had to submit three background checks that cost me $60 and many hours of legwork.  When I was a substitute teacher in Sweden, I clicked on one automated, electronic link, and at no charge, the school retrieved my criminal record.  If the school district is going to rely on volunteerism to beautify and improve their schools, they will need to streamline the volunteer permitting system.  It is my understanding that if I wanted to fix the broken basketball hoop at Lea, I would have to pay for hourly liability insurance to volunteer.  It would be less paperwork and less expensive to buy a gun in this country.  That is sad.The schools are broken because the city has failed to enforce its tax code.  Philadelphia has $515 M in delinquent property taxes owed, most of which would be paid to support the public school system.  More funding could be had from enforcing "broken window" policies which fine absentee landlords and put vacant and abandoned properties up for sheriff sale in a TIMELY and transparent manner that allows people to bid up prices (as opposed to the city sitting on residential vacancies in the hopes of one day bundling them to sell cheaply to a developer).  The city and state, instead of collecting and spending taxes on schools, have slashed the public school budget, starving schools for funding to the point that they cannot function and are in such disrepair that they are slated for closure.  The city and sheriff_s sale office should be held accountable for these missing funds.  The more we starve our school system for funding, consolidate under enrolled schools, and cut programs and building upkeep funding, the more these neighborhood schools will deteriorate taking surrounding neighborhoods with them.  There is high demand for Penn Alexander.  Housing prices in the catchment reflect this with a $100K premium.  There could be high demand for Lea Elementary.  Instead, the current administration is charting a path that will overburden already under-funded schools.  Middle-income neighbors, like me, who can afford to flee the city_s school system will do it- taking our tax dollars with us.  Now is that time that people, young, professional, dual-income families WANT to live in Philadelphia.  If the city can_t or won_t turn over their abandoned and tax-delinquent properties in a timely and transparent fashion, collect and spend the $515 million owed on schools, you will lose us and only further perpetuate a system of inequality on future generations.http://www.philly.com/philly/news/special_packages/157887355.html?fb_action_ids=10151204531620233&fb_action_types=og.likes&fb_source=aggregation&fb_aggregation_id=288381481237582(image: design charette for Lea Elementary's new playground)

9Anyone with a 4 year old leaves... the schools are atrocious.  Penn Alexander is hard to get into and the cost of housing the catchment is $100K more.  LEa Elementary has no greenspace (yet!) and very few middleclass parents choose to send their kids there.  I honestly think that if we changed the schools in this area- people would flock to it---especially given how bad the school market is in the rest of the city.   That will take funding and community engagement to get the school district to focus on programs that can fix up the old buildings, add programming for music/art/foreign language, and beautify the outdoor space (image: greening Lea Elementary's blacktop, phase 1)

response: Zoning for student housing is a major issue facing our community. We have developers buying potentially family owned homes and renting to college students (more than 3 unrelated in one building). Many of the landlords do not live in the city and the houses go into disrepair. Broken sidewalks, unshoveled walkways, trash, loud parties, are the visible problem. The invisible problem is that are neighborhood school is at risk because we no longer have affordable housing for families. Students should be concentrated in areas near universities. I would prefer higher density buildings particularly for undergraduate students to avoid developers taking over neighborhood historic buildings. I do feel that our neighborhood (Powelton Village) is open to higher density buildings, however the buildings should maintain character of buildings in the neighborhood and be designed to attract graduates/working professionals with young children.

[[[39.9475769, -75.169599]], [[39.955176444058225, -75.21448845007325]]]\nI don't think there's a particular area that should discourage multi-family homes, since both renters and owners should be encouraged to enjoy and hopefully get engaged in their neighborhood. But the area near Farragut and Locust Streets consist of fairly quiet blocks that should be zoned for residential, as opposed to commercial, uses.
A new employment hub would improve all of West and Southwest Philly. It would also help diversify the kinds of jobs available in the neighborhood beyond the "eds and meds" sectors.
Ideally, these homes should look exactly like the rest of the housing stock nearby. Let's stop stigmatizing PHA and other affordable housing by making it look different.
replies: very good point.

response: Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nRiver trails would be really great, especially if they connected to Bartram's Garden and the Schuylkill Trail/Park. West and Southwest Philly should also continue cleaning and greening vacant and underutilized land, especially near schools and residential areas.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nThese ideas are all great. In particular, I think bike sharing would introduce new people to biking in Philly, and once they saw how easy, safe, and fun it is, they'd be hooked.There's a great collection of bike sharing videos at http://www.bikesharephiladelphia.org/learn/Video.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nAll of these ideas would be really helpful in improving bus flow.

Yes\nA bike parking area would be incredible. This would be perfect for people who live or work in West Philly: they could bike to 30th Street, then continue on via the El, trolley, Regional Rail, Amtrak, or MegaBus at the station. I think it would certainly discourage driving, particularly for those within an easy bike ride of 30th Street.

I think sidewalk and lighting improvements, rezoning, and broader advertising would all play an important role in helping Marcel's business. He may also want to consider asking his customers why they come to him, and building his marketing campaign from there, as well as trying "curb appeal" improvements to his business to entice the people who do pass by his store frequently.

[[[39.962054, -75.240816]]]\nI never really spent much time on the 60th Street commercial corridor. I didn't think it was unsafe or boring, but there were so many other places to go in West & Southwest Philly that I didn't explore that area, and the mix of stores was less appealing than in other commercial areas.
Yes\nAbsolutely! That would be a fantastic bike ride.
replies: Or a fantastic run!

response: Because they're so large and usually in locations well-served by SEPTA, school buildings might be perfect for mixed-use facilities, with a community center, housing, and retail all in the same place.

While I was at The Enterprise Center CDC, this was probably the question I was asked more than anything else, so it's really interesting to think about now. Redeveloping the Provident Mutual building will be key. As for the rest of the land, I don't know. What I do know is that the Walnut Hill Community Farm, right next to the El station, is an amazing space that came straight from neighbors' ideas about what could happen with this long-vacant lot. The farm is a step in the right direction to bring life back to this intersection and this area.

West and Southwest Philly should strive to be a great place to live throughout a person's lifespan. Programs like Northeast Philly's Rhawnhurst NORC (naturally occurring retirement community) go a long way towards making sure that people like Celia can live independently with support from friendly neighbors and social service organizations. They provide transportation (both through SEPTA and from pre-screened volunteers), social opportunities like group shopping trips, light home repair, and other ways to keep seniors engaged and active in their community. I think organizations like Rhawnhurst NORC are an excellent model for what Philly could do to support seniors.

Aside from people with lower mobility (ex. those in wheelchairs, seniors, and people with young children), I would recommend splitting the commute up with different modes of transportation. For example, Kevin could take the train from Radnor to 30th Street, then take the LUCY bus or 42 bus to CHOP, or walk/bike ride from 30th Street in nicer weather. Focusing on the convenience and ease of a commute will encourage more people to take SEPTA, walk, or bike, which in turn will ease traffic and allow those who still drive to get through the neighborhood faster.

Yes\nYes, absolutely! While the trolley is aboveground, I think it would save a lot of time if the trolleys stopped every other block or every third block instead of stopping at every single corner. In the section of the trolley's route through Penn's and Drexel's campuses, several of those stops are quite close together. I would keep the stops at 37th and Spruce and 30th Street Station as these seem to be used most frequently, and condense some of the other stops on the campuses.

Most parts of West and Southwest Philly are convenient by public transportation, walking, and biking. These forms of transportation should be encouraged as they have so many benefits: increased eyes on the street, better health (through walking and biking), decreased emissions, and improved knowledge of your neighbors and your neighborhood. On SEPTA, it is generally easier to travel east-west through West and Southwest Philly than north-south (aside from the 52 and the 40 bus), so it would be great if more public transportation and walking paths connected to places like the Philly Zoo and Bartram's Garden.

Many of the converted rowhomes (ex. where each floor of a rowhome becomes a large one-bedroom or two-bedroom apartment) in West and Southwest Philly would be great for young adults or small families. There are also more traditional mid-rise apartment buildings with this population. Cedar Park, Walnut Hill, and parts of Spruce Hill have lots of apartments like this, and I think there's room for similar new housing.

Groceries, Office Supply\nAdditional grocery stores (stocking healthy food!) would always be beneficial. I think West and Southwest Philly are fairly well served by most of these store categories, ex. Monarch Hardware on 45th and Walnut for hardware; any of the CVS, Rite Aid, Walgreens, or Sun Ray Drugs for your pharmacy needs. I always ended up leaving West/Southwest Philly to buy office supplies, so that would be helpful, but I think I would put a fairly low priority on a new office supply store in light of all the other things that would be positive changes to the neighborhood.

Some busier streets in West and Southwest Philly, for example Walnut, Chestnut, Market, and Lancaster, could use higher-density zoning districts like RM-2 or RM-3. Other streets with predominantly low-rise buildings and rowhomes would probably use RM-1 or one of the lower-density zoning districts.

I don't know about places that opened in the past 18 months, but I went to college in Philly and loved the city immediately. The first thing I would tell Rachel is to get off campus! The restaurants along Baltimore Avenue (Chaat House, Dalahk, Vientiane, Dock Street, the tofu hoagies at Fuh Wah, etc.) are incredible and incredibly varied. At 45th and Walnut, Saad's and Manakeesh are among the most delicious places in West and Southwest Philly. Other than restaurants, I would tell her to spend quality time in community spaces like Clark Park, Malcolm X Park, Cedar Park, the Rotunda, and the 40th and 52nd Street branches of the library. Meeting lots of people and seeing how kind they are is a great way to get to know Philly. Finally, one of the ways that I came to know and love Philly was through volunteer work. West and Southwest Philly have lots of nonprofits, schools, and faith organizations that are doing positive things and could use help. Volunteering is a great way to fall in love with the community-minded spirit of people in West and Southwest Philly.

I didn't go to any of these schools, but when I used to work at The Enterprise Center we worked closely with teachers and students at University City (among other local schools, like West Philly High and Lea Elementary). The students, teachers, and parents had gone through a lot, including the shift to being a Promise Academy. So many of them were really engaged and trying to make positive changes at the school. It seems sad to prevent that positive change from happening by closing the school.

Maybe people leave West Philly for Center City or the suburbs. West Philly's population loss could also factor in people who move to other cities that are more often thought of as good places to find a job.
[[[39.958043, -75.20986499999998]]]\nTraffic can get backed up here and make it a little scary to cross the street if you're walking or bike riding.

The El\nThe El is fastest and within walking distance of lots of places in West Philly and Center City. The trolley lines are convenient too, but they are much slower than the El in getting from West Philly to Center City since they 1) stop every block or two, 2) get stuck in traffic, and 3) every now and then someone would double-park and the trolley can't pass by. The trolley would be faster if it had a dedicated lane of traffic that cars couldn't use.

Yes, from time to time.\nI generally took the El from West Philly to Center City, but I also rode my bike pretty frequently. The trip to Center City was fast and convenient either way, though it would be helpful to have more and better-maintained bike lanes along the way (the ones on Spruce and Pine were a dream come true!)

[[[39.973953, -75.20421299999998]]]\nMantua and East Parkside are underserved and could use better access to fresh, healthy food. Murray's on Lancaster Avenue and Shoprite on 52nd and Parkside are helpful, but the neighborhoods could use more stores like this, ideally so that everyone was within walking distance of healthy food.
The map is pretty accurate. Getting access to healthy food is more challenging in some parts of Mantua and Southwest Philly than it is in neighborhoods like Walnut Hill, Spruce Hill, and Cedar Park.

West/Southwest Philly is a great place to work because it's so easy to travel to (via the El, trolleys, buses, Regional Rail, bike, car, or walking). The anchor institutions in the neighborhood, like Penn, Drexel, CHOP, HUP, and the K-12 schools all are major employers. In addition, these places inspire other businesses to move to the neighborhood too.

[[[39.957976, -75.212445]]]\nThe Enterprise Center: I worked here for 6 years and the organization and surrounding community are full of inspiring, fun, and thoughtful people.Walnut Hill Community Playground, 47th and Sansom Street: I helped build this playground, and it's a great place to visit.Walnut Hill Community Farm, 46th and Market Street: A truly magical place. It's a former vacant lot that is now an urban farm run by high school students, who have a farm stand on site and work with Urban Tree Connection to run a CSA that serves 50 families. http://westphillyfoods.com/food/

48th and Woodland (Comegys)\nKingsessing and 48th and Woodland rec centers are tied for me. Both used to be a quick bike ride away, and have lots of fantastic activities. 48th and Woodland has the Sprayground, though, and I used to spend lots of quality time there!

I think the most beautiful place in West and Southwest Philly is Clark Park. In the park year-round, an incredible diversity of people come to relax, have fun, and meet each other. I've seen weddings, giant snowball fights, cookouts, picnics, epic soccer games, people doing acrobatics and spinning flaming torches, and Shakespeare in Clark Park plays there. Clark Park belongs to everyone, is cared for by everyone (especially the Friends of Clark Park!), and is a real treasure of the city.
replies: clark park is by far the most talked about jewel in the neighborhood. Nice video.

Yes, almost every day\nthe connection between 30th st station and center city is good (though off peak el headways are long) but access to the hospital complex is poor. the trolleys are slow, crowded, and are still a long walk from the southern reaches of the hospital complex that have been developed in recent years. the 42 bus is even slower and more overcrowded. I'd run the 42 bus to 30th and market (the 30th and chestnut st stopped was discontinued during construction of the garage and never reinstated) to encourage transfers. outside that, there are no easy answers. perhaps a dedicated busway that runs below grade since there are underused streets below grade between 30th st and the hospital complex. a more far fetched idea would be a gondola from the station to the complex and across the river to CHOP's new site on the eastern side of the river.
