The view coming into the city on market street around 39th - where you're at the top of the natural topography and moving downward. The skyline just opens up in front of you and it is a reminder ever time I drive in why this place is home.
None\nI work in University/Southwest and use the rec centers near my home in center city.

Drexel Park, Penn Park, Shoemaker Green, Spruce Street Plaza\nI live/work close by, so have spent time in all of them, and each provides a different but terrific new green space for students/faculty/staff/families/visitors!. I am looking forward to seeing the spring plantings in Spruce Street Plaza.

A new plaza at 48th and Baltimore\nThis is a tough decision because there aren't many details provided about what these plans entail. I personally chose the new plaza at 48th & Baltimore because I am more frequently in that area (and am really curious what is meant by plaza - does this mean something like a triangle with seating/green area in the middle of that confusing and massive intersection?). That being said, the UCD plans for the 40th street trolley portal would do wonders for that station, and as I have previously written, I am all for connecting Bartram's Garden with other properties along the Schuylkill (especially if they are green and improve accessibility and safety).

[[[39.95073580641281, -75.19542413330078]]]\nA bikeshare near/at the HUP/CHOP complex would be very useful for me... I can't always bike to work, but if I had a bike at my disposal during the work day, I could very easily go for a quick recreational ride if a meeting cancelled or I had some time for lunch. If available, I also think a large number of Penn/HUP/CHOP students/workers would use a bikeshare to commute and/or ride recreationally (rather than having to worry about bike storage in apartments/houses without garages/etc) if available. Generally speaking, the bikeshare program will be great for city dwellers with limited storage space
replies: I feel like they need several, or maybe a really really enormous one to serve HUP/CHOP. I've seen varying sizes of bikeshare pods in other cities - there's a big one outside of Boston South Station, for example. I think it'd be interesting to see just how many HUP/CHOP folks would take advantage of this.

response: There's a pretty large area between 32nd & Chestnut, and the traditional shopping streets like Lancaster and Baltimore, and I believe enough residents across this large area to allow success of both new businesses in that area and in the local neighborhoods. It may in part depend on what other major national retail stores are considered (in general, there aren't many chains that I am a big fan of!), but I would bet that a business like the Shake Shack won't "steal" a ton of business from local restaurants further out. Perhaps some people will make a special trip over there from time to time, but definitely not as often as they run around the corner for a quick bite to eat. And, there are many vegetarians/vegans in West Philly who would tire of (or not care to eat) the one "vegetarian" burger on their menu :) To the extent that the addition of the major national retail stores makes that area a more desirable place to live, I think the overall impact on smaller, local businesses will be either positive or neutral.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nThis is what I do...I grew up in West Philly and never had a license until I moved to another state where it was a necessity. Now that I have happily returned, I still do my shopping etc via walking and SEPTA (el, trolley) and without a car... BUT my husband does drive to do a good chunk of the family shopping. As detailed in the previous challenge, there are several shopping options that I (and apparently many others!) would like to see on several sites in the district.

[[[39.9553406, -75.2127964]]]\nThere are some streets in the neighborhood that are dominated by multi-family units, and these blocks tend also to be some of the least well-kempt/maintained, for a variety of reasons, including absentee landlords and transient tenants who sometimes have reduced commitment to the community or who simply lack familiarity with good neighbor practices. I think de-commissioning some of these multi-family homes to single family would help stabilize these blocks, giving them a core of relatively permanent families who would look after them.

I can't speak for the neighborhoods immediately adjacent to this proposed development, but it would seem that some development there, especially if it was guided by solid sustainable/greening goals, could be a great way to increase the number of visitors/commuters and access to the area, which would help support local businesses, improve safety, and would likely spur other revitalization efforts as well. Looking at a map, this would be one way to help facilitate a solid (safe) connection by filling in some of the gap between Bartram's Garden and Woodlands Cemetary (and onwards to => Penn Park). I would appreciate the waterfront access on trail or park.

Although I do prefer low-rises to high-rises for affordable housing, the design with the visible cars and the parking lot between the pedestrians and the housing complex behind is not aesthetically pleasing, places a prominence on driving v. other modes of transportation (especially striking since this is located right at the 40th street transportation hub), and is potentially unsafe as well. In general, I think parking options should be less visible.  A mixed use building, which includes retail/commercial/residential (and hidden parking, if at all) would be much better.

Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nThis is a tough question because all of these would improve recreational use and green space, and places for children and adults to play. I ended up choosing the parks/trails that you could reach by 49th/54th/58th (live closer to 49th, so personally would prefer that :) because I think this would open a world of recreational opportunities to the neighborhood - in the light of trail/waterfront development along the Schuykill River. This could be a portal to/from center city, the Parkway and Fairmount Park (and all destinations thereof!), Wissahickon.... Valley Forge Trail.... And proximity to Bartram's Garden would facilitate better access/use of this historical site as well...

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nAll of these improvements would make me and others more likely to bike! Like many of my neighbors, I have young children (under age 9) just starting to bike independently, and although they love it, and I can imagine some great family biking day trips to Schuykill Banks, the Parkway, the River Roads, and even on to the Wissahickon or Valley Forge once they get older, one of our greatest challenges is safely getting out of our Spruce/Walnut Hill neighborhood to connect up with these trails. It's hard enough for adults, but I am terrified for them to ride with the street traffic!! So, more physically separated bike lines, like the recent improvement on Walnut Street, especially would help with this. Also, don't know if there's much chance of getting Penn to install separate bike/pedestrian lanes on Locust Walk (and would hate to have them paint those pavers), but the prohibition on daytime biking there is unfortunate for those of trying to get safely from West to East via bike.

Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nThis would not only help ease traffic congestion for buses, but also more generally encourage use of SEPTA and promote decreased reliance on cars (and increased sustainability for us all). Not all UC employees can easily take SEPTA, but MANY do and drive anyway in part because of obstacles they perceive to giving up their cars. A multi-pronged approach to removing these obstacles, including financial, should work!

Yes\nDefinitely YES!! This would provide a great option for commuters to/from all the surrounding institutions and businesses who connect at 30th street, which would encourage greater SEPTA use (e.g., via Regional Rail). And I would definitely use it myself.

Lancaster Avenue is LONG, so it's not clear where Marcel's business is located in relation to other businesses. Any commercial area needs a critical mass of businesses to attract the foot traffic each business needs to thrive. Any of the improvements mentioned (improving the streetscape -sidewalk and lighting - facilitating advertising, encouraging residential uses) might help, but implementing methods (via zoning changes and other incentives) to encourage small business development in adjacent existing buildings would be important for that critical mass.
Yes\nI would definitely use this for recreation (cycling). This would be great!!!!
[[[39.950538413523404, -75.23044305419921]]]\nI have never had a reason to go there. Not sure what Mercy Philadelphia Laboratories is?

To the earlier point about decreasing trolley stops, for someone like Celia, it might be difficult to have fewer stops when she is toting shopping bags. Increasing previously suggested local shopping options located near public transit stops would likely assist her.
Actually, as far as I am aware, SDP has proposed to close UCHS but that is not a done deal. In any case, I am not familiar enough with these buildings to propose development.

YES, there is a lot of vacant and underbuilt land, and these frankly are blighting influences that decrease safety, attract litter, and decrease use of this potentially influential transportation hub. A few years back, the Philadelphia Planning Commission and Walnut Hill Neighborhood Coordination Strategy Team issued a report describing several recommendations for Transit Oriented Development in Walnut Hill, centered around the 46th & Market el station.  TOD makes PERFECT sense for this sector, which extends all the way to Walnut street. Their major recommendations included: decrease auto-oriented uses (gas stations, car washes, etc), which are at their core inconsistent with transit oriented development, and which includes re-zoning areas where needed to allow mixed uses of residential, office and retail; implement the Transit Revitalization Investment District (which promotes alternative transportation modes and walkable communities); improving the streetscape to make it more pedestrian friendly/walkable (pedestrian lighting - already underway, I believe; tree planting, sidewalk maintenance, curb bump-outs, buffers between pedestrians and traffic) and enhancing community garden public space. I support bringing the PPD to the Provident Mutual Bldg, and the development of vacant lots and/or site of current Aldi into a great supermarket and a small garden center. I also hope the Enterprise CDC is able to build their mixed residential/commercial/office building at Market and Farragut. The whole corridor connecting more southern neighborhoods (Spruce Hill, Garden Court, etc) to the el stop has much room for development - both the east and west sides of 46th between Walnut and Market have derelict (scary) residential and commercial properties, and vacant lots. It would be great to see these developed to provide amenities (small businesses, mixed commercial/residential) people have suggested in response to previous questions.
replies: I also hope that some of the ideas from the TOD plan can be implemented.\\ Very thorough plan, sounds like this space had a lot of great ideas in mind.\\ Thanks to you both... one thing I don't think I said explicitly but that was evident in the TOD plan is that development of 46th & Market really requires development or at least improvement of the corridors leading to it from the south (and north)...to maximally connect these neighborhoods to whatever development occurs at 46th&Market.

response: Currently, I think Kevin should consider getting a SEPTA Rail Pass and either walk or drive/park to the Radnor Regional Line station, and take Regional Rail (Paoli/Thorndale line, AKA the R5) to 30th Street. From there - he has several options to get to the main hospital: (1) walk (if it is a nice day); (2) hop on the el (to 34th); (3) take any trolley (except the #10) to 37th; (4) transfer RR lines at 30th Street to one of the Regional Rail lines servicing University City Station (once his office moves, it will be just a short walk from there across the South Street Bridge). If his office currently is in the CHOP offices located in the 35th & Market vicinity, from 30th street, he could take the el to 34th, #10 trolley to 35th, or any other trolley to 36th all put him within easy walking distance. In short, there are several SEPTA options he should consider to make his commute more bearable, do his part to ease traffic on the streets, AND he could get a lot of work done on the train!

No\nMy answer (no) is really on behalf of elderly and disabled people who might find elimination of stops prohibitive. I don't mind walking an extra block or two to get on and off trolley, but for some, this might be quite difficult.

USW District is very walkable and increasingly (e.g. with new bike lane on Walnut) bike-able as well. There are multiple forms of SEPTA (bus, trolley, el) serving most sections. Personally, I prefer these kinds of uses to be encouraged (v. driving). I like the plans to connect bike paths to enhance access to destinations along the Schuylkill River for recreation as well as commuting purposes. There are few destinations that I feel are difficult to reach from this neighborhood, as access to major transit hubs (30th street station/center city) is reasonably quick. As I mentioned in Mission 1, improvements in area surrounding 46th & Market el stop would facilitate round the clock use of this hub.

I haven't aimed to rent a place for a long time (I own a house) but it seems to me that there are many existing options for renters that are not just for students. In general, the further west you go, up Baltimore, Pine, Locust, and Walnut, it seems the fewer students there are, and there are apartments for families and young professionals. Locust and Walnut are not exactly near the trolley, but are close to the el and bus lines. Existing options include large apartment buildings as well as multi-family homes. Future exciting projects include the old West Philly High building, and Apple Lofts (not as relevant here if it does end up being geared towards students).

Groceries, Clothing, Other (Explain in Comment)\nI believe we need a good supermarket, and additional clothing store options would be great (I usually go to center city or out to a mall to shop for clothes). One type of shopping that I think would be GREAT and well-supported is a small Garden Center. Not a big-box... but more of a small business (ideally with parking to be able to haul soil/mulch/plants) that has good gardening supplies and great plant selection, especially plants/seeds that are suitable for the type of gardening often done in UC - container gardens, shade gardens, vegetables, and so on. Possible locations for this might be the site of the old credit union on Baltimore Avenue, or the former halal market on 46th & Walnut.
replies: The gardening support center out of Bartram's Garden has this- and a presence in Clark Park on the weekend where they can sell plants (eg. blackberry bushes, and unusual seeds that are hard to get elsewhere).... but it would be great if the place at 47th and Grey's Ferry expanded to carry more items for small-scale gardening.\\ Thanks, I have been to Bartram's little shop, and greatly appreciate their seeds and native plants, but didn't know they sell out of CP! Perhaps they would consider being a supplier (or operating??) a small garden center within closer proximity to commercial areas in UC?

response: Since we have plenty of existing buildings along commercial corridors (some more well developed than others), and to also encourage small business development, I think CMX-1 and CMX-2 (Small scale neighborhood commercial and residential mixed use) would be great...basically where student housing is available above ground floor level commercial properties. This way, single family homes are not de-commissioned for student housing, students (and possibly business owners/customers) may be safer because of the visible presence of both, students may be less intrusive to residents around them, and more small businesses would be developed (and students would help provide a steady clientele).

It's hard to know where to begin..one of the great things about this neighborhood is that there is always something new opening! So sign up for west philly news tweets for updates, or read West Philly Local. Please check out Manakeesh and its companion ice cream/smoothie shop, Bliss (45th & Walnut); everyone will mention the growing 44th and Spruce/Locust corridor with Local 44, Lil Pop Shop, Honest Toms, Tampopo, outfitted with a parklet; Clark Park on a Saturday before 2pm for always evolving Farmers Market - stay and eat lunch, relax in the park; Baltimore Avenue Dollar Stroll - about once a month on Thursday nights where you can "eat your way up and down Baltimore Ave" sampling all the new and long-time bars/restaurants along the way; programming at the Porch at 30th street station.
I did not attend (attended Gompers, which is also on the closure list), but know people who did. Access to good public school education in the community is an increasingly difficult problem to solve.
Hmmm... seems less true in some pockets. Combination of suburban flight and aging population?

The El\nThe el is closer to my home than the trolleys, is quicker, serves a broader area of center/olde city (all the way to 2nd). However, as I noted in my last response, improvements surrounding the 46th & Market el stop would facilitate my use of this stop during evening hours.

Yes, from time to time.\nI usually walk or take SEPTA to get around the city (very rarely drive). Coming from home, I take either the el from 46th and Market (close), the trolley from Baltimore Ave (further), or walk. Coming from work (Penn), I take any of the trolley's or walk. Going home after dark, I don't feel safe getting off the el at 46th and Market and walking home, so I usually get off the el and 40th and Market or take trolley. Both el and trolley are fast and convenient. Further development of the 46th and Market area would be important for me to feel more comfortable - really liked the Transit Oriented Development plans for development of corridors between Market and Walnut. Hope the Enterprise CDC can follow plans for Market & Farragut, and hope the PPD relocates to the Insurance bldg. Opening of CHOP Karabots center will help.

[[[39.955473064864485, -75.21310525512695]]]\nWe definitely need a large supermarket with affordable healthy food options in the community. I selected the location of the current Aldi at 46th and Market for this site because although Aldi provides affordable food options to community members, I believe a grocery store with BOTH healthy and affordable options for the community would be better. In addition, this is an existing large site, with parking, and is next to the 46th street el stop, which is a major transporation hub, so would provide good access to the greater West Philly community, including those who rely on public transportation. Besides, from what I understand, Aldi is owned by the same company that owns Trader Joes.... :).

[[[39.964354540074744, -75.19628244018554]]]\nThis area used to be full of small single family homes. With the addition of a large public housing tower the area went downhill. Now the tower is gone and a new, very attractive public housing development is in its place. Small developers are grabbing up vacant homes and empty lots and filling them with student housing. These buildings are suitable only for students and will not be desired by families, couples or seniors when the new dorms and student residences begin to syphon off demand. Meanwhile there are many folks who would buy in this area if there were new or rebuilt homes and blocks were all residential single family.
We need to diversify our job opportunities. Right now it is mostly the universities and hospitals that employ the most workers. Light industrial job space would add a new player in the mix.

I really can't see much wrong with the way it looks now. This is a great location and if it were torn down and new housing built I think it could attract a mixed use and not just subsided rentals. But I am unsure as to whether the question is focused on that.

All the trails could use some signage telling about the wildlife, the history and the views.

Philly is not just shops, restaurants, etc. It is neighborhoods and people. I wonder if Rachel might pretend that she is actually living here instead of just wanting to entertain herself. Get involved with the community, volunteer for some summer program with children or older adults. Walk over to the Art Museum, and make the river trails at least a weekly destination. List the sites in the area that would be fun to see. Go together with friends for walks or bike rides to see these places. By the end of the summer Rachel will know much more about the area and might also feel as if she is a part of it.

no, but my daughter went to UCHS during the first several years of its opening. It had great promise and was originally to be a draw to students all over the city. University never got the support or good press that could have made it a sought after destination. Too bad. Look what those things have done for the Alexander school.

I went to Lea school back in the 70's- early 80's. It's one of the schools that will be affected by the closures, since they will probably be enrolling the kids from Alexander Wilson. I don't think it necessarily has to be a bad thing, but it probably will end up being a bad thing. The state of public schools in the city of Philadelphia is disgraceful and just steadily getting worse. I would love to keep hope alive but it hard when it's obvious that the powers that be don't really care.
replies: The WEst Philly Coalition of Neighborhood schools (West Philly Coalition for Neighborhood Schoolswestphillyschools.org/) has done a lot of work with Lea Elementary is setting up reading tutor programs (through Garden Court Community, and the Spruce Hill Community Groups) .  There is a lot of grassroots activity in trying to reach out to the schools to make them better- Spruce Hill Community Group also help build a playground at Wilson... but there is so much red tape involved in helping the schools- background checks, law suits if the playground equipment breaks, principals being overburdened and understaffed to coordinate these programs... a lot of work to be done to keep these schools alive and functioning in our neighborhood!\\ It's an uphill battle but I do believe that community members can (and do) make a difference.

response: Suburbs! For people with kids it's defintely tempting to bail out and head to the 'burbs where (if you can afford it) you get way more for your money: better schools, more property, better supermarkets, parking.
Buses\nMost convenient because it usually drops me off closest to my destination.

I hate to complain about this because I'm sure it could be much worse but I think we could have better supermarkets in the neighborhood. Drexel Park, Penn Park, Shoemaker Green, Spruce Street Plaza\nI've spent a lot of time in many of the University City parks, either catching up with friends or taking part in some of the activities offered. I think one of the fun things that can be used to help people explore other areas of the USW area are 5K/10K races. Running around the city I have learned so much about the area and I've found new places that I make mental notes of while running to go back and check out. I think setting up something like a run that highlights the many parks of the area would be neat, or some type of scavenger hunt that leads people to these interesting areas that people have discussed on these boards. For example, I now want to visit Clark Park, the Woodland Cemetery and there are some mom and pop shops mentioned that I now need to go check out!

A new park along the Schuylkill River near Bartram's garden\nSince I'm not a resident to USW and only a commuter into the area, I probably wouldn't find the new plaza or redesigned trolley portal useful, but it does sound nice. I do feel that spreading out the park along the Schuylkill River near Bartram's could lead to some interesting, green development spaces in the area.

[[[39.954856252917224, -75.1822276649475]], [[39.945241491613494, -75.17987804985046]]]\nThe obvious spot is 30th street station so I'm going to pick a less obvious spot, which is 23rd and South Street. I'm picking this spot because there is an empty building there with a lot outside that I think would make for a cool hang out spot. Additionally, it's fairly central location in the Filter Square / South of South neighborhood where I live and would utilize a bike share from my location into UCD, Center City or anywhere else in the city. There are many college student in my area and many doctors that work in the UCD as well. Therefore, I'm highlighting a place outside USW bt at the same time pointing out the other locations to travel to would be the hospital, universities and 30th Street Station in USW district. The other great spot would be a bike share to Bartram's so people could go on impromptu picnics in the summer!
replies: Those are all great spots!

response: There is a certain buzz about new places like the Shake Shack that will bring people into a new area. When the Shake Shack opened up in Center City, how many people went there and then discovered there are some really excellent restaurants and shops just around the corner. From Capogiro, to Village Whiskey to the Home Brew store just a couple places down. While I wouldn't want to see a bunch of chain restaurants, I think sometimes the bigger places can help open up the communities to more customers than would otherwise be in the area. Also, there are many people who do all they can to avoid the major retail stores or chain restaurants. These people are always looking for new hip and trendy place that no one has heard about yet. I think people want to get good customer service nowadays. People want to know that the owners care about their business. Overall, I do not believe these businesses will have an impact on Lancaster and Baltimore shopping. I rather think that places like this will help bring more people into these developing areas as it seems the move from Suburbia to the City is happening, and more buzz means more people checking out those areas.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nHaving access to larger box stores can be good, but I do not think it brings pride to the community. If we can find ways to keep cost down for small businesses throughout the districts this will bring more pride to each micro-community. For example, I wait to grab coffee at a local neighborhood shop versus buying something at Starbucks because I want that business to survive and grow. I want more smaller shops opening up because they can see the success of the shop I'm supporting. I want to be able to see the same people in my neighborhood and get to know them. We live in a big city but we should be able to have that small town feeling!

[[[39.932507461177245, -75.22477822875976]]]\nI think that single family housing is still important to the community. These homes should maintain access to mass transit and the local parks. This type of housing would seem to be a good fit for the outskirts of the district.

Rather than bringing industrial space to this area, I think it would be better to utilize this property for young family housing. I wrote about this on a previous question but I'll reiterate. I think this area could be used for trendy, green housing that sparks community and creativity. The parks would be built out and utilized by these young families. The city would just have to concentrate on building out better bike paths and improving upon mass transit into this area. I could picture people living in this community and biking to work either in UC area, or if the Schuylkill path is extended from South St to Bartram's Gardens then it would be an easy commute into Center City as well.

Well, if the sky is the limit then I would look at some of the cool designs for green buildings being introduced in Singapore, Hong Kong and Dubai. The attached is a photo of Fusionopolis, a new green concept building in Singapore. There are other designs on the inhabitat website that I think are really cool.
replies: Wow! So Green!

response: Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nI've said this many times but I think the easiest way to figure out what works is to look at examples that already work. In the past couple years, I've visited a few cities like San Francisco which I believe was voted most 'walkable' city and London who both highlight their waterfront in different but effective ways. In London, they promote activity and hold street fairs on the weekend on their South Bank. There are many restaurants, street vendors and plenty of area for people to hang out along the banks. We need to figure out ways to make it easy for people to get to these type of areas, promoting physical fitness and giving everyone the opportunity to get out of the stressful areas of the city!

A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nI think the best way to figure out how we could improve Philadelphia is to see what works and what doesn't work in other cities. On a visit to Montreal this past summer, we used the public bike share which was easy to use and very convenient to all the major landmarks.  Their bike lanes were clearly marked and seperated in the high traffic areas down town. I was quickly convinced that we need something similar in Philadelphia!
replies: Montreal rocks!\\ Montreal seems like a model city for these plans\\ Stephen, I totally agree with you! Why not to gain second-mover advantage by learning from success and failures of others.\\ Exactly what I was going for here, thanks for your comments.

response: Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Other (explain in comment)\nFirst off, I don't think people would need financial incentive if they keep getting frustrated with the alternative of driving. Removing parking lanes and making the buses run more efficient will increase ridership.As another improvement, having electronic board showing the next arrival time for each station would be ideal, as long as those times were correct. Putting up a board showing the arrival time only to have the bus come 10 minutes later would be even more frustrating.

Yes\nIt would be great to have a secure area to keep bikes, and I feel this would encourage more riders. One of the biggest issue with having a bike in the city is the worry about it gettting stolen. Seriously, where are all these bikes going anyway? I feel like GPS/Bluetooth tracking devices in bikes would be a huge business. I'm probably a little angry having had a bike stolen in the past. If the bike parking facility also offered a monthly maintenance program, I think people would really enjoy that as well.I still have concerns with some of the intersections and light timings with pedestrians but overall this would be an improvement.

I'm not sure exactly where the business is located but sidewalk improvements and in general having a clean area feels safer. This will increase foot traffic. Additionally, allowing re-zoning for multi-use space seems like an easy quick win for the city to help small business owners. Is there a reason this isn't allowed now?

Yes\nI currently utilize the Schuylkill River trail for running and biking at all times of the year. It's one of my favorite things about the city! Within a few minutes of leaving my door, I can get to an area where I can see the buildings of the city but I don't feel like I'm in the middle of the city, if that makes sense? Running along the water is peaceful and I enjoy much of the outdoor space there. I'm very much looking forward of the boardwalk extension from Locust to the South Street bridge. For those that don't use this space, you must check it out. For those that do, don't forget to donate or volunteer to many of the Schuylkill Bank fundraisers!
replies: such an expansion would also provide a change of scenery too

response: [[[39.953203169466065, -75.22074418640136]]]\nHoping not to offend too many, but living around the Drexel and Penn Campuses a while ago, I tried to never venture past 45th street at the absolute farthest. The areas felt unsafe, as shooting were reporting only blocks from my house. Additionally, there wasn't a reason to go to these areas, all the shopping, restaurants and bars were located in the UC or CC area. I'm sure there are some great neighborhood finds but I don't think I would adventure out there without a guide.

From what I've heard, the city has a big problem with the way that small business are taxed. Even as residents we have one of the highest city wage rates in the country. We need to focus on making philly friendly, especially for small businesses and the people that are shopping there. We need to go after tax cheats, investigate and eliminate programs like DROP that take money out of the pockets of hard working individuals. Celia shouldn't have to pay for being a loyal citizen of the city. She should be a beneficiary of all the great things that we can do to bring her neighborhood back to life!

I think I'm going to go with a recurring theme from a couple of my posts. I think this is a great area for innovative mixed use space. Allow for high tech business to have space within a high tech / green building. The residents would be involved in trying out new forms of green technology. Almost like a micro-city within the city, exploring new options that could be implemented across the city if they seemed to be working well within these communities.

It makes sense to have business or mixed use buildings along the rail. This will help with the previous questions regarding commuting, parking and generally improvements of traffic flow. It would be nice to mix it up and get a business that wasn't part of the Hospital or University to help bring more diversity into the area. With Drexel starting a new Entrepreneur program, maybe creating a technology innovation space, that would be rented out by up and coming small tech companies?
replies: In terms of mixed businesses, they already have an Aldi, Rite-Aid, CVS and Forman Mills in the area

response: First of all, the University City Septa station is about 3 blocks from CHOP and will be a walk across the South Street bridge away from the new location. With a station in Radnor, it seems like this would be an easy answer. However, I could understand Kevin's hesitance to not use public transportation. Having an available phone app, showing real-time septa service schedules would eliminate this barrier. Overall, this would increase ridership and reduce the amount of traffic, pollution and angry drivers!
replies: There are phone apps already. check out septa.mobi and google maps.

response: No\nI'm not trolley rider but from what I've heard fewer stops may not be the problem. Having reliable, on-time service is the key in my book.
replies: I agree, see my response.

response: With a staggering obesity problem in the country and in the city, I believe we should promote walking and biking. We need to make it easier to bike around the city and not have to worry about bikes getting stolen or where to park your bike. I recently went to Montreal on vacation and the bike share in the city is great. There are bike racks all over the city in key locations, mainly catered to tourist. The bike plan can be daily, weekly or monthly I believe. Anyway, as long as you ride from point A to point B within 30 minutes, you can take the bike and ride it around unlimited throughout the day. Think of how convenient this would be to have bike racks filled with bikes all over the UC area. People could then use these bikes to go to work through the greater center city area. These would also be used by visitors to the city to explore. We are on the right track but I think if we keep building out more bike lanes and focus on biker safety, our resident and visitors will have a much more pleasurable experience.

I think that development near the waterfront, close to Bartram's Gardens would be an interesting place to develop a small community targeted on 25 - 40 year old singles. This would be small residential condos located next to the Gardens to allow for easy meet up groups. Whether it be biking, social sport activities, book clubs or gardening. The buildings should be designed with this age group in mind, pushing the architects to link green and high tech living. I think this could be a 'test' residential area for green energy buildings, allowing these post graduate students to be involved and give input on design.

Clothing, Electronics\nThere are already many other types of stores in the area but would nice to see a high end electronics store along with a few more clothing stores that currently seem to be limited to Walnut Street in Center City.
replies: like a best buy?\\ high-end clothing?\\ I suggested middle-income clothing stores\\ maybe not a high-end electronics store either\\ electronics mid-ranged in price.

response: Residential Commercial, will help to increase housing options and allow for creation of jobs by having small businesses within these buildings. It may also help to lower the student housing cost by having the businesses pay a little higher rate.

One of the best things about Philly is the Phood. There are new restaurants opening all the time, though I frequent Center City more than USW. However, I've had some great meals at JG Domestic, Distrito and enjoyed some great beer and beer events at City Tap House. During the summer there is also a lot going on around town, including live bands at the Blockley and World Cafe Live. If you haven't been to WCL, you are absolutely missing out. In addition to live entertainment, there are First Friday events, summer festivals all about town and plenty of activity for sports in the University City area.Lastly, if you are old enough, there is no other city that can compete with Philly Beer Week!p.s. Philadelphia is spelled wrong in the Bio...you might want to fix that! ;)

While I never attended a USW High School, I did live across from the University City High School for a few years. Growing up in a different State, I understand how things could be very different. However, this school had big fights outside the school at least once a week. Perched in my 3rd floor bedroom, I would peer out my window when I heard lots of shouts coming from below. When I looked down from my window I would see 50 or so kids in a circle around 2 - 6 people that would be throwing punches in the middle of the circle. I definitely saw a few fights back in my high school days but nothing like what I saw here. The fights also went on for 20 - 30 minutes before some type of police would show up. On one occasion, I found a purse on the ground on my walk to class and I figured it belonged to someone in the school. I figured I would just run into the school office and have them locate the owner. I was met at the front of the school by two security guards and maybe a metal detector, I can't remember because it was a surreal experience. One of them had to escort me to the office, which I'm pretty sure was for my safety. I can't imagine having to go to school in these conditions. Maybe more consolidation will lead to less administration and more money for teachers and other leaders to keep these kids active in a positive way.

There are probably a few trends that have led to population decline in this area but a couple of what I feel are the more obvious. First of all, when going to school in this area 10 years ago you either stayed on campus or went out somewhere in Center City. It felt too dangerous to go beyond 40th street. Why would any students at that time want to stick around and live in an area where they didn't feel all that safe adventuring while in school? These bad stereotypes stick with you and I think it gets hard to change the landscape of any area where people feel threatened.The other trend I recently read about is that suburbia is actually becoming more of a draw for the poor due to housing prices. With more people moving into cities it's leading to higher home prices and an increase of overall living expenses. People can buy more for less outside of the inner city area and I believe this trend may impact this area of the city as well. If you tie in the first point about the crime rates, the areas of the city that will grow are the areas where people feel safe and where there is access to nice restaurants and other amenities. The University City campus area has a lot to offer with and a big campus police presence, therefore it's the only area of growth which I believe highlights these points.

[[[39.95456840543795, -75.18124061203002]]]\nThis has to be a close toss-up between  3 interesections that I'm aware and see frequently: 1. Schuykill Ave and Market 2. 30th and Market 3. JFK and Market. Actually, as I think about it there are many more as you hit rush hour around the Universities. I'm choosing a location that I mentioned in my previous comments, suggesting it could be better for vehicles and pedestrians.

Other\nMy favorite mode of transportation is my own 2 feet, whether walking, running, rollerbladding or biking. If I do use other transportation to and from USW to CC, it's usually by Taxi to be honest. I've seen other people comment on this before but I'll say it again. Time efficiency is the most important as it pertains to public transit. I would utilize public transit more often if I could check my smartphone, see that a bus will be at x cross streets in 10 minutes and know that's a reliable prediction. In a recent visit to Switzerland, all times were posted for trains, cable cars and even the baggage claim. The times were always very reliable, with everything running right on time. I guess it's because they have good watches!

Yes, from time to time.\nFor the most part, I commute by either walking or running from Center City into University City. I really do not have a set route and I try to mix up my routes, using all of the main CC to UC bridges. Ideally, I think it would be best if there were some type of pedestrian overpass around 30th and market or if the vehicle/pedestrian traffic timing was slightly altered. There are many times when arriving and leaving 30th street station by walking down market street where cars are either in the way and blocking the cross walk or people are trying to cross when vehicles have the left turn signal. It creates a dangerous environment for walkers, bikers and is probably equally frustrating to the drivers.

The Universities and Hospitals, along with the businesses that doctors, nurses and students support between restaurants, hotels and other services. I believe that UPENN is the second largest employer in the city of philadelphia, only behind the city itself.
[[[39.957381034602484, -75.18272119140624]]]\nI work in the Cira Center and very excited to utilize the Porch in front of 30th street station this summer!

response: None\nI utilize the outdoor space around Penn Park and Schuylkill banks.

One of my favorite spots to view the city is from the South Street Bridge. The reason I also use this site is not only for the way it physically bridges the University/Southwest District to the neighboring South West Center City District but how it has been a literal bridge in my life. I moved to Philadelphia from Vermont to attend school at Drexel University. While I have many memories of my times at school and there are many sites I cherish around campus, it was on one of my first few rollerblading adventures (yes, it was big back then) that I discovered this amazing view of the city. After graduating, I ended up moving across the bridge to the South West Center City area but I work on the west side of the bank. Therefore, I feel like my life is forever linked between the two districts, mostly through this bridge. I believe that many of my neighbors will have the same story and therefore any improvement in the University/Southwest District will have a big impact on our lives as well. As we now focus and learn more about the UC/SW district, I believe that we need to embrace and highlight the partnerships with these close knit areas and pathways between them.
replies: what a great narrative.

Drexel Park, Penn Park, Shoemaker Green, Spruce Street Plaza\nI have actually walked through or spent time in all these parks, and find that they are great improvements to the feeling of their immediate neighborhoods.  The green provides wonderful relief from the pavement and hard walls of our buildings, and the space allows people to meet informally and chat or otherwise enjoy the space.  None of these spaces suffers from misuse, perhaps because they are surrounded by busy schools and businesses that keep things lively.

A new park along the Schuylkill River near Bartram's garden\nI am a committed fan of parks, which allow the public to use open spaces in whatever way they want.  I don't mind the idea of improvements around the 40th St Portal, but  a cafe might go a long way toward paying for the redesign.  By contrast, parks are not sources of revenue, but they are a real boon to the neighborhoods around them.

[[[39.947958, -75.20961699999998]]]\nIt would be great to have a bike rental facility in the Clark Park area. response: I prefer to avoid chain stores--and particularly chain restaurants--whenever possible, so my foot traffic is more likely in Marcel's current location than if he moves to the mixed-use area around 30th St. However, if his business is one I have a need for, the 30th St Station area is convenient for trolley and bus transportation, and I certainly might pass by there.  Having offices or homes above a retail store is a great idea, it lets us use the space more densely and hence more efficiently.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nAll of theese are good ideas. But if I were farther out all these factors would make me more likely to cycle in.  (Of course a pair of knees 20 years younger would help as well).

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nI don't think there is a glut of parking in that part of Chestnut Street, and though a bicycle lane is a great idea Philadelphia drivers are not likely to honor a bus lane very well.  Fewer bus stops would certainly help traffic move more smoothly (right now it is also backed up by construction zones). Financial incentives are also a great idea--our buses are expensive for short distances (though reasonable for long ones).  I think a metrocard system, where riders swipe in and out of buses to pay variable fares, is also a good idea. Same card could also work for the trolley and el.

No\nI think the routes are generally rather convenient and efficient.  The set stops underground are spaced fine and eliminating stops on the surface makes little sense. Powelton Village after a big snowstorm. The roofs and trees covered with snow, neighbors shoveling their walks, digging out cars, children _playing in the snow. Everyone enjoying the closeness and quiet that the snow imposes on the scene._It's the camaraderie of neighbors, the caring for the neighborhood and the small town feel that our residential streets that make Powelton, and other University City neighborhoods, special._Now, if there were only more homeowners in Powelton, and more dedicated on-campus housing for Drexel students, this unique slice of the city would flurish.

[[[39.9498331, -75.20946429999998]], [[39.9498331, -75.20946429999998]]]\nNear my house, park, trolley, popular businesses, community node...hits all the right notes.  Let's do it!

Neutral.  30th Street and Lancaster Avenue serve entirely different populations, and you're not going to get Regional Rail commuters and (many) Drexel students to shop at 40th and Lancaster.  These need to be seen as two different animals with two different solutions.  I would visit both, because both serve different purposes.  Preserve Lancaster Avenue structures for something truly special that serves the neighborhood.  It isn't going to be a regional draw with standard storefronts -- explore innovative business ideas, think about types of operations that don't exist anywhere else in the city, and talk to Drexel and the Science Center about how some of these buildings could be used as "workshops" as is happening in 19125.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nStick to where the transit and frontages are -- Baltimore, Chester, Woodland, Lancaster.  But this cannot happen through traditional commercial corridor mechanisms.  We must find new solutions that do not rely on every neighbor shopping here and provides other services to generate revenue.

[[[32.1845875, -87.46944300000001]], [[39.9556507, -75.21661460000001]], [[39.9556507, -75.21661460000001]]]\nWalnut Hill seems very susceptible to remote landlords renting to student populations.  Given the number of new developments coming through and the manageable size of these row houses, the City should try to protect single-family in order to preserve this neighborhood for homeowners.

This will be a HUGE missed opportunity if PIDC does this through its traditional single-developer approach and doesn't take the time to think about a multi-phased approach that can incorporate some of the pressing employment needs of the USW community.  Think about the small business and artisanal production going on in the city right now...make such spaces available in USW so that people can both live and work in the same neighborhood.  Think about the full spectrum of job opportunities, not just University City satellite operations.

Integrated mixed-use development that brings the housing to the street edges along 40th Street and Market Street.  Perhaps a denser housing stock would open up some land that Altman could sell to the Science Center or Presbyterian to recoup some of the costs.

Something else we haven't thought of yet!\nMill Creek "Creek Walk" with various interventions as it flows north.  The area of USW north of Walnut Street needs more green love!  So little up there, and Lee is in a sad state right now.  Need a green asset somewhere between Malcolm X Park and Mill Creek Playground.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee\nSAFETY is what governs my bike usage: in terms of safety while riding and safety of the bike while it's parked.  If there was a Bike Share, I wouldn't have to worry about my $200-$1000 bike being stolen every time I lock it up.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit, Other (explain in comment)\nNot just Chestnut Street!  What about South, Spruce, and Walnut?  Could be a traffic nightmare, but could also be very useful.

No\nIt won't reduce congestion unless there are bikes available for sharing/renting at said facility.  Doesn't mean I wouldn't use it, though.  I would definitely park my bike there, but I imagine most travelers and commuters are not going to bring their own bike unless they are going to make the full commute from their house on bicycle alone (which doesn't seem likely).

Nothing better than residents.  Need feet on the streets!The gaps in Lancaster's fabric need to be filled to make it feel vibrant again.  Don't try to make it Passyunk or Baltimore: that's boring, and frankly, Lancaster won't work that way anymore.  Make some of those larger footprint buildings available for co-working or workshop space.  Partner with nearby USW institutions who have dedicated employees who want to put down roots in a new West Philadelphia frontier.  Create an inclusive economy that has jobs of all types, that then allows neighbors to shop in their own neighborhoods.  The same ol' commercial corridor strategies won't work on Lancaster.  We need to be more creative.

Yes\nI would use it for recreation purposes, or practical transportation when I had time to not use SEPTA.  Much better than the Grays Ferry Bridge!The connection to the Schuylkill from the neighborhoods would be crucial, though.  Right now, it's more pleasant to cut through Penn and take South Street than to go on Grays Ferry.

[[[39.9556449, -75.23621100000003]]]\nI haven't been west of 52nd Street in this area just because I assume it's also residential and therefore not that interesting.  52nd Street also seems to be the safe/unsafe boundary these days.

Well, in Celia's case, she has the 52 and 64, which both end in shopping centers, but are certainly a bit of a schlep.The reality is that Celia is not going to leave Kingsessing if she has lived there her whole life unless she is forced to, but the fact is that Kingsessing cannot support the sort of retail she would need to never have to leave her community.  One possible solution could be "trucks" similar to the West Philly Food Hub that provides fresh food to various stops along Lancaster Avenue -- one could imagine similar mobile retail options for other sorts of products.Another could be SEPTA integrating this sort of retail mapping into their own materials.  For example, every neighborhood has a map that shows their transit lines and what commercial activity is along those lines.  These can be used as reference for residents.  For seniors, the individual SEPTA vans can be used to pick people up to take people to the location itself if it's far away, or at least to a transit line so they do not have to worry about a lengthy transfer.

Drexel should build the first fully public and inclusive University-assisted school system that provides education and all-day services for K-12 residents.  Like Penn Alexander meets Harlem Children's Zone.  New schools, but also partnerships with USW's amazing institutions to provide training, extracurricular activities, research, and internship opportunities for students.  Great way to provide much-deserved opportunities for neighbors as well as spur growth along Powelton, Haverford, and Lancaster.

I would do something a little more romantic with the Provident Mutual site than filling all its green space with police car parking lots, but beggars can't be choosers.Can we talk about the public housing towers?  Elephant in the room!A lot of youth are within a two block radius of there.  Locke, WPHS, West Catholic, Lee, etc.  It could be cool to do something focused on youth entertainment.  Something active like an indoor rec facility, bowling, something of that nature that can really be a draw.  Something active like that will be needed in order to stimulate businesses under the El...it won't be possible to bring that corridor back otherwise.

Getting to UCity from 30th Street really isn't that bad.  It's called the LUCY bus.  Maybe that hits traffic also, but at least you can read or check your email instead of being behind the steering wheel.Make the UCity Regional Rail stop the end of the line instead of 30th Street.Is there a PATCO-Regional Rail link underground for a seamless transfer?  I should probably know that, but if there isn't, creating one would probably help New Jersey folk, because  there are so many RR trains running in the morning it would be a really easy (and free) transfer to make.Bike share at 30th Street that's funded by Penn so employees and students can use it for free!
No\nNot convenient, but absolutely more efficient.  Do it!  Every other city does.

Biking and north-south transit (east-west is pretty well covered).It is nearly impossible to go north-south in USW unless you happen to live along the 64 or 52 routes.  Some more routes that connect the commercial corridors from Woodland to Lancaster makes a lot of sense.  Also, add more Regional Rail connectivity through the 49th Street Station.  Just having one line go through there is pretty ineffective.

You mean housing options in terms of homeownership, not renting?  Can plans please stop stigmatizing renters as people who don't give a shit about their neighborhoods?  It is fucking infuriating and straight-up inaccurate?Alexander Wilson school site, assuming it closes.SE corner of 43rd and Baltimore.Some of those great old buildings west of 50th Street on Baltimore Avenue.The failed "Apple Lofts" site, though that could make sure sense as live/work for fabricators.  In general, there are some great underutilized buildings that are too big for traditional retail that could be great for housing.Redevelop some of the blocks south of Woodland, i.e. the Clean and Green stretch around 49th and Paschall.

Clothing stores that are more reasonably priced.
Why on Earth is this a question for the public to answer?  Leave it to the planners!

It's the old stock that makes Philly great, not the new.  She can find expensive coffee shops and "locally grown" restaurants in any East Coast city she goes to.  What makes Philly great are the little places that you wouldn't ordinarily think much of from the outside, but are bastions of goodness on the inside.  Some examples in USW include Saad's, the West Philly Tool Library, and Tiberino.

Didn't go to school here, but I generally believe that students and neighbors are well served by having access to nearby, high-quality schools. I hear about epic battles to get into Penn Alexander, subsequent overcrowding which doesn't benefit students, teachers or staff, and more expensive housing in that catchment area. Good schools foster good neighborhoods. It's easier said than done and a lot of people disagree on how to improve the school system, but having many good quality schools around the region benefits everyone and is worth the effort. Closing schools would make it harder for kids to get to school, thereby making it harder to get a good education. It also means fewer venues for after school activities, putting further stress on rec centers and leading to neighborhood decline. That said, I'm not incredibly familiar with the circumstances at these schools and the specific challenges that they face.

There is a lot to do in Philly, especially over the summer. Check out free movie nights and other events on Schuylkill Banks, right across the river from Drexel. Uwishunu has great insider tips on things to do in the city, including free concerts and festivals. The Cultural Alliance's phillyfunguide has a really comprehensive calendar and you can sign up to receive their 'funsaver' offers for 1/2 off tickets for tons of cultural events in the area.

response: Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nLiving in the center city, I am lucky to have access to the Schuylkill River park and trails. It is great place to go for a walk, a bike ride, or even a movie night! Schuylkill River Park Connector Bridge built last year made our lives even easier. Before we would have no access to the trails if a train came, we would have to wait for it to leave or try to go to Walnut Bridge, which was under construction too. Thus, the level of development the Schuylkill River Park achieved so far is very impressive. It makes working out so much more enjoyable! I wish every person in the City of Philadelphia had a chance to enjoy our beautiful parks!
replies: How often do you run along the river? I too enjoyed the easy access to the river trail. Hopefully, they'll make more access available to the UCD residents as well.

response: Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nI think if you offer someone a reward for certain behavior, they will be more likely to comply if you try to force someone to behave a certain way and they will naturally resist.There are multiple ways to incentivize employees to use public transportation to get to work instead of driving a vehicle. For example, employees might have to log the days they walk, bike, carpool or telework instead of driving  to work. When they log 30-50 (the number maybe different depending on an employer and a program) days of using alternative ways to get to work, they are eligible for vouchers at local stores and other businesses or money incentives.
replies: That sounds like an interesting program, do you really think people would change their commuting method based on small monetary incentives?

response: More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee\nI had a chance to use bike sharing in Montreal, Canada. The bike stations were located throughout the city, and as a tourist who had to cover a lot my feet the bike stations were like a blessing from the sky. It was incredibly convenient! You pay a fee for a day and use a bike for 30 minutes at a time. I know 30 minutes does not sound like a lot; however, when you are a tourist or running errands  in the city and have to get to a bunch of places, but don't want to walk or take public transportation, bike sharing is the way to go! It is a practical, economical, ecological and healthy alternative to energy-guzzling vehicles.
replies: I was there too, it was a lot of fun and felt really safe. Go Montreal!\\ Even though I own a bike, I bike share program would help me gets others out and around as well

response: More jobs is generally a plus. No one really wants to see high rates of unemployment. However, I wouldn't want to live near industry if it was putting out large amounts of pollutants. Hopefully whatever we do, we can keep the air and water around us clean and healthy.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nI already use biking as my primary mode of transit around the city. It gets me where I need to go quickly and directly. However, in some places in Center City/South Philly there aren't many good places to lock up. I usually find a street pole not too far away, but having designated places to lock up would make everyone happy I think. Also, bike lanes just make everyone safer. Biking in the city can be a bit intimidating at first, and I do know plenty of people who have been hit by drivers who weren't paying attention (talking on cell phones, speeding, etc). I usually feel more comfortable in the bike lanes.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes\nI would like to see a bus/bike lane on Chestnut.

That has often dissuaded me from using regional rail and I have opted for other modes of transit instead.

response: Chop recently built a new facility in that area. Once that is opened, it will add a medical facility to that area. And the Aldi that is there provides groceries. Perhaps some new office buildings could go in by the new Chop building?

Riding on Septa's Regional rail is pretty expensive. Kevin would have to pay about $150 a month for a monthly pass from Radnor. Perhaps SEPTA could provide more free parking for monthly pass holders and more express trains during rush hour to make the commute faster and more convenient. Also, some employers allow you to purchase pre-tax transit checks. Not Sure\nI don't ride the trolleys during rush hour, so I am not sure how slowly they go during the rush hour commute. However, it seems like cutting back on some stops would save time and be more efficient.

I think that biking/walking around the city is usually the way to go. From my home in West Philly, its just a short bike ride to many parts of Center City. South Philly is also easy to get to.Its easy to get to the Fairmount/Art Museum neighborhood by bike or car, but not by SEPTA (it would take several transfers).As a biker, I am always interested in seeing more bike lanes and more places to lock up bikes.

Some of the large Victorian style homes have already been broken up into smaller apartments. Perhaps this is the way to go for people who want a 1-bedroom apartment but still want to stay in West Philly.

Clothing, Hardware, Jewelry, Antiques\nI like the mix of shops on Baltimore ave, as well as the stores on Walnut near UPenn. Along Baltimore ave, we have lots of restaurants, but limited amounts of clothing stores or jewelry stores. I think having more stores like that could turn it into a fun and similar sort of destination as Main Street, Manayunk or Chestnut Hill. It would be nice to be able to do almost all of my shopping within walking distance of home. I would HATE to see big box stores in this area. Locally owned businesses support local economy more so than a box store does, and add more character too. I checked off hardware store because I can only think of one in this area (45th and Walnut) and the more I can buy in this neighborhood without having to get in a car, the better.

RM1. There are already a number of high rises on Penn's Campus. But for off-campus housing, I would like to see the neighborhood remain similar in appearance to how it is now. We have a lot of old, beautiful, buildings in University City and Southwest. Some of the large houses have already been divided into apartments. I like this solution because we can maintain or repair historic Victorian homes that were built in this neighborhood 100+ years ago and add a lot of character and charm. At the same time, we can acknowledge that many young people in this neighborhood are not going to buy large mansions, but would prefer to rent an apartment.

There is GREAT food along Baltimore Avenue (Vientianne, Vietnam Cafe, Gojjo, Dock Street, etc). There is also a lot of good Ethiopian food in the area, which is certainly worth checking out. Clark Park is a good place to sit outside and relax in the summer. There are also lots of shops and restaurants along Walnut Street by the University of Pennsylvania, and MadMex is always filled with college students.

I went to Lamberton Elementary School in the late 80's and have good memories of it. When I became a teacher, I did my student teaching at Overbrook Elementary School. If I just want a milkshake, I'll go to the local grub shop around the corner.  However, the city should make it easier for local retailers to do business to make sure that their stores can thrive.

I don't usually use the trolley to shop, because most of what I need is available within walking or biking distance. It might increase housing demand in nearby neighborhoods.  As long as it's light industrial, I don't really see it having a negative environmental impact.

response: [[[39.94803805428813, -75.22374826049804]]]\nI dropped the pin at 50th and Baltimore, but you could really say this about any neighborhood in the district. response: More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee\nDedicated, buffered bike lanes are, in my opinion, the single biggest thing that can make biking more prevalent in the district (and City-wide).

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes\nWhen you say "separate bus and bike lanes", do you mean a separate lane for buses, and a separate lane for bikes, or one "separate" lane for both of them. As a cyclist, I'll take what I can get, but separate, dedicated, buffered bike lanes are much better than the lanes that put buses and bikes together. Buses and bikes are, after all, fairly dissimilar modes of transportation.

Yes\nAny additional bike parking at 30th St. Station is a good idea, but why stop there? This is also an ideal location for a bike sharing station. And, while we're at it, can we add bus shelters on JFK where the Bolt Bus and Megabus operate? Or better yet, can we consider ways to make these operations more permanent (a plaza, signage, pick up parking, shade, etc.)?

First of all, I find it hard to believe that rents in those other neighborhoods are comparable. But assuming they are, I think the only way to get more foot traffic on Lancaster is to make Lancaster better. Not too many people from East Passyunk are going to say "Hey, we have everything we need right here, but let's go to Lancaster Ave. every couple weeks anyway." Create more mixed housing and allow apartments above the stores. Once there is a critical mass of businesses and other institutions creating energy, then think about improved lighting and amenities. Those things are what you do to put the finishing touches on a street, not what you do to try to get it to be economically sustainable. It has to be sustainable first.

response: I love the Car Share idea, and that added a real amenity to our lives in the neighborhood, as it kept us from having to buy a second car.  Stunk when they went from pay as you go to subscription, though, and we had to let our membership lapse.Posting routes and schedules at bus stops would be a huge plus, since many Poweltonians take transportation occasionally rather than regularly.  I think we should promote the fantastic transportation access we have in the neighborhood -- close to 30th St station, with access to the airport, multiple bus lines, trolley, and the El, as well as driving access and easy access to the bike routes to Center City.  I always felt I was walking distance from anywhere is the world, because of the rich transportation infrastructure.  Being able to get details on the fly, when I need them, about how to get places, maybe even from a Powelton transport webpage or app, would be a big jump up.

Would like to see that fostered and encouraged, since the energy is already there.

Zoning isn't the answer here -- the housing stock mostly already exists.  I don't know what the master plan says about student housing, and spreading that knowledge around would be a first step.  Clearly there is no will to enforce the three unrelated persons law, nor enough money at Drexel to build appropriate student housing for its expanding student body.  The most important change of direction I could see would be to recognize in the community planning process that Powelton and Drexel need each other.  Drexel needs Powelton to provide a zone of amenity around the campus, and Powelton needs Drexel to provide street energy and public spaces.  Lots of good working together in recent years but none when it mattered back in the 90s when our neighborhood was being trashed.

So lots of business might attract new residents, theoretically - current residents will of course protest, NIMBY-style.  Whether opening a Subway hurts a local sandwich shop, or a Starbucks hurts a local coffee shop, I don't have the data to say.  All else being equal, I'll pick a local shop though.

Keep Marcel here!  I don't know what block of Lancaster Ave. we're discussing, but the first half a dozen or more blocks in West Philly seem perfectly attractive and well-lit to me.  By the time you're well into the 40's, there's definitely a little bit of the ol' "blight" to the scene.  If the area could tolerate more residents without changing the zoning in a way that promotes the kind of building that would actually deter people from moving there (I'm thinking the charm of the Powelton area necessitates those particular types of housing units), then by all means, makes some changes.  Further west, there needs to be some sort of critical mass of businesses or *something* to convince people that the neighborhood is safe.  I don't know how you do that.  That seems to be the heart of a lot of these issues.  A neighborhood is a little rundown, therefore people assume it is unsafe, avoid it, and the neighborhood becomes more rundown.  Lather, rinse, repeat.

I'm not sure if I understand the question fully, but I suppose there's a trade-off between aesthetics and efficiency.  That is, it appears that RM-1, 2, or 3 could house large numbers of students at minimal cost, possibly at the expense of neighborhood "charm."  If students were encouraged to find housing in the RSA and RTA zones, the students would be more spread out, potentially living in more attractive, "homier" buildings while theoretically having a beneficial economic impact over a larger swath of the city.  Of course, many of these buildings are older, and I imagine as the students are more dispersed, the cost for every individual student's housing my increase.  But then I don't really know what I'm talking about.

Maybe I shouldn't say this, but "Rachel"'s perceptions of the relative safety of Boston might not be too far off.  Also as a much smaller city, Boston's attractions are more "compact."  The coolest things about Philly are sort of these tiny pockets.  Anyway, the Bottle Shop at Local 44 is about as good as it gets in Pennsylvania for take-out beer selection.  Right around the corner are several new places to eat, including Lil' Pop Shop and Honest Tom's Taco Shop.  Not bad for a random half-block in the middle of residential zoning.  I understand that all the stuff below the Radian is relatively new, though I'm not sure whether it was built within the last 18 months.  I understand there's new park space along the Schuylkill that I've not yet had a chance to check out.  All in all, I'm not sure that the newest things about USW are the coolest or best things about it, though they are signs of a vibrancy that will hopefully continue grow in the coming months and years.

I can only speak to what I've heard recently amid all the hubbub surrounding Penn Alexander's overcrowding issue (I do not have children of my own.)  A number of parents seem frustrated with their perception that Penn Alexander receives disproportionate resources (I don't know how the funding works) but doesn't have near enough room to accommodate the growing number of in-catchment kindergartners each year.  It seems to them that closing a school that could help to deal with some of the "extra" students is counterintuitive.
replies: UPENN spends an extra $1500 per student... but UPenn can't really extend that offer to ALL of the neighborhood schools.  It would be great if other universities would partner with schools... but even better if the school district would just FUND. THe. SCHOOLS!

response: I probably can't speak to that as I have only been here for a little more than a year - and most of my experience has been in Spruce Hill.  But I would be curious to see the breakdown of "flights" over individual years, though I'm aware the census is decennial.  My understanding is that crime rates (at least in some neighborhoods) have been dropping steadily since the 90's, though it's possible that people have moved in a sort of delayed reaction to earlier years.  Also I'm aware that housing prices have something like tripled within the Penn Alexander catchment, a possible deterrent - though I'm not sure that that didn't produce a net GAIN in that particular area.  Frankly my daily experience in Spruce Hill is that the neighborhood has a steady influx of young people, many of whom (myself included) have no affiliation whatsoever to the Universities.

The El\nThe El is almost always faster than the bus for East/West travel.  I do wish the 46th st station were better lit at night - I will often take the bus if I'm getting back after dark.  Demolishing those decrepit buildings across from the station helped a bit.  Finding a use for that enormous abandoned insurance building across the street to the west of Aldi would do even more...

I always promote biking as the best mode of transportation in Philadelphia. Most neighborhoods below the northeast can bike into center city within 30 to 45 minutes and the city is relatively flat. I think the number one factor in making biking difficult in the USW are trolleys. I do not see why our trolleys can't be replaced with trackless trolleys like they have on Frankford Ave. above the Frankford Terminal Station on the blue line. These vehicles run on electricity so they don't have the fumes of buses, they can carry bikes on the front unlike trolleys, they can maneuver on the street around parked vehicles or accidents, and the best part for bikers, they don't require tracks. People get hurt from getting tires stuck in tracks often and it makes them nervous to bike on roads that contain trolley tracks, which are often the most direct routes to destinations in and out of the neighborhoods. I know they look cute, but I think we could get the same level of transportation from trackless trolleys. Maybe we could get some designed to look like the green trolleys that run on Girard Ave. so people don't think they look to modern for the neighborhood.

I think the RM designationns 2, 3, 4 are appropriate for student housing as would be RMX 3 and the CMX designations.  Where student oriented development would not displaces single family home uses.Several concerns.  One is that we've seen several developments suitable only for students occur in lots now having a CMX designation that should have been rezoned for residential use.  The resulting by right developments are awful rabbit warrens of bedrooms devoid of light that will never be appropriate housing for anyone but students.  The other concern is that we have several houses cited by L & I recently for illegal occupancy by more than 3 unrelated people in RTA-1 zoned properties.  The owners have challenged the constitutionality of that law, but someone on the Zoning Board suggested the owners simply go apply for a permit for a group home.  Our lawyer later suggested that while a group home would require a "special exception" under the new code, the new code makes that an easier process for the applicant than the old code did.  This could make large neighborhoods of single family homes vulnerable to conversion into student group living especially in areas contiguous to the University.
