The Liberty Bell is unique because since the bell was made, the words of the importance have meant different things to different people. When William Penn created Pennsylvania's government he allowed citizens to take part in making laws and gave them the right to choose the religion they wanted. The colonists were proud of the freedom that Penn gave them. In 1751, the Speaker of the Pennsylvania Assembly ordered a new bell for the State House. He asked that a Bible verse to be placed on the bell - "Proclaim LIBERTY throughout all the Land unto all the inhabitants thereof" (Leviticus 25:10). As the official bell of the Pennsylvania State House (today called Independence Hall) it rang many times for public announcements. In 1915, the bell made its last trip and came home to Philadelphia, where it now silently reminds us of the "power of liberty". For more than 200 years people from around the world have felt the bell's message. No one can see liberty, but people have used the Liberty Bell to represent this important idea.

Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nI think that both the Schuylkill and Deleware river fronts are both in dire need of more public access. I would frequently use parks and trails along both rivers.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets\nSafety on the road is a big concern I hear from all my friends. People feel much safer biking when there is a dedicated bike lane that separates them from traffic. Streets like Chestnut before it hits 34th seem especially dangerous with 3 lanes of fast moving traffic and no bike lane. As on Walnut street one of these 3 lanes could be converted into a buffered bike lane for commuters coming into U city from the west. Signage can also make a big impact on getting drivers to look for bicycles. If all roads have watch for bicycle signs on them drivers are going to start doing just that.

Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes\nCurrently there is no bike lane for a large portion of this stretch. Adding a shared bus bike lane would not only create less congestion for buses but would also create a safer biking experience.

Yes\nWhile I would not personally use this facility because I work elsewhere in the city I think that the idea itself is great. This sort of infrastructure will only have a positive impact on promoting bike commuting in the city. It would be great if the facility had a bike repair shop and even showers.
Best spots to eat, Bobby's Burger Palace, Honest Tom's Tacos, Dock Street. For shopping check out Vix Emporium for local made items.
Did not attend school here.
The district has lost significant numbers of black residents while gaining only modest numbers of white, latino, and asian residents.

Other\nI usually bike, if I am going somewhere far like Northern Liberties or Fishtown I sometimes drive. I find SEPTA to be slow, dirty, and sometimes unsafe feeling, especially if you're walking home from the Market Frankford 46th street station after dark. Trolleys are better but I don't take them if its not during normal work hours. On weekends the 34 stops running way too soon and waiting at 13th street station to get home to West Philly on a Saturday night is miserable.
Yes, almost every day\nI work in North Philadelphia and commute either by bicycle or car. Using public transit takes too long, requires to many transfers, and too much walking after reaching my stop.
[[[39.95442036912019, -75.20512300109863]]]\nNear the University and Students. I feel that the people who live and work in this area are more likely to want to buy 'healthy food'.
yes
U Penn, U Penn Medical Research, Drexel, IRS, CHOP, avenue of sciences. Educational institutions create positive employment opportunities in the communities they inhabit.
[[[39.948235454392595, -75.20992951965331]]]\nAlthough Cedar park is closer to my house I find Clark park to have a much more pleasant atmosphere.
None\nDon't know whats happening at any of them. Is there a email list?
Bartram's Garden. River access and relative isolation make it a great place to escape the city.

Though I somewhat dislike the modern architecture of the Hub and Radian (sp?), I think it's time to accept that that area is going for that style--though some greenery would be nice to make it feel more livable.
Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nnot sure why, tbh.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nI ride recreationally and for exercise up and down the river trail. Extending it south would be great!
replies: the riverfront trail sounds great indeed!

response: Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit

Yes\nIt only works if getting there from center city on a bike becomes easier/less hairy an experience. I would occasionally use it, but right now, I wouldn't enjoy the experience of getting there from my home near spring garden and broad (why not do this for suburban?)
Drexel Park\nHaven't been to any of them because they're not on my way anywhere.  They're fine for students, but give me Fairmount Park or Bartam's over these any day.
A redesigned 40th Street trolley portal with trees, seating, and a cafe\n40th street needs a lot of help
[[[39.95724945219157, -75.201947265625]]]\nI'd use it mostly for out-of-town guests.  Put it on the El like at 30th or 40th Streets

One of the nice things about living on Lancaster is that you are very close to a lot of higher-end retail in UC, but there is plenty of small retail options for day-to-day items.  I don't think Lancaster will ever attract restaurants like Shake Shack, so it's fine to have them nearby and increase the overall attraction of West Philly, especially because it is very convenient to get to 30th street from most points west.

Other (explain in your comment)\nNow that I have kids the sheer volume of goods necessitates driving most of the time, but I used to bike to most things.  It helps that we live on the northern side of USW, which is closer to supermarkets and some box stores that makes biking possible.

[[[39.96086787623826, -75.20297723388671]]]\nWest Powelton/Saunders Park is beginning to be over-run with new student housing developments.  We need to act to ensure that this neighborhood doesn't reach the 75% rental status of Powelton Village and become a student ghetto.

New employment options is great, but would retain the significant neighborhood barrier that the current industrial uses create.  Mixing in some housing along Grays would help transition the two neighborhoods and help redevelopment cross Woodland Avenue.  I think all the improvements to Bartrams and now the new trail might be enough to encourage higher-income folks to invest in living in those parcels, maybe something like a condo tower with low-density industrial around (similar to Navy Yard).
2.5-4 story mixed use buildings with frontage on Ludlow, 40th, and Market.  Would be great to keep the plaza and bring it up to grade, maybe with the storefronts on 40th facing into the courtyard

Something else we haven't thought of yet!\nCreate more public parks alongside the commercial development happening along Market St west of 38th.  Especially with the potential loss of the UNI garden when UCHS closes, the area on the northern side of USW has very little green space.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee\nBike lanes can always improve, although we've made amazing strides in the last few years.Having bike sharing wouldn't change my personal habits much, but would make it easier to bike as an option when I have out-of-town guests.

Other (explain in comment)\nChestnut desperately needs a bike lane, but a dedicated bus lane only works if the cops actually enforce it, which was not the case when they tried in Center City.As noted before, reducing the number of stops could work in some places, but would have to be carefully studied stop by stop and probably wouldn't increase ridership or reduce transit times much.I wish UCD would work to create a real-time display of current bus locations or arrival times, maybe in partnership with local businesses (could be in the window), but definitely as an app, so you know how long to wait.  Some of the buses are woefully unpredictable.  It'd be great if they included trolley and subway info as well so commuters could make educated decisions about which option to take in areas that are as public transit-rich as most of West Philly is.

Not Sure\nI don't know how much of the congestion around 30th is due to the train station.  Seems to me it has a lot to do with the highway ramps, especially getting onto 676 and 76W, plus some poor street design. Seems like better bike parking at the station is an important part of a larger city-wide bike promotion program, but not sure it's going to make much difference as an individual action.As for using it, again, not sure.  There's only been 3-4 times in the last 15 years that I've wished for a better bike rack at 30th, and that's when I'm going out of town for a few days.  If it's not as convenient as the current street-level racks right by the door, I'll probably continue to use those.  Of course, I don't have a very nice bike, so....
replies: I agree that bike parking is not the single-ticket item to solve the complicated congestion issues around here, but it certainly won't hurt. While it's true that the people getting on and off the highway probably aren't in a position to switch from driving to biking, but there is some segment of the population out there that will respond to investments that make the city more attractive and safe to move around in...at least i hope. \\ Especially if it's free. Paying for bike parking has a long way to go to be accepted I'm sure.\\ Allowing bikes on all trains would also help the commuting crowd that might use a service like this.

response: The problem with Lancaster is there are big gaps in the commercial offerings, which makes it hard for pedestrians.  And there is no parking, which makes it impossible for the Avenue to attract any of the thousands of people who commute to/from Lower Merion each day.  Free (and safe) public parking lots would help significantly, as would somehow getting the businesses between 40th and 42nd to create housing in the upper stories.

Not Sure\nIt's not really a direction I go often, but I would use it for pleasure if I wanted to go to Bartram's.  Or maybe to bike out to the airport if I'm extra ambitious and don't have a lot of luggage.
[[[39.9552756856465, -75.22203164672851]]]\nThe area north of Malcolm X Park.  For some reason I just never end up passing through that way.  And I assume it's just houses so there's no reason to go.

Tax land instead of improvements!  If we flip the tax structure, it will de-incentivize speculators from holding onto vacant land, and remove the financial penalty for people to fix up their houses.  That will reduce gentrification, help people keep up their homes and streets, and allow the urban organism to do what it does best - solve community problems through collective action.And bus lines should stop every other block to allow faster transit to commercial centers.

38th Street needs more retail activity to help the Lancaster Ave corridor regain its vibrancy.  The Drew/Presby barrier is huge for pedestrian traffic.  But parking is an issue in that area so maybe keep the Walnut Center lot as a free public short-term PPA lot like they have on Germantown Ave in Chestnut Hill.  A grocery store would do very well in the center of the parcel, with smaller-level retail facing the major streets.

Mixed-use housing!!!  With the development of the new youth prison, the SSA building, the CHOP branch, and other commercial/governmental developments, we really need to make sure there are people living in the area to keep eyes on the street and create bridges to West Powelton and Mill Creek.

Frankly a major source of congestion is that Penn and Drexel are constantly alternating between huge construction projects on the major arterial roads that clog traffic all over the area.  How about forcing the universities to pay property tax (or PILOT equivalents) for all their real estate speculation and profit?  It might slow construction, and it might free up some cash for significant public transit upgrades, like connecting the CHOP regional rail stop to some other lines that go directly to where folks live.A better zoned system of fares on regional rail would also encourage more use of the R-line stop at 49th and Chester instead of paying full fare to ride one stop.
replies: Yes!

response: Yes\nThe problem with too many stops is only an issue really when you're behind a trolley in a car.  The trip from center city to USW is actually quite quick via trolley as-is.

The trolleys are great, and quaint, but frankly the bus system in Philly could use some significant upgrades.  There are some good ideas out there like real-time GPS tracking, wait time indicators at stops adjacent to community businesses, and reducing the number of stops to decrease trip time that could be implemented and would make travelling in directions other than to/from center city much easier.  Going north/south or from USW to south philly is quite difficult and time consuming with public transit.Also, make the Chestnut Street bike lane continuous!!!

There are plenty of two story houses on the western edge of the district that are perfect for small families.  Personally I think Market Street west of 38th could stand to see more housing development to accompany the expansion of the Science Center.  It would help the neighborhood transition north of Market to have more residential options there, and there is not much existing housing stock to be threatened by higher-density development.

Groceries, Hardware, Postage/Parcel\nWe could always use more grocery options, especially north of Market, but what I am often missing is a good copy center or notary public.  The folks at Campus Copy are often incredibly inattentive.  Plus the post office on 40th keeps pretty short hours.

RM-1 seems the most appropriate in residential areas since it allows for multi-family by right, although I don't think some of the rowhomes are large enough to qualify. Ideally we'd have more mixed-use buildings, especially on the main corridors, which would include CMX-2.5 and CMX-3.

Boston is terrible.  Philly has so much more diversity of neighborhoods, people, interests, and opportunities.  Plus it's a city where a young person can actually make a difference.  But it's a huge city geographically and you have to work to get out there and see what makes it special.  Spend some time past the boundaries of where you feel comfortable and Philly will lose some of its gritty edge.  Caribbean restaurants on Woodland Ave, Bartram's Garden's new meadow, Fairmount Park by Memorial Hall, see a show at the Mann Center, go to Puppet Uprising at the Rotunda.

No, but I worked at Shaw, Wilson, Drew, and UCity.  Parent involvement in the schools is terrible, but each of these schools had some great things going on and it's a shame to just cut our losses without a plan for moving forward that recognizes the existing strengths.
Moved to suburbs because of schools.  Plus students graduate and don't stay in Philly because of lack of interesting jobs.

Buses\nMy neighborhood on the north side of Market is very well served by buses, but not by much else.  It is very hard, however to get from Mantua to Baltimore Avenue north-south without a transfer or going out of the way.

Yes, from time to time.\nI usually bike.  The connection across the spring garden bridge is terrible with the merge onto the parkway.  It's also a tragedy that the Chestnut Street bike lane disappears by Penn.
[[[39.96113102688192, -75.19885736083984]]]\nEasily accessible to mass transit and to low-income populations that currently lack access.  Plus Lancaster Ave needs more retail development.
No.  Way too much green, especially considering that many people are not as mobile as others by foot.
Two major universities, including two of the largest hospitals in the country.

[[[39.94816965442095, -75.22065835571289]]]\nBaltimore Avenue for food and random encounters with old friends, Lancaster Avenue because it's close to my house, and Penn's campus for food and service retail.
48th and Woodland (Comegys)\nIt has lights on at night and is hardly used so it's great for pickup soccer.
The native meadow at Bartram's Gardens.  It makes it easy to imagine a country estate so close to Philly and yet so far in the 1800s.
Penn Park\nMy kids love Penn Park.  We have taken bikes there and run there.
A new plaza at 48th and Baltimore\nIt would be great to be able to handle business and shopping on foot without going to the congested area near campus.
[[[39.947380049825455, -75.2074404296875]]]\nI might use bike share but I'm curious as to how helmets are handled. Do people bring their own helmets?

I am more likely to patronize independent stores then chain restaurants.  I am not familiar with Shake Shack but I have been discouraged to see the success of Dominos on Chestnut St. in a location previously occupied by very good but not successful restaurants.  Too many chain restaurants detracts from the look and feel of the community.

Other (explain in your comment)\nI often drive for food and drug shopping by sometimes do my shopping locally on foot, or occasionally by bike.  I sometimes use the trolley to go downtown for clothing or specialty item shopping.
I'm not sure.

Something more consistent with the architecture of the community. One of the challenges with modern apartment design is that it can start to look dated, especially if resources that go into its building are not abundant as in the case of public housing.
Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nI am not sure because I am not familiar with Myers and Comegys rec facilities.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nBike safety is a big issue.  Drivers are not very attentive to bikers, and it can be downright scary at times. A bike trail leading from W. Phila to Center City would be amazing because it would make it easier for families, not just adults, to bike to and from Center City.  UC is home to many biking families whose kids are very competent bike riders yet we don't bike places because we don't want our children biking on these city streets.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nI like the idea of fewer stops in less congested areas, provided that SEPTA could still find a way to serve people with physical limitations who rely on bus service.  Perhaps there would have to be a "local" at least a few times/day for those who have trouble walking.  Chestnut St. from 40th to the river is very congested. I try to avoid driving or biking on that stretch but often cannot avoid it because there are many places I am coming from the West and need to reach many places on Walnut by car.  It is especially critical for reaching the 40th and Walnut St. area when coming from the West. Perhaps another route to that area could be developed?   Financial incentives are a great idea.  It's amazing how successful Trader Joe's and Whole Foods have been at encouraging reusable bag use through low-cost incentives like the chance to win a gift card and 5 cents back. Something along those lines could be considered.

No\nBike parking is a great idea, and will encourage bike usage.  Who is the intended audience for this facility?  People who would bike to 30th then take the train, rather than drive and park a car?  I don't use 30th St. Station very often so I would not have much use for the facility.
Good advertising and promotions could help Marcel.  The city could encourage other businesses to open near his so people have more reasons to go there.
Yes\nYes!  For recreational and commuter biking and, if it was nice enough, picnicking.
[[[39.944155736473796, -75.22881227111816]]]\nI've been to the post office over here but not in a long time and nowhere else. I just haven't had the occasion.  I do drive Baltimore Ave. in that area.

This is a tough one.  I'd like to keep business within our community but it is hard for independent businesses to compete on price with larger stores.  A first step would be to make sure that Celia is aware of all of the shopping options that still remain, and has a means to get to them.  Price may still be an issue. For example, the food co-op is not far from where she lives but prices may be too high for her.
A good academic public high school would be great.
Something to make the area safer and brighter and deter criminals.  Perhaps a few nice restaurants?  Young professional housing?

This is hard to answer without knowing the route Kevin is using.  There is a regional rail stop near the hospital area. It might help Kevin if the R5 stopped there.One of the biggest road problems in this neighborhood is caused by double parked vehicles.  Some blocks, such as the 3500 block of Lancaster and the 4300 block of Locust, are routinely blocked by trucks and other delivery vehicles.Chestnut Street between 43rd and 30th is also challenging. The lanes are a bit too narrow for the types of vehicles using them.  There is often road work or other activities blocking at least one lane.  Spruce Street between 38th and 33rd is also difficult for similar reasons.
No\nThe trolley is fast enough for my taste.  I would be interested in an express version of the 42 bus -- one that does not go around the hospitals.

I think that walking, biking and public transit should be encouraged.  One way to encourage public transit would be to provide more (any?) places where SEPTA tokens can be purchased. Biking would be easier if bike lane lines were maintained.  In the recent past, some lines were so faded that drivers often ignored them.  It would be great if there were a direct public transit option to the Art Museum or Parkway area.  South Philadelphia, east of Broad Street, is also a little hard to access without a car and sometimes takes more time to reach than expected.
yes, perhaps on the 13 line where multi-family residences and apartment buildings already exist.  the 4200 block of baltimore where there is an open lot?

Clothing, Other (Explain in Comment)\nI would not want to see a lot more shopping but there are some items I wish I could buy closer to home, such as: children's clothing and craft supplies such as yarn.  More high end/high quality grocery options might be useful too.  A good bagel store would be nice.
I'm not sure. Students live in a lot of different kinds of residences in this community.

Most of the good things I would suggest have been around longer than 18 mos.  Newer places she could check out include: the expanded Mariposa store, Honest Tom's Taco, Lil Pop Shop, Harvest Restaurant and Grill..
I have fond memories of attending Lea in the 1970s.
I think that this is due in part to the conversion of multi-family dwellings to single family dwellings.
[[[39.97711552885726, -75.2271814880371]]]\n52nd St. is congested at many intersections.  It is especially disorganized and dangerous where it crosses Lancaster.
Trolleys\nTrolleys and buses are equally convenient to me but I use trolleys slightly more because they are faster.

Yes, from time to time.\nI usually take the 34 trolley or 42 bus. I occasionally take the 13 trolley or 21 bus.  I sometimes drive, and occasionally bike.  Once in a while, I walk.  I would like to see more places to buy SEPTA tokens in UC.  I would also like more uninterrupted bike routes, as opposed to bike lanes that abruptly end.
not sure
University of Pennsylvania, Penn Medicine, CHOP, the VA, etc.
None\nI don't have occasion to use any. I take my kids to Clark Park. I run in Woodland Cemetery.
Garden Court neighborhood around 46th - 47th between Pine and Larchwood in the spring when the trees are in bloom

I don't think this is a one approach problem.  Marcel would need to think of all possibilities and weigh them for what works best for him considering the results and how much he'd have to invest.  I think the city should work on making the area presentable as a neighborhood not only to those that are visiting but more importantly to those that live there.  I would encourage more mixed use zoning in all neighborhoods to encourage foot traffic and ongoing activity.

Yes\nI would use it but maybe not frequently.  I would run or take my kids on their bikes.  I would go from our house to the gardens and chill out by the water.  Then go grab something to eat in center city.

[[[39.948630252893395, -75.24293141937255]]]\nI've been to many places in the district.  Much of it was what was easily reachable by trolley.  For those that are hard to reach by trolley I have driven to.  If I haven't been to an area it's probably because it's mostly residential and I don't know anyone there and there is otherwise not other attraction to the area.  I have had jobs or done studies where I have been asked to review the streetscape of an area and admittedly this was awkward at first and potentially scary as people see an obvious outsider (I'm asian) observing their area.  Even if you tell them what you're doing they may get defensive or skeptical of your presence.    What I have notice is that sometimes I am surprised by the population in a neighborhood and also I get concerned when a dynamic changes quickly.

I would work with my neighbors to work with the local government and possible investors to have such stores in the area.  I would start with requesting a transportation loop for those that need it and could benefit from it hat would help complete errands.
If remediation of any issues was available there are many options.  Charter schools, condos, office space for startup, cultural institutions. could make use of the buildings.

I would do mixed use development.  Something to encourage foot traffic in this corridor.  Give some residence as an option.  I would add office or institutional space as the area now has other types of institutions nearby - CHOP, Juvenile facility, CDC.  I think it will be nice to encourage some organizations to locate there and have some civic engagement.

Kevin should move into the city and walk to work.  Incentives to use other modes of transportation either through government or employer programs might be helpful.  To do so we'd need to set up infrastructure or work with SEPTA to make it work.
Yes\nPeople should walk more.

I would encourage biking/walking and public transit.  This would help with the health of our people and is environmentally friendly.  I think minimizing the number of transfers one needs to go east and west is important.  I find it difficult to get to south Philly via public transit.  Sometimes I opt to drive for the sake of convenience.

I think that there are a number of vacant lots throughout the neighborhood and along the trolley routes.  This is a neighborhood that people want to live in.  I think developers would do well and see value in developing low to medium density residences in the area.

Hardware, Electronics, Office Supply\nI think that we have a variety of stores in the area especially along the major thoroughfares.  There are obviously more of some types than others, i.e. bodegas, food, hair spaces. etc.  I would like to see more of the other type of stores but I'm not sure how well they could complete or be sustainable.  I admit I would go to a larger chain and drive there because they are cheaper.  I could see myself going locally if I was in a rush or for a matter of convenience.  I don't really want to see large chains in the neighborhood.

I would recommend a low to medium density zoning district.  I believe the lower densities encourage a community of people getting together and bonding.  This will conceptually add to a better social environment and alert criminals that this is a community that cares for one another and would support one another.  I would like mixed use as an option to encourage foot traffic amongst our sidewalks to also encourage community engagement.

I was Rachel when I went to college.  I would have rather gone to Boston as well. I spent my first two years going back to NY each month to have fun.  Rachel should hang out with natives.  She'll learn the cool stuff about Philly.  There are so many different neighborhood with different cultures that you can keep discovering new things all the time.
No. I chose and was lucky enough to be able to send my kids to a charter school in Center City.
They probably went out of the area or Norther Liberties or Fishtown.  Similar culture but cheaper.
[[[39.95435457509754, -75.19199090576171]]]\nI try not to go by here much during rush hour. I would rather take the South Street bridge or travel back to 47th and go over the Gray's Ferry bridge.

Trolleys\nI live right off of the #34 trolley route.  It seems to me to have the most frequent number of trolleys out.  I like that I can look out the window and observe the neighborhood.  The service seems to serve the times I need.  If I go out late I will take my car.

Yes, almost every day\nDuring the week, I take my kids to school. We take the trolley and switch to the Broad Street and then walk to blocks. I then hop on the 40 to travel on Lombard to get back into U. City for work.Outside of these times, depending on what I'm doing and who with I will drive or use public transit to get to center city.
Yes it looks about right but every day I find myself looking for good health options at a reasonable price.  The food trucks are responding to this and more healthy options are cropping up.

There are large institutions in USW - colleges/universities: Penn, Drexel, USP; Hospitals: HUP, Mercy; government: post office, IRS; and research is growing and it's quickly becoming a hub.  There are many employers for the research institutions.

[[[39.94969, -75.19491199999999]]]\nI work at Perelman Medicine School.  I have been working at Penn for many years.  I like the work/life balance it affords me. I also like being able to walk to work.
None\nI like to go to Clark park for activities.  Otherwise we go to the West Philly YMCA at 52nd and Chestnut.  I do want to try 49th and Woodland for the spraygrounds in the summer.

Clark Park - It's a place for everyone.  The children can go there to play on the playgrounds or in the bowl.  Everyone likes to shop at the farmers market.  I really enjoy that people can simply play a game of chess/checkers or sit back and chill/read the paper in the furniture provided.  If anyone gets hungry they can hit any of the multitude of stores along Baltimore Ave or around Clark Park.

Rachel, my favorite place to eat is Vietnam Cafe, which is not far from Drexel and a short walk from the #34 trolley.  It didn't open within the last 18 months but don't let that stop you.  Newer places include Local 44 and its companion bottle shop, the popsicle shop around the corner from there, and I hear there's a Shake Shack coming to Drexel's campus.  You don't have to stray far from campus to have a little bit of fun.
I did not attend public school here.

Very few parts of the city are gaining population.  Many jobs are outside of the city; people leave to work closer to their homes.  People also leave to find better schools and to take care of other family members.

[[[39.95129508317233, -75.19920068359374]]]\nThis intersection could use a redesign...lots of pedestrians mixing with the buses, vehicles looking to get to the highway, bicyclists, and lots of vehicle turns make for a hazardous intersection.  This could use both turning lanes and perhaps some pedestrian bumpouts.
The El\nWhen I use transit to get to work, it's a combination of the El and the Norristown High Speed Line.  For leisure I end up using the trolleys the most.
Pretty much never\nHow I get around depends on where I am going.  If I'm going to Center City I use public transit.  Other parts of the city are not so easy to access without a car.

[[[39.95359793929699, -75.22065835571289]]]\n49th and Spruce - is a parking lot now.  This wouldn't be the biggest store.  Would be interesting to see a food store go into the ground floor of the former West Philadelphia H.S.

Yes and no.  It appears that institutional uses like the University of the Sciences are included - which has access to dining options on campus and restaurants nearby.  And the map doesn't seem to take into account the food co-op on Baltimore Avenue.  That being said, Philadelphia (this neighborhood included) is underserved by full service grocery stores - or even corner stores with healthier options.
There are a lot of major employers here: the various universities and hospitals and the Science Center, for starters.

[[[39.948262, -75.21007299999997]]]\nClark Park would be the most, followed by the various resources that the neighborhood around the University of Pennsylvania has to offer - be it the hospital, the cultural events, or the restaurants.
None\nI don't use any of the recreation centers.  Perhaps that will change as my family grows.

Cedar Park is the place that is most beautiful.  It is a much-used and much-loved park, that teems with life every time I go by.  Kids playing soccer, the weekly farmers market, the playground, the drum circles...it's so nice to live so close to this great resource.
replies: Make that Clark Park.  I am keyboard-challenged.\\ Seconded. There really is a great mix of things that go on at that park!

response: Penn Park\nHaven't really spent time in any of these...

[[[39.95274260178683, -75.20696836090087]]]\nWith the UPenn and UScience so close to historic victorian homes, it can be very tempting for developers to buy the old homes and carve them up into as many apartments as possible to accommodate students and earn maximum rents. Zoning can protect the historic neighborhood while also ensuring some high density in appropriate spaces to increase the likelihood of our mom and pop shops staying in business and providing amenities to everyone.

response: Walking, biking, and taking the trolley to work are awesome options, but we have to attract Kevin to move to the neighborhood for that to work. Drop the commute, Kevin! response: Apple Lofts would've been a great addition for this purpose and is right on the 34 trolley line within walking distance of Maripsoa, Dock Street, VIX, and everything that's coming up there. What a shame- it would have been a great addition to the neighborhood- and continued some of the westward rejuvenation of old building stock that needs badly to be repurposed.\\ Right, after that huge zoning process and approval, the Apple Lofts building is up for sale.

response: Groceries, Clothing, Bodega, Other (Explain in Comment)\nCorridors like Baltimore Avenue and Woodland Avenue need to keep filling in vacant properties with businesses that have frequent neighborhood business (ones we will go to more than once a month). The wine shop, coffee shops, grocery stores, and certain restaurants are extremely popular. We're oversaturated with second-hand stores. Talking Headz was a great addition for a higher end hair salon. We could probably handle another. Might be able to handle a higher end nail salon. Honest Tom's Taco Shop, the Cedar Park Cafe, Manakeesh have been popular new restaurants. The Bottle Shop by Local 44 has been a popular and welcome upgrade to the less great beer distributors. Eleana's Soul is a huge loss -- would be great to have another good bar/food and jazz venue like that. If there's any way to relocate the mechanic shops in the prime locations between 45th and 46th on Baltimore Ave, those would be prime areas for more neighborhood-friendly options, perhaps a nice brew pub?
replies: Everyone loves brewpubs!\\ Oh- a good day spa would probably see some traffic too (Baltimore ave or Spruce closer to the student housing)!

response: Commercial/residential mixed-use with student housing in floors above and commercial on first floor, or more dense options near public transportation and close to universities. Checkout the summer Dollar Strolls on Baltimore Avenue to sample a lot of local options. Go for a fancy date at Harvest. Get a beer at Fiume, Local 44, or take a six pack home from the Bottle Shop. Honest Tom's tacos and burritos are worth the trip too.

Hopefully it won't be as ugly as The Hub in the background....Beyond that, I think it's what's inside that counts. A mix of smaller and larger apartments is key. If all the 2-bedroom apts are huge and showy and expensive, you'll attract wealthier tenants. If they are all small and simple, you'll attract less-well-off tenants. Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Other (explain in comment)\nBusses tend to clump up. Everyone waits and waits and waits for e.g. the first 42 to come, and get on it, so it waits; meanwhile a second 42 and then a third 42 get backed up behind it. So there is a 16 minute wait for what should be 10 minutes between busses, and then all of a sudden there are 3 in a row. So what needs to happen is busses, which already have GPS tracking devices on board, need to have a policy where if a bus of the same number is 2-3 blocks behind it, the bus flashes a "next Bus 42 in 1 min" sign and just keeps moving. If they get too close together, the first bus is already ridiculously late so waiting passengers are understandably mad, but if they do this enough to stay on time, busses could actually be a bit reliable. Oh, and OF COURSE, we need to start ticketing double-parked vehicles. What the heck. They snarl everything up. I can't believe it's so tolerated in this city.

Yes\nAbsolutely overdue! It's easier to get around in a city which has infrequent and never-on-time busses and trolleys if you just bike. If you can't take your bike with you, you have to lock it up nearby and risk losing your wheels, seat, lights, bell, panniers, etc. to theiving miscreants.

Something new and exciting and different from the infill that's already in this area. A building similar to Basket Apartments by OFIS Arhitekti might draw new residents to the neighborhood (http://www.dezeen.com/2012/10/11/basket-apartments-student-housing-by-ofis-arhitekti/).

[[[39.96869617477193, -75.21705346679687]]]\nI have never been to the Mill Creek neighborhood -- safety is definitely a concern, but I am also unaware of any great development/retail/interest points that would inspire me to visit.

First, the city needs to support new, small businesses in these neighborhoods so that residents aren't forced to shop elsewhere. There are some excellent incentives for new businesses that many people may not be aware of, in which case the city should be providing better education for its residents and entrepreneurs. Better transportation is needed across the city, but there are also a huge number of existing, vacant buildings in other neighborhoods (that are closer to transit, are safer, and have better retail options) that the city can rehab and offer to older and low-income individuals and families.

More public green space and gardens, especially for those in the community who use the existing school gardens. There are many potential uses for adaptive reuse of the closed school buildings, and the adjacent land should be used in conjunction with the targeted or planned reuse.

I have never used this station and don't spend much time in this area, so I am not knowledgable about what this neighborhood might need. Perhaps food/coffee options for commuters? Grocery stores, security/police offices? This is not necessarily an ideal spot for residential buildings, especially given the vacancy rates nearby. Perhaps community or urban farms, or public green spaces might also be popular here?

Alternate, trolley-free routes might be one way for the district to ease some of the congestion, as well as incentives for car-pooling. Better enforcement of bus-only lanes could also help and perhaps encourage commuters to take the bus rather than drive. Perhaps express shuttle services from 30th Street station to some of the work nodes around University City would be an incentive?
No\nThe amount of stops isn't a problem, because it makes the ride more convenient for all who use the trolleys. More frequent trolleys and adherence to schedules, however, would save much more time.

The city should encourage more biking in the district, and could do so by providing safer, protected bike lanes. Public transit could also improve DRASTICALLY so fewer residents feel the need to drive.

There are a number of vacant lots along the trolley lines in West Philadelphia (past 45th Street) that offer the opportunity for developers to build affordable, lower-density housing aimed at young professionals that still fits in with neighborhood character.

Groceries, Hardware, Postage/Parcel\nFor everyday errands in the neighborhood, it's difficult to find a post office (or post box!), hardware store supplies, and sometimes even groceries. I would not advocate for big box stores (such as Lowes or Home Depot) in the neighborhood, but more small businesses and selection would be ideal. Smaller specialty grocers would also be a great thing to have more of in the neighborhood.

RM-1 would be the best fit for student housing is USW. It allows for multiple dwellings in one building, as well as the potential for some types of small business and office space, but keeps the neighbor character and would likely lead to more community relationships. Large apartment complexes and infill projects are not ideal for this district.

Lower property values in other areas of Philadelphia closer to Center City have probably attracted many young residents wishing to become homeowners. In addition, the population of USW is largely transitory -- students, visiting scholars, etc.

[[[39.94899214951649, -75.20362096405029]]]\nWoodland Avenue from Chester Avenue intersection to S. University Avenue is a transit nightmare during peak times. The whole area surrounding the 40th Street Portal is incredibly unfriendly to pedestrians, and often unsafe. Cars are parked illegally in the street and bike lanes, there are no traffic lights or crosswalks, and several types of SEPTA transit, as well as other buses use the area as parking. It is nearly impossible to cross the street, and the area is also dirty and not well-lit for being such a major transit hub.

Trolleys\nI often take the trolley because it is the closest option for where I live and allows me to easily transfer to other transit options. However, it is incredibly unreliable. Buses and the El are my second most-used modes of public transit in the city, but only if I am headed to a destination inaccessible by trolleys.

Yes, from time to time.\nWhen walking/biking, there is not enough of a barrier between pedestrian/bike traffic and automobile traffic on the bridges from USW and Center City. Other forms of transit (bus, trolley, subway via SEPTA) are unreliable, crowded, dirty, and often feel unsafe (at certain off-peak hours). When 2+ people are making the commute, SEPTA is also too expensive (it's much easier and cheaper to hop in a car with a few friends to Center City and pay for parking downtown than it is to wait for SEPTA transit, and pay fare both ways).

The city should improve public transit and paratransit options to help those who have difficulty getting around. At the same time, the city should look at ways to incentivize small business and retail operations (NOT chains) to move into these vacant areas.
Keep the new developments in similar scale to neighboring facilities. The city should sponsor new affordable housing complexes with active ground-floor retail.

Kevin could park a little farther out, if it's practical, and switch modes of transportation. Yes\nThe frequency and small distance between stops on the trolley make it slow and unreliable compared to other modes of transportation, particularly driving. Eliminating a few stops would certainly help a lot.

The city is a network; people are originating and going to different points throughout the city and the region. In order to address all these transportation options, and reduce the necessity of a car (environmental, health and cost issues make it impractical for many residents), the city should plan to share the roadway with all means of transportation. Trolleys and buses are low cost options and particularly helpful for those with disabilities or who can't walk very far. Routes with the highest ridership potential should be explored and expanded, particularly in fast growing parts of the city. But these routes, by nature, are fixed systems and can't be as flexible as others. The city should also look for places to add  new bike lanes and improve pedestrian connectivity. Many places in Philadelphia, including the USW district have a long way to improve this type of work, so there are a lot of opportunities for progress.

I think there is room for this kind of housing. Philadelphia should allow for building owners and developers to create smaller homes that can be rented for lower prices to professionals. The city could explore one room apartment and other subdivision designations that will help keep housing costs low and accommodate young urban professionals the city needs to grow economically and physically.

Both! There a lot of ways to encourage foot traffic and help businesses in neighborhood commercial corridors. For one, pedestrian and crosswalk improvements go a long way. Consider streetscaping and lighting enhancements as well. Traffic calming and better traffic light timing may make pedestrians feel more comfortable strolling down the street. In addition, Marcel should get like-minded business owners together and start a coalition of business owners to do neighborhood cleanups and lobby City Hall for improvements or more small-business friendly government policies. Lastly, Baltimore Ave has a "brand" and monthly dollar strolls in the summertime, consider something like that.

The city should provide more assistance to small and start-up businesses that can locate to some of the existing buildings in her neighborhood. That being said, culturally our country has already changed towards a more "big-box" and suburban shopping lifestyle. SEPTA should reflect this change and provide adequate service to nearby shopping centers. Making the city more pedestrian friendly would go a long way, or encouraging urban-friendly big box development while still allowing the neighborhood to retain its character would be a good idea.

These buildings should be retrofitted into student housing or market rate apartments, perhaps for grad students. However, open space or parking lots should be redeveloped into something everyone in the community can enjoy (remove parking lots and turning them into parks or community gardens would be a great idea).

The 46th Street El station is screaming for re-development. First off, there are many vacant lots nearby which can be developed on. Due to proximity to the El, this calls for mixed-use, DENSE residential and retail/shops. I don't believe this part of the city can support office space. Something on the order of 5-8 stores would be appropriate, without overshadowing the neighborhood too much. There is also a suburban style grocery store nearby which should be redeveloped into something street fronting and urban, but retaining the tenant if possible (Aldi). Finally, some of the existing rowhomes nearby are simply beyond repair -- it may be necessary to remove them and join with other lots to complete this sort of development.

I think Kevin could consider taking Regional Rail more often. As far as I know, there are shuttles that run between 30th street and Penn's campus/CHOP in addition to the abundant trolley service that passes through 30th. Perhaps a more direction connection between the 30th street regional rail station and the SEPTA system could be introduced. In addition, perhaps train shuttles that run between 30th street and the University City SEPTA regional rail stations.

Yes\nYes, but I think this should be done strategically and with neighborhood input. There are some blocks certainly short enough for elimination, but other sections may have long enough blocks that stops should not be eliminated.

USW is extremely lucky to have such a diverse array of transportation opportunities, however there is still room for enhancement. Firstly, trolley service should be upgraded to become wheelchair accessible. Secondly, traffic signal prioritization should be introduced so trolleys no longer have to wait for red lights. The 21, 40 and 42 are all very crowded during peak times. Consider traffic signal prioritization for these bus routes in additional to bus rapid transit or "express" bus services between Center City and West Philly.

I think we should resist retrofitting too much existing houses to fit the needs of new residents. West Philadelphia's gorgeous Victorian architectural style is too unique. (Besides, isn't this complex only about 10-15 years old?) And you know what would improve this complex? Trees! The rowhouses that replaced the high rises around 13th & Fitzwater are pretty nice, in that they have actual architectural detail and are not cookie-cutter cheap construction rowhomes. Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nMore shade! Shade structures, trees, something is needed at all of the facilities mentioned here to make them not a living hell in the summer. But green space is different from recreation space--one provides for stormwater management, cleaner air, and a visual break from concrete, and the other is a space meant to be actively used by people who want to increase their physical and mental well-being. Don't conflate the issues.

Partnerships between rec centers would be great too. With the right technology like Skype and videoconferencing options kids (and adults) from different areas in the city could interact and share resources so if one community is lacking in something another that has access to more resources can share.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nLiving in Southwest Philly and not being a real avid biker as it is I would love having a bike parking option at 30th St. to help cut my travel time and still allow me to bike at least halfway to my destination. It's actually pretty difficult (and time consuming) to bike from Southwest to say, Northern Liberties, particularly for someone who doesn't bike everywhere to begin with.) So a shortened route, parking at 30th St. or safer bike lanes would definitely encourage me to do it more.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes\nI think a combination of the second and third options would be a nice adjustment. While removing parking on Chestnut seems helpful unless there are other places for people to park removing the current spots might just increase congestion elsewhere. Perhaps moving forward, development in University City should incorporate more affordable parking (particularly for residential and/or medical facilities) and short toerm parking options so that on-street parking isn't the only option for people.

Yes\nI have always thought this would be an excellent idea for commuters. Since Philadelphia is such a large city, even with our very good public transportation system, often commutes can involve multiple transfers. By allowing people to ride at least halfway to their destination it would encourage people whose trips are otherwise too long by bike alone to both support public transit, take cars off roads, and encourage healthy activity. They have been doing something similar in Berkeley California for almost 15 years with bike lockers, it's high time we catch up.

[[[39.96317041003146, -75.34906106567382]]]\nShould we really be zoning for single-family homes within the city? I think we should be encouraging higher housing densities, particularly in areas with access to mass transit.

Attracting new businesses to this area would be great - light industrial, research, or otherwise - but I think it's important to try to match those jobs with the skill sets that already exist in the neighborhood. I also think there's an opportunity to partner with local universities such as USP, Penn & Drexel on new research initiatives. Finally, while I would support more manufacturing jobs, I think the last thing this section of the river needs is another toxic industry that is harmful to the environment, so let's keep it clean...In terms of parks, how about something along the lines of the Gas Works Park in Seattle:

I think higher density housing makes sense for this corner, especially given the proximity to the subway. Not sure it needs to be a tower (there's already a tall building directly across Market) but maybe something more at the scale of the photo below. I still like the idea of a small park along 40th, but not one that slopes down from the street. Most importantly, we should avoid large parking lots that front directly onto 40th street!

Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nMay be a long time horizon for this, but I think extending the Schuylkill River Park to Bartram's Garden (and beyond?) and then improving access from different points in the neighborhood to the river would be fantastic, especially the idea of connecting to Cobbs Creek Park.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets\nCanada has it right! Cities like Montreal and Vancouver (pictured) have dedicated bike lanes that are physically separated from traffic. I would be much more likely to bike through the city, especially with my kids, if there were a dedicated route like this:

Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes\nPaint is cheap...I think a dedicated bus lane + bike lane painted with a solid, bright color would be effective. Chestnut could work well west of the river, but it gets dicey once it narrows down in Center City. A wide street like Market would work much better, especially near City Hall where it is widest. I would be hesitant about the idea of placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas--wouldn't these areas also have a greater density of riders?

Not Sure\nI'm conflicted...A definite Yes to encouraging more bikes and discouraging cars as much as possible. I see 30th St primarily as a hub for mass transit, not as a destination for cars, and I want to encourage people to use mass transit! However, I don't see people who commute to work by bike from West Philly wanting to switch at 30th St. Likewise for people taking the regional rail in from the suburbs. How about a bike sharing hub at 30th St aimed more at leisure riding than commuting? Certainly would be great access to the Schuylkill River Trail and as a starting point for exploring the rest of the city, especially for people arriving from out of town by bus or train...

One industry or warehouse would be fine, but if split up, it should be mixed-use. I bet Penn or Drexel might be interested as well.

Outdoor cafes would be nice near the playing fields of Drexel. Above-ground and underground retail would make a good transition between the residential areas and the station, and would permit lingering around the station, make it a meeting place, keep many eyes on all areas throughout the day, making it safe, and make it a destination instead of a quick transition place. See Munich's Viktualienmarkt or Sofia's use of underground passageways (http://www.picturescolourlibrary.co.uk/hybrid/data.svt?viewpage=picture_details_np.jsp&pclref=2596432).

Hire a German for mass transit planning and renovation.Philadelphians aren't afraid of a fight - so take on the auto industry. Population growth might be rising or steady, but it's still going to be growth, not decline, for the foreseeable future. Adding cars or more lanes for traffic doesn't even delay congestion - once people think they can drive somewhere quickly, they will. We must discourage driving. That means (once again a nod to Jane Jacobs) making streets narrower, parking sparse and expensive, walk signals that stop all traffic for pedestrians, and giving an out to a commuter - mass transit. The benefits will greatly exceed the costs, which will be worthwhile even in the short-term (see Weisbrod and Reno, _Economic_Impact_of_Public_Transportation_Investment_, 2009, avail. at http://www.apta.com/resources/reportsandpublications/Documents/economic_impact_of_public_transportation_investment.pdf). Long-term, the prohibitive cost of commuting by car will put all the money that used to go to car maintenance, gas, parking, etc. into the mass transit system. Not to mention the safety benefits - how many times have you seen or heard on the morning traffic report auto accidents on Philadelphia's major arteries?

Yes\nEvery four blocks minimum on a stretch that includes more than one destination, if the blocks are less than 1/10th of a mile long. More often than that is a godsend to few and an annoyance to most. When I lived at 38th and Powelton, I took the #10 Trolley, which stopped three times within a one-block section of 36th Street between Market and Lancaster.

Mass transit should be first and foremost, parking lots should be moved underground, and bike lanes should be added to sidewalks, not streets. Hire a German to plan a restructure of the public transportation system. Yes, I'm biased, but one cannot refute that German commuters generally get upset if a trolley is more than two minutes late in any of their cities, while Philadelphians routinely curse SEPTA for buses and trolleys that run so erratically in timing that schedules are completely ignored by commuters. Parking is difficult enough as it is, with no plan to get better. Building underground garages will (a) free up space for bikes on streets, (b) allow for easier controlling of parking environments by garage employees, (c) discourage the use of cars, as will the higher cost of parking, and (d) pay for itself within a few years. Underground parking can also be added to residential zones, including under or in the basements of rowhouses and duplexes. Bike lanes should be between pedestrian sidewalks and traffic, not between parked cars and traffic, for safety reasons including visibility.

There are already a wide range of housing options on the trolley routes. Rowhouses, apartment buildings, and vacant lots line a good portion of Woodland Avenue along the Route 11 trolley, and larger houses, duplexes, and rowhouses are found along dog-friendly Baltimore Avenue. There should always be room for new housing options for any demographic in any area of a city. If I were Sarah, I'd look for an apartment in a large apartment building with a concierge, or rent a room above a street-level business. In either case, she would join her fellow users of the building in being another set of eyes for safety and hands for community needs. Another option would be to rent a room in a larger house, trading communal living for lower costs.

Groceries, Clothing, Convenience Store, Drug Store, Bodega, Hardware, Hair Salon, Antiques\nThe options checked are examples, not necessities. A mix of stores attracting a demographically-mixed set of shoppers at different times of day is important - a steady stream of people at all hours makes the neighborhood attractive and safe. Small stores are preferable in order to be pedestrian-friendly.

CMX 2.5- mixed use encourages use at all hours of day and night (see Jane Jacobs and J.H. Kunstler)- pedestrian-friendly means fewer cars, more safety; a destination (add benches!)- parking should be in underground garages: more space, out of sight, easily controlled- flexible architectural structures allow for retention of historic or aesthetically-pleasing buildings and utilitarian filler or whimsical expression- Does "Community Garden" include courtyards? What about rooftop gardens? Businesses should be allowed to expand above ground floor - how popular would a rooftop cafe be?- Think "Why not?" instead of "Why should it be allowed?"

There were some lovely places to live, and I would have shopped on Lancaster Avenue frequently. But one of the things I did as a prospective buyer was to stop into the police station at 39th & Lancaster and ask what they thought of the area. And I was told very plainly that they thought I would be stupid to move there. I think they're wrong (there were some lovely blocks where the neighbors were friendly and there was space for a large garden). But I realized I would have felt stupid later moving in, having something happen, and then needing to call the police. So maybe just having the city not give up on its infrastructure would help Marcel a great deal.

[[[39.948058, -75.22062199999999]]]\nThe co-op is just 4 blocks from my house and the perfect place to go grab whatever groceries I need for the week or for a dinner party in the neighborhood.  They do great sourcing, they're super friendly, and I like their membership structure.

response: 48th and Woodland (Comegys)\nMy ultimate frisbee league often has games here and I've occasionally played basketball on the courts there. Clark Park in the late summer/early fall is the epitome of West Philly beauty.  Bustling with activity (Shakespeare in the Park, Farmer's Markets, Picnics, Flea Markets, Dog Walkers, Kids, and Sports), it is a wonderful community resource year round but never best than in August/September/October. A new plaza at 48th and Baltimore\nI like all the ideas, but 48th and Baltimore is closest to me and I know that in order for me to use it frequently it has to be close. Otherwise, a park along the river close the Bartram's garden would be lovely.

[[[39.95318672067416, -75.2163024482727]]]\nFor me, it would have to be close to home. I would like to have it somewhere along Spruce Street, preferably by the tennis courts on 47th. replies: I definitely think that mapping these bike share racks out so everyone is within x blocks of one from their homes would be great.

response: In moderation, I think they can have a positive impact to draw people in, but if they start out-competing local business that it's bad. As an example I know people who work in Center City that came to USW just to go to Bobby's Burger when it opened. But while they were there they noticed how much other things the district had to offer and had desert at the more local Capogiro.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI shop online, unless it's for food, which I do locally, unless it's something special, which I have to go to Wholefoods to get, and in that case I drive (shame on me :-( )

[[[39.87891303366479, -75.19336419677734]]]\nI don't understand why it would ever be good to only allow single-family housing, which is why I'm supposing I have misunderstood this question. I can see why you wouldn't want factories spewing smoke in some areas, or why you wouldn't want a high-rise blocking all the sunlight for a park, but otherwise not...
replies: A variety of housing styles needs to be built in a close proximity to each other in order to create a livable neighborhood!

response: I think it's a great idea, as there is enormous potential in that area. I also think it would be a good thing for the USW district. USW is already connected both through Grays Ferry Ave and S. 34th Street. If biking was improved it would be very easy to get to that area, the new (not yet built) parks along the river. You live in USW and bike to work by Grays Ferry. While they are at it, they should make it easier to continue biking to FDR park. I've done that bike ride a couple of times to play tennis in FDR, but it wasn't the most pleasant bike ride. With good bike baths it would be, though. And the quickest way to get to FDR Park.

I don't know the details on the affordable housing, but to me it makes more sense to spread out the beneficiaries of affordable housing instead of concentrating them in one area. If that is the case I would like to see mixed use high-rises with commercial property on the ground floor, and to mix the tenants where maybe 20% is part of the affordable housing program.

Something else we haven't thought of yet!\nThe river is beautiful and should be utilized for parks and recreation, but I'm a little torn as to how to answer the question. I believe in having real close access to green space, and since the river is a 15-30 minute walk for me, I wouldn't use it as frequently as I would wish. Instead, I'd like to see more small, neighborhood parks. The city owns a lot of dilapidated buildings. If you had a quarter block of fallen-in-on-themselves buildings, I say tear them down and build a neighborhood park.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nNumber 1 is definitely more physically separated bike lanes on city streets.  Being able to lock up your bike is a big plus, but getting there and back safely is by far the most important thing.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit, Other (explain in comment)\nAll that, a circular subway line, and keep improving the biking possibilities.

Yes\nI think it's a great idea, but it has to be coupled with better ways to get to 30th street station by bike. I currently don't use 30th street station in my commute, but if I did, I would definitely bike like to be able to lock my bike safely at 30th street station.

All the options seem good to me. Lancaster Ave is a great location, or should be. It has trolley lines, is close to the city, and close to the fairmount park. Re-zoning to allow for more people to move into the area would be good. Good sidewalks and lighting is essential, and I think has been a boost to Baltimore Ave.
Yes\nI would love it. Our little family would bike out and have a picnic in Bartram's Garden on a nice spring or fall day.

[[[39.93665368473341, -75.23645120239257]]]\nCobbs creek and the Moriah Cemetery are places I've heard about, and I've passed by by car, but never explored. I would love to take my toddler there sometime, but my general feeling of the surrounding area is that it's a little unsafe. Also, I would love it if I could safely bike out there from where I live, but there are no safe bike routes that I know of going in that direction.

This is a hard one. If Celia knows someone computer savvy, she might ask to learn how to order most of her necessities  on-line (groceries and clothes). Obviously, Celia can use the trolley line on Chester avenue to get into Center City, but there are fewer options to get out to other stores (and the trolley will only get her to Market street). Again, I think a more extensive underground subway system would be great, and a way to quickly get to many places in the city.

The district is in desperate need of good, local schools, so it's a shame that they are getting closed down. That aside, I think a mixture of affordable and luxury apartments and condos could bring people in if it's also mixed with a good recreation center with pool, spa, sports facilities, and, as always, high quality food - grocery stores.

The Provident Mutual building is right there! This is one of the most beautiful buildings in the entire city! The building could be turned into mixed used condos/apartments and commercial. Otherwise, I think small cafes, lunch places, restaurants, and, perhaps, a grocery store would make the area much more alive with people.

Kevin can take the commuter train to 30th street and then change to a trolley (or walk the last mile). If he has to drive, perhaps he can carpool? There are carpooling websites were he might find someone to go with, unless he knows someone at work. Since Kevin works in finance it might be that he doesn't have to be physically in the office everyday; perhaps telecommuting a couple of days a week is an option?

Yes\nYes, and that also goes for buses. As it is now they often hold up traffic, both bikers and motorists when they stop so frequently to take up passengers. I would not mind walking an extra block to access a trolley or bus. Every other block, or say every 200-300 meters, is a reasonable distance between stops, in my opinion.

If I could dream freely, I would love to see new subway lines (extensions to the El). In a dense city like Philadelphia, with narrow streets and heavy traffic, under ground is by far the fastest way to get around. I walk the extra five minutes from where I live to get to the trolley line instead of taking the bus in the morning just because I know that the segment under ground will make up the time. The El is great, but very limited direction-wise- which is why I seldom take it. Places like IKEA, and Italian Market, Northern Liberties, etc. is really hard to get to without a car (or it takes forever with the bus)Otherwise I normally bike everywhere, and Philadelphia has improved a lot for bikers over the last few years, though there are lots that can still be done.

There's an empty lot right next to Clark Park on 43rd and Baltimore Ave. I've long been wondering what is to happen there, and who owns the lot.What I could recommend for Sarah right now would be to buy a condo, either in the Garden Court Condominiums at 46-47 and Pine, or the condos at 48 and Pine. It would be great with more condo options.
replies: I've been wondering about that lot too.  A great place to develop.

response: Groceries, Clothing, Bodega\nThe most important thing to me is to be able to get high-quality food within walking distance.

I'm not a planner, but I think RM-3 and RM-4 makes sense- if it's a question of creating new student housing. At capacity, a smart high-rise building would have a much smaller carbon footprint. The floorplans can be made to accommodate for common kitchen areas, commercial stores on the first level, etc.
replies: CMX-3 for mixed use.

response: There's a new popsicle shop on 44th, between Locust and Spruce st. They have a great selection for a hot day. Right next to it is Tom's tacos, that perhaps you should start with and have a popsicle for dessert. There's a ton of other good food around Drexel, on Lancaster Ave, or on Sanson str between 34th and 38th street- just to name a few. If you like to exercise there are tennis courts, yoga studios, or you could simply go for a run in fairmount park along the Schuylkill river. You are right next to it all.
No, I haven't attended any, but I'm sad to see the schools go.

I'm not sure about the entire demographics, but looking at my own little family we will, regretfully, move when our son is ready for school. This is true for most people in our age and socioeconomic group. The public schools are horrible, and if you are not part of the lucky few that get their kids into Penn Alexander, you will most likely move. Friends have done it, and we will do it. USW is a wonderful district if you are young or old, but not in between. People go to Narberth, or somewhere else down the main line. Not because of better restaurants, shopping, or community, but because of better schools.

[[[39.955012512469985, -75.18340783691406]]]\nI'm not sure where the USW district ends. Center city has the worst congestion, but I often notice very heavy traffic when I bike home by 30th street station. The bottle neck seems to be getting out to 76 or 676.

Trolleys\nOn rainy or snowy days, I take the 34 trolley from 47th and Baltimore to 19th and Market. Even though I live right next to the 42 bus stop, I prefer the 5 minute walk to Baltimore avenue. The reason is that the trolley is mostly underground, and not subject to the same heavy traffic that the bus is. The bus (when I have taken it) takes about 40 minutes, while the trolley takes 15 for approximately the same distance. So it's definitely worth the extra five minute walk to Baltimore Ave.

Yes, almost every day\nI bike from Pine and 47th to 18th and Market, daily. Passed 38th and Spruce I have a bike path the whole way until 18th street, which is great!  I bike over South street bridge, which is a great bike commuting bridge. 18th street to Market st is the worst part of my morning commute. Over the five years I've been biking to this route, the commute has improved a lot. Still I've had a few minor accidents. Biking down Spruce between 40th and 33rd I've had (parked) car doors open in front of me, cars squeezing me off the road, and someone who got the idea to park and drove right into me while I was in the bike lane. Biking home is worse. Traffic going south is so bad that I usually take JFK to 30th street station instead, then bike Walnut home (I'm always nervous on JFK, since the cars (and trucks) drive really fast. JFK, including sidewalks, is very wide, so there's room to accommodate for bikes- I know a lot of ppl would use JFK a lot if there was a bike lane.

[[[39.953104476652925, -75.21894174194335]]]\nThere's a lot of apartment buildings in the blocks between 47-49 street and Osage and Spruce, which means a lot of people would be served by a store on 48th and Spruce. Yes
I would assume that the universities employ a lot of people- Penn in particular. Further, the Cira Center and the old post-office at 30th street. Retail and dining around the university as well.

[[[39.947906453901844, -75.20958619689941]]]\nClark park's playground is a weekly hangout. Our son loves it, and if we're lucky we'll get a cup of something and a bagel at the green line caf_, and maybe something from the farmer's market.

response: Personally, I think student housing doesn't fall neatly into any of the prescribed zoning designations.  If I had to pick, I might suggest RM-3, RMX-3, or CMX-4.  This is a huge issue, and one that really wasn't adequately addressed in the re-write of the zoning code.  Most students currently vie for single-family housing and apartments in the heart of our residential neighborhoods; housing that could otherwise be occupied by professionals and adults.  While a mix of students in the neighborhood is a good thing, the mix needs to be balanced.  The balance in Powelton is very unhealthy right now:  about 85% students to 15% longterm residents.  Student housing should be strategically planned, and Universities should commit to sustainable expansion plans that address these needs.  So while we can suggest zoning districts for student housing, it is truly in the hands of the Universities to ensure that their growth is done with minimal impact to the neighborhoods.
replies: yep.  something penn did a poor job with, and now they're trying their hand at drexel.

I'm a little confused on this. Is this question asking what already-existing student housing should be zoned as? Or is it asking where I think students should live?Undergraduate students (particularly underclassmen) are either required to or tend to live in higher density residential districts such as RM-2, RM-3, and RM-4. Kevin could move into the city, like many young families and empty-nesters have chosen to do.  Otherwise, there are only two categories of actions that will work: increase the cost of commuting by car, or decrease the cost of commuting by train.  In the former category, for instance, the city could increase the parking tax to make it more expensive to commute by car on a regular basis. Or, USW could create dedicated times during peak commute times (e.g., 7:00 - 8:30 and 4:30 - 6:00) when one lane of a major road (e.g., Chestnut) would become "bus only" (although the city would actually have to enforce this), or a perhaps permit only buses and trolleys to travel on the thoroughfare (e.g., Baltimore Ave) during that time.

Yes\nWhen the trolley is above-ground, make the stops every other block (e.g., even or odd-numbered blocks).  That would tend to speed up the above-ground portion of the trip without imposing substantial additional costs in terms of walking time or safety.

Get SEPTA trolley drivers to encourage standing passengers to move to the back of the trolley.
