It depends on where the subject lot is located within the surrounding community; good development practices take into account the context in which the development is occurring.  Thus, for instance, if the lot were on a major thoroughfare (e.g., Market/Chestnut/Walnut Streets or Baltimore Avenue or 52nd Street), RMX-3 or CMX-3/4 might be appropriate.  Conversely, in a more purely residential area (e.g., along Pine Street or most any of the numbered streets in USW), one of the RM or RSA zones might be more appropriate.
Allow people to move into apartments above store like this.
Not Sure\nMaybe.
Incentives for people to open neighborhood businesses that serve basic needs like food, hardware, clothing.
replies: These are the businesses that deserve to get some tax breaks!

response: Large-scale housing co-op.
Coworking space with a green roof.
Better, faster connections between 30th st station and USW.
Yes\nUnless you want to eliminate the stop at my front door.
More buffered bike lanes. It's hard to get to Northern Liberties.
The empty lot at the corner of Baltimore and 43rd.
Office Supply\nNO big box store.
RSA-4 - we don't need more enormous towers.

None of these\nThe 'you don't belong here' Ivy League tone of Penn is strong and intimidating, and I have never even stepped foot inside any of the Penn parks which require taking a pathway into them. I realize these are open to the public but I don't feel welcome in any of them, except maybe Drexel Park (but it's so wide open anyway). Also that Spruce Street Plaza JUST opened in this winter and there is really nothing there, nor is it warm enough to lunch/gather on those benches. I think that plaza in particular will see a lot of use from students, workers, visitors, etc once trees bloom and it's warmer out...

A redesigned 40th Street trolley portal with trees, seating, and a cafe\nMore amenities around transit hubs. I lived in Osaka, Japan for a bit, and every last train station had all kinds of quick food spots, covered/warm waiting areas, mini convenience store & newstand options, bike parking, etc.

[[[39.93237583091819, -75.20864205932617]], [[39.9439539, -75.16797830000002]], [[39.9439539, -75.16797830000002]], [[39.9439539, -75.16797830000002]], [[39.9324444, -75.1512204]]]\nI think Center City would benefit from some bikeshare options. Tourists would dig this and be able to ride the buffered lanes, and hopefully so would residents who just need to get around close-by, but maybe don't always ride.

Foot traffic for businesses within walking distance of college campuses (and their student housing areas) is valuable. Chain stores are tricky tho. I hate that the Subway was opened on Baltimore ave, which is overwhelmingly independently owned/small businesses. A chain store (singular!) may be a welcome addition to a thinly populated shopping ave, depending on what the residents desire. But I think other chains end up an unwelcome eyesore and seem out of place. Really conflicted on this one.
I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI feel like the current options are nice and accessible...

[[[39.9412882, -75.2187346]], [[39.94160159503423, -75.22312164846745]], [[39.94554986033927, -75.22638321462955]]]\nI'm just becoming appalled at how the going rates for studio apartments and one bedrooms in and around Cedar Park has changed over recent years (500 to 7-800 and higher). The UPenn and other transient student populations seem to think these prices are fine, while long term and permanent residents find it more and more difficult to afford homes and apartments in an area that was once hospitable.

Really, ask the residents that live along those avenues first. Coming from 48th and Baltimore aves down onto Grays Ferry, I usually get the feeling that the two areas are disconnected. Do these neighborhoods feel they have good access to transit, jobs, rec space, shopping? If light industry comes in, whatever they build should also require provisions for public space or something that the residents of these neighborhoods want/need.

Improved housing should make provisions for natural light and green/garden space--something that actually feels like a neighborhood block instead of an institutional complex. Just avoid those old tall, dark closed-in projects that are already proven to be a bad idea. Also, while the housing is being improved, where are the current residents supposed to be?
Expanding Comegys (48th and Woodland) Recreation Center to include more spaces for different activities\nShow a little love to the rec centers. Some people can't get out to the trails.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets\nDedicated, physically separated bike lanes (and the green ones, specifically!) are a very visible space that is less aggressive than simply trying to ride in the street, or a narrow bike lane on the side of parked cars, which are infringed upon by immediate-to-the-left traffic and immediate-to-the-right cars that might open their doors on you at any minute. I feel MUCH more at ease riding in buffered bike lanes.

Other (explain in comment)\nA combination of the 2nd and 4th options might work. If you remove parking, where will those parked cars go? If you combine bus and cycle lanes, how will you prevent SEPTA buses from dangerously cutting off cyclists as they pull to the curb to accept/drop-off passengers? Who counts as an employee of University City and how would you determine giving them financial incentives to take transit? I think the congestion is linked to a broader network of traffic concerns in and around Center City...
Yes\nConsiderate and well designed bicycle parking will go well if there is an equally thorough way to direct and ease motor vehicle traffic as well.
Public transportation and walking should be encouraged to improve the area.
CMX-2.5
No ... Too loud and this does nothing to solve the crime problem that effects Philly and the surrounding areas.
Groceries, Clothing, Bodega

Drexel Park, Penn Park\nI think Spruce St Plaza will be nice for people that work near there, but I don't have much use for it. I've stopped in Drexel Park to take in the incredible view of the city, but there isn't anything else to do there. I've enjoyed lounging around with friends on the sloped sections of Penn Park on fall afternoons.

A redesigned 40th Street trolley portal with trees, seating, and a cafe\nI've seen some initial renderings of what the trolley portal could become, and think that it's a very exciting project. It makes a lot of sense to include a cafe - or preferably, a diner! - at this spot since there's people here 24/7. More eyes on the street and foot traffic is a good thing!

[[[39.869427591480665, -75.1909609375]], [[39.94217400000001, -75.218951]], [[39.94217400000001, -75.218951]]]\nAssuming that they make smart decisions about where to put the rest, I think it's a no brainer to have bikes available to get to/from the library and rec center.

As mentioned by so many in the previous question, I think there's clear demand for big box stores closer to USW neighborhoods. For better or for worse, i'm not sure it's a question of whether they are good or bad for local businesses. The reality of today is that a ton of people use them and go out of their way to do a big box run every so often, weekly or monthly. I would personally visit both because I think there's a time and place for each. What I can get on Baltimore Ave I can't necessarily get at Target, and vice versa.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI don't live in West Philly anymore, but this answer still applies to me. When I need to hit big box stores, I use PhillyCarShare, and I will probably do that no matter where I live in Philly until there are more accessible options.

[[[39.95152537227368, -75.20053105926513]], [[39.951103, -75.214831]], [[39.951103, -75.214831]]]\nThe housing stock is so beautiful in this part of the city. When it's leased to students, they don't always take care of it. Plus, there's good schools in this area and it's very popular for families.

Pretty much all job creation is good, right? I don't know if these are the kinds of jobs people have skills for in this district, but any large facility is going to need all different kinds of employees for maintenance and repair and upkeep as well as the research and industry jobs, so I say bring it. I don't have a memory in my lifetime of this land being used for anything more productive. It feels sort of off the map currently. My other point is that they definitely need to include the trail with any new businesses. Not because it looks nice, but because that will be a great way for people to get there!

It does seem like this large lot could be designed to welcome a lot more residents than it does currently. It's such a great location! I like all the examples in the resources, but out of the 3, I think the Paseo Verde one near Temple U is the one that makes the most sense scalewise. I've been in the rowhouse ones in hawthorne, and they're nice, but I think they make more sense on narrow residential streets where you're used to seeing rowhouses. On a corner like this right in front of a subway station, you could go a little higher, and leave room for a bitter plaza/park somewhere out front (one that people actually use, not the sunken space that's there today). The picture I found isn't a mixed-income building, but it represents the kind of size I think could be appropriate at this location. I think we've learned from our mistakes enough to know how to design a larger building for multiple income levels that is safe and inviting.
replies: This looks like a luxury apartment building by the local standards. There seems to be always the lack of money issue that prevents something like this to be built as an affordable housing option.

response: Redesigning Myers Recreation Center to include more space to walk, sit, and for kids to play\nI feel like there's so much potential at these large rec sites, but poor condition of the facilities keeps a lot of people away. I also think people consider rec sites as something for kids and teens, and not as much for adults, and that shouldn't have to be the case. A facility like Kingsessing is big enough to accommodate something for everyone. It already has a ton of great programs, but with more money it could fix up what's already there (basketball, tennis, pool, ball field, etc) and fill in with other stuff (maybe outdoor exercise stations for adults or seniors, a fenced in dog run, an actually paved path or course for walking/jogging, better gym facilities inside...i could dream all day).
replies: we would definitely use it more if we felt safe walking to and from it in the evening... but a clean pool in the summer would be fabulous- and some quality YMCA-style programming on the weekends with ZUmba and fitness classes would probably draw a crowd.

response: More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nBiking is a viable form of transportation if it's convenient and safe. I only feel truly comfortable on the streets with buffered bike lanes, like Spruce, Pine, and Walnut west of 22nd. I'd feel even better if we could physically separate them with concrete or bollards or something else, but the space of the painted buffer is good enough to make me feel  confident. As for BikeShare, I've used these systems in other cities and think they're great. I would just hope that Philly be smart about station placement: don't just serve the campuses. Serve the neighborhoods where a lot of people live to commute into the campuses.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nEvery time they build a multi-million dollar parking garage on the campus, I wonder why they couldn't divert even a bit of that money into their employee programs for discounted septa passes, or in helping the city to re-engineer streets to become more accessible to pedestrians and cars.

Yes\nI don't bike in this area, so I wouldn't use it personally, but anything that encourages cycling will be good for traffic. I hope they publicize it well. Right now, bike parking is not easy near the station.

The most important thing is having people close by to use the businesses regularly. Once you've got that, then you can start making the street more of a destination, like Baltimore has become. Baltimore still has a lot of businesses that cater to the neighborhood (the pet store, the bookstore, the yoga studio), so it's not like it's all restaurants that people are coming from far and wide to check out. There's already some great places on Lancaster (I love Reeds coffee on the 3800 block!), so I guess the other piece is making sure people know. I wonder how many hospital employees, for example, know that they can right around the corner for a great coffee, rather than 7-11 on 38th.

Yes\nSince I don't live here anymore, I would probably use it recreationally, to come from somewhere north all the way down and to Bartram's Garden as my final destination. I would also consider doing a longer ride along 58th street, where they're building a new path, to Cobbs Creek. That would be a nice way to spend an afternoon. I wish I lived over that way, cause that would be an amazing way to travel to Center City for work or for fun.

[[[39.9603939, -75.20215940000003]]]\nI've never spent anytime in the West Powelton neighborhood. I don't know anyone there, and there aren't many businesses on Lancaster that interest me. It seems like this neighborhood and all the staff and visitors to Presby could support more businesses, especially food places.

It seems like there's two issues here. The house has become too much for her to care for on her own, and she can't get around easily. To the first issue, this is why I like the idea of introducing new housing styles into the neighborhood. Big Victorians don't make sense for every phase of life. I don't think she should have to move out of the neighborhood she knows to find a place without a lot of stairs and a place that doesn't have lots of ongoing repairs. In terms of getting around, this is where more shopping near 30th street might come in handy. It's way easier to get to that area from here than it is to deal with the 64 or the G or the 52 to one of the big box shopping centers. That said, in the meantime it'd be nice to speed up the 52 a little bit so it doesn't take her all day to get up to the shopping center in Parkside.

I didn't realize how much land these two properties take up until I looked at it on googlemaps: http://goo.gl/maps/Jm141Given its location, it would be surprising if the large universities did not have an interest in acquiring this property. That said, the School District can take its time and consider the best way to dispose of the land. As it stands now, it's a superblock, with none of the usual grid that cuts up the city and makes it that familiar scale. Perhaps the School District could subdivide it or get council to pass legislation legalizing streets back through the site. That way multiple parties could develop different pieces of it incrementally. I'd say that open space would be nice in this lot somewhere, but Saunders Park is so close.

This building being built next to the Temple Regional Rail station seems like the right kind of concept for this kind of location with fast access to Center City. Ideally, you want housing for multiple income levels that allow everyone to connect to jobs quickly. And then some kind of commercial enterprise to attract positive street activity to this location. Not sure if sit down restaurants would work right under the train, but you never know. I'm picturing this somewhere on the 4600 block of market on the southside where there's mostly vacant land. There's also some lots on chestnut that could handle a building of this size.

I think a lot of people take regional rail into 30th street, but then it's getting south that's the problem. I guess people don't want to switch to a different train that's heading to University City Station even though that's probably the fastest option. If they knew which lines had the most hospital employees on them, maybe they could look at rerouting some of them so that they could continue through to Univ City (even if they aren't currently scheduled to do that). If there were predictable service from 30th street to university city in the morning (more than just the routes that happen to stop there) then maybe people would stick with the train.

Yes\nYou have to be careful with this one, but I remember they studied this on the 34 a few years ago. They found that 41st, 42nd, and 44th all had very low boarding levels compared to the stops on either side of them. Cutting these out could potentially shave a couple minutes off the trip and get the trolleys from Cedar Park to the portal faster. I also think that stop just past the portal at 41st where chester meets woodland is really silly. Seems like you could walk there from the portal, or you're probably looking to go farther down one of those two streets. Farther west, I think it all depends on whether there's a lot of traffic and making sure you're still serving the senior citizen population well. as long as you can do that, cutting a stop here and there to make the trip faster is a great idea.
replies: I agree you have to look at each stop individually, and not just cut out every other one.

response: In this district, I think the answer is "it totally depends." I know a lot of people in south philly, and the 64 doesn't run frequently enough to make it a good option for cutting across town. If it were more reliable, i'd rather do that than take a trolley and switch to the BSL. Also, the 64 terminates at 49th and woodland on off peak hours, and I think it should always run up to the 46th street el just to make connections easier. The other thing I notice is that no one uses the 49th street regional rail station, even though that would be a 3 minute commute for people that work at CHOP/HUP. seems like they should promote that area as a great option for people making that commute. In general, I guess my biggest observation is that if certain transit improvements were made (mostly more frequent service) then I think we could convince a lot of people to cut down on driving and traffic would get lighter.
replies: It would be wonderful to have a time table of the buses and a countdown meter for the next departure at the trains or trolley stops- that would make people feel like they could gauge how long until they need to abandon all hope of ever getting some place with public transit.

response: I think small apartment buildings for PhD students and other young professionals could make sense on the wider streets like Woodland. Somebody brought this discussion up over on the Soap Box page, and there's a lot of different opinions so far. I can say that I moved across the city when I was ready to buy instead of rent because none of the beautiful West Philly houses were the right size or price range. If there had been more options like 4300 Spruce, for example, or those larger buildings in Garden Court, then maybe I would've thought about staying. The places where that kind of building could fit are: 1) on that huge lot across from Clark Park at 43rd2) on Woodland vacant lots, especially around 47th3) Maybe some places on Lancaster too, though I'm less familiar4) on walnut, near where that new hotel is

Drug Store, Hardware, Electronics\nWhen I lived in Cedar Park, we had lots of great places to eat, but not many places to buy basic essentials for the house, like a screwdriver, or a new tv. Mostly, i could get that stuff by heading into center city, but I think it would be cool to see that stuff pop up on the west side of the Schuylkill too.
replies: Particularly if I have a sudden home repair need at an inconvenient time, I don't want to wait 12-14 hours until I'm headed back into the city.

response: I guess it depends where it is. It makes sense to put the larger buildings on the campuses where there is already a precedent for larger structures for dorms and academics. For example, the building in my photo is really cool right there on walnut street, but it wouldn't make much sense if it were in the middle of a neighborhood. I guess I'd say CMX-3 is the right scale for buildings on or near the campuses.

I think a lot of times that people who don't feel the city is interesting or safe haven't taken the time to experience it for themselves. Sometimes you need to go outside your comfort zone a little bit and explore. This area has an amazing diversity of ethnic restaurants, some really beautiful and quiet parks, and architecture that's different than many other parts of Philly. To say nothing of Bartram's Garden and some of the unique attractions. My advice to Rachel is to get off campus and actually walk around.

I didn't go to school in the district, but I can imagine how disruptive it will be to see these long-time institutions go away. That said, I'd like to believe that many of them can be re-purposed in ways that strengthen the surrounding neighborhoods, whether that means using the existing building or redeveloping the land into something else. There are some very interestingly located schools on the closure list.
I think that some families moved out because jobs relocated to the suburbs during this time. It also could have to do with more students moving in and families looking elsewhere.

The El\nIt's hard to beat the speed and frequency of the El. A lot of times, I'd rather deal with walking farther from an el station to my destination just because I know the El trip will be so much faster. I would take buses or trolleys if there could be some guarantee that they'd actually run regularly.

Yes, from time to time.\nI've noticed that the neighborhoods south of south in center city are growing with new residents all the time, but transit hasn't kept up with that population growth. Increased frequency on the 40 bus would go a long way to address that issue, but the 40 is always late. Maybe a shortened 40 route during rush hour that does more of a loop?

[[[39.954025604038065, -75.18521028137206]]]\nSomewhere around 30th Street Station would an awesome spot to sell lots of healthy food. There are always so many people coming and going through this station at all hours of the day. A big supermarket or something like it would allow people to pick up healthy options during their commutes. They did this with a farmers' market at the Frankford Transportation Center one day a week and I loved it!
replies: That's a good plan!  I'm always at a loss for food options in the station which usually results in buying B&J ice cream.

response: I'm a little surprised to see part of what looks like the University of the Sciences campus showing up in red. It's clear to see how much the major hospitals and universities are growing. i feel like every time i visit the district I see more and more cranes. These are big places that need a lot of employees to support them. While Drew Elementary closed in June 2012, University City High School is open and so cannot be up for sale yet. The School Reform Commission votes on the proposed school closures including UCHS on March 7, 2013. This question is disrespectful to the UCHS community which has created an alternate plan that may include moving to another site or co-locating with another school. Still, it is poor form of the Philadelphia City Planning Commission to dance prematurely on the UCHS building's grave.http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/31/education/philadelphia-district-may-close-37-schools.html"For some students, anger over the planned closing of University City High has been replaced by an understanding that the proposal reflects the poor condition of their building, not academic performance. Students are now focusing on how to keep the school community together, albeit in a different location.'Emotion turns into logic,' said Matthew Gillian, 18, a senior who is helping in the search for alternative locations for University City students at schools that remain open. 'It makes you understand why certain things have to happen.'"

I walk by there everyday and would desperately like to see development there. It should definitely be mixed-use with retail on the ground floor and residential above. Yes\nDefinitely. They can really be slow during peak hours. In a perfect world I would have the 34 trolley (which I ride the most) stop at only the even numbered streets and not stop at all between 44th and the 40th Street Portal. I think that is a good compromise between accessibility and speed.

response: Definitely focus on public transportation. Shorter bus headways would be a great start. I usually walk to the El but would use the 42 bus more if it came more often. Another option I like is having the trolleys and buses stop at every other block instead of every block like they currently do. This will speed travel times. An El stop at 22nd Street to access Rittenhouse would be helfpful. A bike lane on Chestnut to match the one on Walnut will be helpful as well. I wish I could get to areas in South Philly quicker. In my dream world we would have a Locust or Spruce St. subway extending from 52nd Street to the Delaware River. There is already a tunnel under portions of Locust Street in Center City. Also, this new subway and the El could both interchange with new subways running under 22nd and 5th Streets. One can dream, right?

YES! Please! As a young professional I have the same problem. Currently live in a building with a mix of people including grad students. It's fine for now, but eventually I'll want to buy. response: Groceries, Drug Store, Bodega, Antiques\nGroceries and drug stores are always needed. Bodegas are convenient and add to the urban feel of the neighborhood. Antique and other specialty stores add great character to the neighborhood. Big box stores are disgusting and if I wanted them I would move to Delco or Columbus Blvd. I don't need clothes stores, as the stores on Walnut in University City and Walnut/Chestnut in Center City are convenient and I don't need any closer to my residence. Automotive isn't necessary, as I don't own a car and I feel we have too many already.

CMX-5 and CMX-4 would be appropriate in areas directly adjacent to the Schuylkill. This extreme density will serve as a transition area to Center City. Other areas near the college campuses could be  CMX-4 and CMX-3. Commercial corridors (Baltimore, Lancaster) could be CMX-3 and CMX-2.5, while CMX-2 should be sprinkled around the district to keep areas vibrant at all times of the day and allow for locally desirable commercial uses with residential above. RM-2, RM-1, and RTA-5 would be appropriate in areas that are currently all residential. We shouldn't include any auto-oriented zoning. Dense housing and commercial are key to fostering a walkable, transit-oriented environment, as well as preserving affordability for students and non-students alike.
Honest Tom's Taco Shop is a must. Grill Fish Cafe on Baltimore Ave. Vix Emporium, also on Baltimore, is quirky and cool.

I did not, and I don't know anyone who did. Regarding schools, I think the city should look into a public-private partnership for Lea Elementary. Funding from local institutions could help elevate the quality of education at Lea and serve as a good option for those who cannot get their children into Penn Alexander. If Lea also gets overcrowded we should reserve priority spots for families that have lived in University City for at least 10 years. This will help mitigate the negatives associated with gentrification.

I think there has been a loss of residents in the western portions of the district. Areas near Center City have seen an influx of people. This will continue to fan out but one barrier is a lack of quality housing stock. Many of the row homes are very large and need a lot of work done. I think there is definitely demand for new construction that we may see come to fruition in the next few years.

This might be a good place to focus some of the schools and/or other functions where the close proximity of the El would be an asset, not liability.  Also a good place perhaps to cluster government offices and commercial offices (lawyers, architects, professional services)

We desperately need better housing and service options for seniors in this area including but not limited to mixed income retirement projects.  We also need to expand the existing services offered to homebond seniors by Ralston House, LIFE and PCA which offer programs to help seniors 'age in place'.  Finally, I think the renovation of many of the housing should include creating units for handicapped and seniors that could help multi-generation families live together with independence.

Having torn down our community to build these schools, I think they should replace them with residential housing to help buffet the concept of home ownership in Powelton.  This could be a place for a mid level condo building aimed at working professionals.

stop allowing  Penn and Drexel close streets or add traffic lights in the middle of the block.We also need right turn on red at the corner of Lancaster & 34th Street at lease during off hours (and perhaps elsewhere)Something has to be done about the madness around the train station.  I would think someone commuting from Radnor could make use of the trains.

Biking and public transit.  I find it difficult to get from Powelton to the rest of USW without a car. Permit parking should not be allowed on both sides of the street unless there is easy access to public parking lots.  My mother is semi-homebond and for myself or individuals coming to visit or assist her, there is no parking available on her block if one needs to stay longer than a few hours.

Spruce Street Plaza looks nice and I may have the occasion to use it on a visit to the hospital, but I'm not in that area much.  Drexel Park looks great, but I haven't had the opportunity to use it and don't anticipate using it.

Much as I would love a park along the river near Bartram's garden, I think the 40th street portal re-design would be more useful to me and others directly in the neighborhood.  Breaking down the scale of that expanse would be great for the neighborhood.

[[[39.96738055701113, -75.18340783691406]]]\nI think a bikeshare station by the Schuylkill River Trail (maybe near the art museum) would be a great spot.  Especially if tourists could pay to rent bikes there.

As much as I don't love chains, I do think that their interest shows that the area is a viable area for business development.  Bringing more people to the area for shopping because of a known quantity (a chain) can also be a plus.

I always drive\nI do most of my shopping via driving.  There are a few local shops I use.  The big thing for me is grocery shopping (I shop weekly at one of the two whole foods in cc and go to trader joe's every month or two).  There is nothing I would like to access on a regular basis by foot.  I would love to walk to get groceries.  I don't think I would ever use the trolley to get groceries - I buy too much at one time.  I also drive every two months or so to a Target, etc for paper goods/cleaning supplies/etc.  I do not need that to be close.

[[[39.92013311045293, -75.21482186889648]]]\nI am not as familiar with the area that pops up on this map.  It does seem like there are large stretches of space and big buildings, the airport, etc.  The density of single family homes may have the potential to enliven these spaces and break them down.  Particularly as you get closer to the grid (Bartram's garden) and closer to the river.

I love the idea of new jobs.  I think it is important to consider access to the jobs (public transportation and bike routes).  My concerns for the area are about the middle architectural scale - these ventures all sound like big buildings with the potential for large wasteland in between.  Even with leaving waterfront access, or especially with waterfront access, there need to be residents to activate the space.
I would like something that is more urban and connects with the street facade, but is activated on the ground level with retail or shops.  Shared open space could be within the block.
Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nConnecting West Philly south to the river would be a great asset for our community.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nSafer bicycle lanes is the most important thing for me, especially if I am traveling with my children.  Bike sharing is very intriguing, especially if you don't have to return the bike to its original location.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes\nA separate bike lane on Chestnut would be helpful.  I think placing stops every other block would be great.  It would be less confusing if the bus always stopped on an even or an odd street (instead of every 3rd, for example).

Yes\nI think a bike facility is a great idea. I would not use it as I do not commute using 30th street station. I do think improvements to bike lanes to/from 30th Street will be necessary as it is not currently a great place to ride.
I think apartments above retail is a great solution and works in other areas of the city.

Yes\nI would use it for recreation.  I think getting to that trail would be tricky.  I would love it if there was an easy bike connection to that trail from Clark Park or Woodland Cemetery.  I would then use it frequently.

[[[39.951591169017185, -75.23696618652343]]]\nI have never had a reason to go to the area around 57th and Cedar.  I assume it is mostly residential and I don't know anyone there. I don't know if it is unsafe.

It might be interesting to have some of the mid-sized mixed-use apartment buildings in that area with commercial and retail on the first floor.  Residents would be good for that large expanse and the retail could service those residents.

The area near the 46th Street El has real potential to become a new commercial center for this area.  I think a lot of the businesses mentioned in challenge # 2, grocery store, hardware, drycleaning, clothing, etc.  would work here.  People can easily stop in on their way to/from work.

If Celia has lived in Kingsessing all her life, I don't think different housing options would work for her.  A combination of increased transportation options and new closer shopping centers would definitely help.

Kevin has an interesting and probably very common commuting problem.  I'm curious if he takes the train if he the takes the Lucy loop.  That bus seems like it could be utilized to be an effective way around the east side of University City.  I guess the other option is to take the R1 to University City Station.   Both options seem like they would be more relaxing then dealing with traffic.

Yes\nI think eliminating every other block would make trolleys move through West Philadelphia faster.  I think eliminating more than that (like every third block, or something else) could get confusing and eliminate convenience.I also think that stop elimination would be more effective on buses.
I would prefer improvements in walking and biking.  To encourage and improve in that area, we need more shops, such as those mention in challenge #2, that are nearby.

I think it depends on the location.  If this is off-campus housing on a more major thoroughfare, then I would prefer CMX 2.5 or CMX 3 - something with commercial on the ground level and not too high.  I think that would fit in well in most areas.  There are areas where RM2 or RM3 or RM-4 might fit in as well.

Several young families live in the apartment buildings along Spruce Street.  But I do think there is an opportunity for some low rise modern apartment buildings with retail on the ground floor could fit in on some of the larger thoroughfares like Baltimore Avenue.

Kevin, stop driving!!!!! Radnor has incredible accessibility to regional rail, and the Norristown High Speed Line. He could easily take the R100 into 69th and get on the El to 30th, or he could take the regional in, and do the same.What may be helpful is if more of the trains terminated at University City, instead of 30th Street...I have often though about a subway line (lets call it the Yellow Line) that goes from 2nd and South, west along South Street to University City Station, 30th Street Station, and then replaces the 10 Trolley underground along Lancaster. Once it hits 52nd and Lancaster, it splits, and runs along the Bala-Cynwyd Regional Line all the way to Manayunk, and another, which covers the Paoli-Thorndale Line's stops up through Bryn Mawr on a rapid-transit basis.

Yes\nYes, keep them running smoother, have the stops every 2-3 blocks, at least on the 34 trolley! The trolleys are wonderful and contribute so much to the character of the neighborhood, but if we consolidate the stops (40th, 43rd, 45th, 48th, 50th, 52nd) the entire congested stretch of Baltimore will be much easier to navigate.I also think the trolleys need to be modernized for the 21st Century. Make them longer to fit more people, and make them ADA-accessible, with low floors and ground level doors. Boston's Green Line, and Portland's Streetcars are great examples to follow.

I think that most of USW is covered well when it comes to transportation, but Philadelphia as a whole needs to improve their rapid-transit system to get on the level of connectivity that USW has. My only suggestion, maybe, is a better link to West Fairmount Park and the Mann Center, but there are already buses that do this.I would like to see 52nd Street station re-opened on the Paoli-Thorndale Line, but that isn't necessarily USW.

I think CMX-1, CMX-2, and CMX-3 are great for student housing because students are not isolated and insulted in buildings that only house other students.  These zones would allows for a variety of different types of units to get built - from studio apartments with kitchenettes to 3 or 4 bedroom units with full kitchens and bathrooms.  Offering a variety of units will allow students to pick the right living situation for them, and not force them into dorm-like settings.  Dorm-like apartments are often unpopular with upperclassmen and graduate students, and when all the property near campus is taken over by dorm-style high-rises, they are forced to live further away from campus.  Mixed use buildings also provide opportunities for businesses to locate near campus.
Universities are huge job creators.

The southeast corner of 40th and Market is relatively new (housing was created within the past 20 years, I believe). Why would we rebuild it for a more "modern" view? I don't think that "modern" is the most appropriate goal as much making the residential area more inviting. It is a pretty dull space that murals, and park benches and flowers could make more enjoyable for residents and attractive to people of all incomes. Since it is located right at the 40th street EL stop, as well as a transportation area for trolleys and buses, I hesitate to make it more kid-friendly with a playground, but that is also something that could make the area appear more like a community space than a dull lawn.

Something else we haven't thought of yet!\nCreation or encouraged development of community gardens in city-owned (abandoned) lots. This can be achieved with involvement of local recreation centers and community groups such as churches and youth organizations.

None of these\nI have not been able to utilize these parks, but I would love to if I had the opportunity. Perhaps the universities could partner with UCD to make the parks feel more open to the community as a whole?

A redesigned 40th Street trolley portal with trees, seating, and a cafe\nThis project would not only beautify an area that is in desperate need of attention, but it would also make it clear that the district is serious about incorporating transit into its future and is excited to work with SEPTA to shape the current transit system to better suit the needs of the community.
[[[39.949559665366614, -75.2033527431488]]]\nWould be an excellent transfer point for trolleys.

I think they will play a supplementary role. Yes, some business might be lost in the short-term, but having national retail in USW will attract more people (and more money) to the district as a whole and many of these new faces will be drawn to the traditional shopping corridors on Lancaster and Baltimore. In the long-term, it is not a zero-sum game, it's expanding the pie.
I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI'm car-free and I'm proud :)
[[[39.96349933710124, -75.19345002746581]]]\nThis region is farther away from major employment hubs and commercial corridors, so it makes less sense to upzone for development.

I think there could be concerns over quality of life in regards to the presence of manufacturing, but they could be ameliorated by bringing in light and high-tech manufacturing, which leaves a lesser environmental impact.

I would like to see something like Paseo Verde, with a mixed-use, transit-oriented development, and green space aspects, but perhaps with the brick design of the residentialarchitect.com picture, to better weave the building into the community. Following the model of Paseo Verde by finding a funding partner within the community would also be an excellent idea.
Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nAccessible trails and parks on the river would best utilize the natural beauty afforded to the city.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee\nBikeshare is a great way to get people who are new to biking in cities on bikes. To my knowledge, Capital Bikeshare in DC has been very successful not only at getting people on their bikes, but also encouraging people to buy their own bikes to ride in the city. Biking in cities definitely benefits from network effects (utility increases with each user). Bike parking and physically separated bike paths are also really critical (maybe more so than bikeshare); I know that the lack of bike parking and bike paths (particularly physically separated paths) has held me back from using a bike to commute.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit, Other (explain in comment)\nAll of the above, also consider improving the existing bus infrastructure, like bus shelters, it's a little thing that could encourage individuals working or studying in USW to take the bus. Cleaning up the bus shelters in DC, for example, has made people who would not usually consider the bus actually become regular bus commuters. Also, this is a much bigger idea, but a BRT, or BRT-lite, model with separate rights-of-way and off-vehicle payment system would be a great long-term solution to consider.
Yes\nI think it will be a great way to ease traffic concerns, especially if it is clearly connected to the city's network of bike paths.

Improving the density of this area is key to energizing businesses in the area, and given the strong transit bones of the area, it is clear that much can be done to increase the amount of people who live and shop along Lancaster Ave.In terms of advertising, I think that would be an excellent idea, as it would put the name of the corridor in people's minds. Given that I did not hear about the Lancaster Avenue corridor until a random article on Newsworks, I believe that the UCD could do a lot more to promote this corridor as the next Baltimore Ave.
Yes\nI would use it to go between USW and CC without having to deal with the traffic on the roads.
[[[39.94402412861857, -75.21623807525634]]]\nI have never been able to get down here.

I think that providing an alternative commercial hub within the USW district (such as a new development at 46th street) and providing effective transit to this new hub would be the most proactive approach the city could take, as doing so would not only improve the community by bringing commerce and jobs, but it would also allow individuals like Celia to get what they need without having to travel halfway across the city.
While I am not sure what can be done with University City High School, save for tearing it down, the Drew School could be converted into market-rate apartments with a quota for low-income residents.

I would like to see a large mixed-use development at 46th street that would have a similar feel to the commercial corridor in Columbia Heights, DC which houses an urban target, but would have the same level of connectivity to the MFL as the Clark/Lake station does to the James Thompson Center in Chicago (the El platform is directly connected to the building). This kind of development would be highly transit-accessible and would provide services to all groups within the community.

Offering a BRT-lite service with off-bus fare collection and separate right-of-ways for buses along certain stretches might be the best method of getting people like Kevin to these critical job centers. A BRT-lite line could start at 30th street and terminate past Washington Ave, providing rapid and cost-effective service to CHOP, UPenn, Drexel, and South Philly. Kevin could likely improve his own commute by transferring to a south-bound regional rail train and getting off at University City.
Yes\nHaving the stops every other block would increase frequency. Also, I doubt that there is the infrastructure for this, but having express trolleys might be an interesting direction to take.

Public transit should be promoted heavily, as improving transit will encourage walking and biking as well (although more separated bike paths would be awesome). Encouraging public transit use will need to include improving the conditions of the stations (see my Soapbox post), both in USW and CC and improving transit times. The city needs to work with SEPTA to provide people with an easy means of finding when the next train, trolley, or bus is coming, including putting screens in MFL and trolley stations to display arrival times (Chicago has a nice system for the El that could be adopted). In terms of new service, it would be great to see a BRT, or at least express service, come to the city as a whole and USW for major bus corridors. Finally, one of the bests ways to encourage non-car use would be to emphasize mixed-use zoning, which creates the kind of spaces that people actually want (and can) walk, bike, and take transit to.

Absolutely, whenever I take any of the trolley routes it is clear that the corridors they travel along could be up-zoned for mixed-use development (see the giant parking lots right before Lancaster Ave. on the 10 line), encouraging new CMX-3 and below development along these corridors could bring new life to the corridor whilst keeping the corridors' character. Getting more people to set down roots in USW will be critical for bringing the "eyes on the street" that allow for safer neighborhoods. In terms of new CMX-3 and below development, I think that Montreal (why are they not a sister city?!?) would serve as a source of best practices.
replies: Montreal? Yes! How about Portland, Oregon??\\ Absolutely! I just used Montreal as an example since the Phila2035 reports highlight the city as a peer city, which actually holds a lot of truth. Both Philly and Montreal are former industrial cities  which faded during the era of de-industrialization and are now in the process of reinvigorating themselves. There are a lot of excellent cities from which we can draw best practices. I haven't been there in years, but apparently Toronto has one of the largest streetcar networks in NA and continues to have large ridership, perhaps some trolley transit-oriented development (TOD) ideas can be adapted from there as well?

response: Groceries, Bodega, Hardware, Big Box Store (ex. Target)\nI would love to see an urban Target. Having lived in DC, where the Target in Columbia Heights serves as an anchor for the community that has grown around it, it seems hard to believe that Target would not succeed in Center City and University City.
replies: *or University City. \\ Don't you worry about this chasing out local businesses and adding more to traffic problems?\\ Devin, herte is what I suggested as well: "Having a Target store added to my neighborhood would be nice as long as the store is designed for an urban neighborhood. Also, I'd like to see a high quality grocery store in University City around the 36th and Market St." \\ Thanks for the responses, Oleg and Mike. Like I said, the "urban" Target in the Columbia Heights neighborhood of DC would be a great model, as many people use transit (Metro and bus) to get there. They do have parking there, but it is actually placed under and above the stores in the complex, with commercial properties along the majority of the street level. In terms of a Target or other box store hurting small businesses, that's always a very legitimate concern, but in many cases the existence of such properties can actually invigorate the whole neighborhood, especially in areas which are undeserved by retail to begin with. Going back to the Columbia Heights example in DC, there are many locally-owned businesses which have sprouted up along the periphery of the Target complex that have been able to take advantage of the traffic it generates. \\ Interesting. I have never seen that type of Target.  It seems similar to what whole foods has done in several neighborhoods in nyc and here too at their 9th and south location. This space really needs a significant intervention that livens up that corner. The big setbacks from the Aldi store and around the future police HQ are intimidating. Can something built along the side of those properties?Walking to that area, Chestnut feels big and intimating, too. Could there be bump-outs at S Farragut and Chestnut to make the crossing nicer? The gas station and carwash just to the south also make it feel uninviting walking there. Could something be built to "shield" the sidewalks from those parking lots?I'm not exactly sure what the intervention should be, whether it should be residences or businesses (is there a latent market for anything here?), but this area is so stressful, disheartening and unappealing to pass through that something needs to be done.

Yes\nAlthough it is very convenient to be able to get off close to your stop, and it's also beneficial for folks who have trouble walking longer distances to be able to get off close to their stop, the trolleys really do stop at every. single. corner during rush hour. The area is certainly car-friendly with its plethora of non-permitted parking spaces. If more areas were be permit-only, this might encourage more people to either buy a permit, which would bring the city some revenue, or shift to public transit or biking.There is a lot of public transit in the area: trolley routes, buses, and the EL. More transit-oriented development, such as what was suggested in the last question, could encourage this.There are also already a lot of bicyclists. If the existing bike lanes on Baltimore and Spruce were improved, or if a bike lane on Chestnut, where there are no trolley lines, could be installed, I think many more people would bike. So many folks I know have been doored or have been flipped off their bikes due to trolley tracks on Spruce and Baltimore, so having other, safer options, would be amazing and could encourage a lot more people to bike.

There are a few areas that I could envision new housing for young professionals or small families:Route 34 trolley:At 46th and Baltimore/ Cedar on the north side, there is a vacant building and unused parking lot. The site could be large enough for a developer to put in some housing.Route 11/ 36 trolley:At Woodland between 47th and Markoe, there is vacant land and Gold Star Pizza with a large parking lot and setback that doesn't feel appropriate for the area. Perhaps this block could be redeveloped with housing for young professionals and students. (Also: amazing fresh bread across the street at Four Worlds Bakery!)Route 13 trolley:What is the future of the University City High School site? 44th and Spruce is where it's at in terms of interesting openings, in my opinion:44th and Spruce:1) Honest Toms Tacos. It used to be a food truck, but now it's an awesome brick and mortar restaurant on 44th between Spruce and Locust. Their breakfast tacos are particularly tasty.2) Lil' Pop Shop. A popsicle shop may not that sound that amazing, but this one is, and this cute shop is definitely worth a visit in the summer. My favorite flavor are the earl grey with black pepper and goat cheese with blueberries. Also on 44th between Spruce and Locust3) Local 44 Bottle Shop. Next door to Local 44, a popular neighborhood joint, is their newly opened bottle shop. The shop stocks hundreds of varieties of quality beers, and they even do mix and match 6 packs.
I did not attend these schools, nor do I know someone who did. Without those schools, though, that particular area, especially Lancaster between 36th and 38th, will become particularly desolate.

According to the resources page, students in dorms were counted for the first time in the 2010 Census, which inflated population numbers. In addition, single family homes are being converted into apartments which means more people can occupy the same space. Despite those facts, the population shrunk, which I suppose I wouldn't have expected.Perhaps the rising cost of housing due to the increasing area where students are choosing living, and the presence of the Penn Alexander school's catchment area are forcing more and more people out of the area. It could also be that more and more of an aging housing stock is becoming uninhabitable, which is forcing people out of the area if they cannot afford repairs? I am curious to learn more.

Trolleys\nIf commuting, low on time, or if going further away, I always took the El. I think I used the trolley the most, though. Though slower than the El, it feels faster than buses (once it goes underground, at least). Yes, from time to time.\nWhen I was in USD, I was lucky enough to be close to several transit lines: the 34 trolley, the 46th St MFL station, and the 21 and 42 bus routes. When commuting to work at 7th St, I would always choose the MFL because it was the fastest (10 minutes from 46th St to 5th St), most frequent (at least around rush hour), and most reliable (it seemed to almost always come on time). If coming home late, though, I would avoid that station and get off early at the 40th St MFL station and walk the extra distance because I felt safer walking home from that station. I suspect the transfer of the police hq to the 46th St area will make the station feel safer to some (most?).

[[[39.952127821345194, -75.19269498562812]]]\nWhen I lived in USD, I was a student, so Penn was the place that I spent the most time. If I was to put on a second point, though, it would be at 50th and Baltimore: jazz in Cedar Park during the summer, Dock Street, Satellite Cafe, VIX Emporium!

None\nI'm already not the most active person (I'll admit it), but from where I lived in USD, all of these rec centers were a mile or more away. As a person without a car/ bike, this distance was a barrier. Not only did I not use these spaces regularly, I never used them at all.

I lived in USD for 2 years while I was in graduate school for urban planning. My number one favorite place, hands down, was always Clark Park. Every Saturday I would trek to the Green Line cafe at 43rd and Baltimore and meet other Clark Park/ farmer's market enthusiasts (usually other planners in my program) and we would grab a cup of coffee and people watch for an hour or two, appreciating the vivacity that the farmer's market would bring to the space. In warmer weather, in addition to those purchasing produce and other local goods, I loved to watch the dog walkers, the LARPers, the food truck afficionados, the hula hoopers. The space is incredibly lively on non-farmer's market days, as well. The chess players, the drummers, the fire spinners, the kids playing soccer, the families and their kids on the slopes of the bowl or playing on the playground, the basketball players and lone ponderers spread themselves out under park's canopy and across the parks' lawns, creating an amazing mosaic of people and revealing the broad cross-section and types of people who live in this district.

Penn Park, Shoemaker Green, Spruce Street Plaza\nSpruce st plaza is very new, but I pass by it all the time. Encourage cycling. This is not as simple as adding bike lanes everywhere. It requires sane traffic policy, and proper management and revision of dangerous intersections (like Springfield/Baltimore Aves), along with better road surface maintenance -- the recent reworking of Baltimore Ave's trolley tracks and pavement was an example of a SUCCESS. It's so much easier to ride a bike on now. More bike racks please -- good ones that are truly secure. The more "normal" people can be persuaded to cycle, the more a dominant culture of safety and courtesy will prevail among cyclists, rather than militant hostility.Promoting cycling can help reduce congestion without having to spend $$$$$$$ on changing the trolley system (which wouldn't address the parking problem, which cycling DOES address).

I would be happy to see many things built in that area - it certainly seems run down and empty now.  I avoid using the El partly because it's an unpleasant area to walk through at the moment. I also usually drive if I'm going to south philadelphia or to the Fairmont/Art Museum area.As far as biking goes, I think adding bike lanes to more streets would be wonderful if it was feasible.
