[[[39.944550558516966, -75.19962983703613]]]\nLimited access.  It looks like an old motel, and in a better world it would be a very interesting spot.
More coops.
Museum of lost lives.
An insane asylum, like it used to be.
replies: You're so crazy

response: I don't worry about Kevin.
replies: word.

response: No\nThey're fast enough, and spaced far enough apart.  Too many people would have trouble walking further to catch a trolley.
Biking and walking.
I don't see any zoning districts listed here, so...From zoning code, my guess is RTA-1
49th and Woodland
Other (Explain in Comment)\nDon't see need for any more of these.
Penn Park, Shoemaker Green\nAs a Penn Student I have spent time at both of the Penn parks.
A new park along the Schuylkill River near Bartram's garden\nThe park would be a great addition for recreational infrastructure. Especially if it connected Bartram's and The Woodlands.
Businesses will have a positive effect and I would prefer local businesses.
I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI do not own a car and am lucky enough to live near grocery stores.

[[[39.94724844817378, -75.21310525512695]], [[39.94408993257789, -75.21808343505859]], [[39.93987835161908, -75.22374826049804]]]\nSingle family housing should be close to the city and should allow for ease of use of public transportation.
I think it will encourage revitalization. This is a good idea.
Modernization to me signifies strengthening the infrastructure. The building itself could reference Philadelphia's wealthy architectural history.
Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nThis would encourage use of not only parks and trails but encourage development in that area.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nPhysically separated bike lanes make it safer for cyclists and encourages alternate transportation. The riverfront trail could further encourage recreational cycling and a healthier lifestyle for Philadelphia residents.

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit\nThe downtown was not built for such heavy car traffic. Increased public transportation can help alleviate this problem.
Yes\nAs a bicycle commuter, I would certainly use this facility. A safe place to park my bike plus safer roads to ride my bike are a priority.

Penn Park\nThe only park I've really spent time at is the Penn Park, and even that was only once.  Although these might be great parks, I'm not sure what is really happening in these areas.  I am drawn to Clark Park, for example, because there are always activities happening, such as the Farmers Market.  Penn Park is a great park, but it's just a large sports field and I don't play sports..  Maybe if there were more space for just laying down a blanket and reading/picnicking.

A new plaza at 48th and Baltimore\nA new plaza at 48th and Baltimore would be most useful to me, because I live right around there and would definitely use something like that.  However, think redesigning the 40th Street Portal is a great idea that has crossed my mind before.  The portal is a strange area that takes up a lot of space that could be utilized in a more social and green way.
[[[39.954917475566646, -75.18418033275543]]]\nI think 30th Street Station is a good place for the Bikeshare.  I think this would be a great service to add to the city.

I would visit these stores.  I think they would be a great addition to the area.  They would attract more students and people in general, but they could increase the price of living, which I don't necessarily think is a good thing for our neighborhood, especially for the families who have lived in this district for years and years.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI think more shopping around the UPenn/Drexel area or along Baltimore Avenue makes sense.  There is also 52nd street between Baltimore Ave and Market St.  There are some great shops and stores around the district now, but if I really want to go shopping for clothes, or things that are not groceries, I go downtown to Rittenhouse or the Gallery Mall area.  It'd be great to have more retail stores around here, especially because I don't have a car.

[[[39.95040681794837, -75.22700982666015]]]\nAround 50th and Baltimore, there are a lot of young families, as well as people who have been living there for years and years.  It seems like a place that makes sense to  have single family homes for all the families.  But there are also lots of student and recent grads looking for apartments.
I think bringing more jobs to area may mean bringing more people into the city.  This may mean more neighborhoods getting congested or having a stronger demand for more housing.

I like the image of the brick row house.  It's homey and comfortable.  I like that's it not too modern/swanky looking.  It stays consistent with the look of the rest of Philadelphia's historic row homes.

Building parks and trails on the river that you could reach by 49th, 54th, or 58th streets\nI think building more parks and trails would be a great way to encourage more walking!  That's something I would definitely use. Redesigning Kingsessing Rec is a close 2nd though.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, A secure bike parking facility at 30th Street Station, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, Public bicycles available for sharing at a minimum fee, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nPersonally, I do not like biking, so I don't know if that could be changed.  But in general, I think these are all great ideas to encourage other people to bike more and make biking in the city more safe!

Placing stops every 2-3 blocks in congested areas\nI don't take buses too often, but I feel this is what would help the trolleys move fast as well- in certain areas, decrease the amount of stops to increase traffic flow.  As a commuter, I really wouldn't mind walking an extra block or two!
Yes\nI don't bike, so I wouldn't use the facility myself.  But I think it's a great idea for all the people who do bike!
Lancaster Avenue is a street I rarely travel to.  Making physical improvements and re-zoning to bring more people to that area seem like a good idea to me.
Yes\nI actually haven't explored Bartram's Garden.  But in general, I support more hiking trails.  I think that would be a great and beautiful addition to the city, encouraging people to walk more.

[[[39.97152466722231, -75.2451201019287]]]\nI chose the area around 63rd and Haverford Avenue.  I have not really gone beyond the 52nd and Market, unless while taking public transportation.  Those are areas that  I'm not sure are safe.  I don't know what's there, or if there would be any businesses of interest to me.
Better transportation, but also somehow building up the neighborhood to offer more amenities (grocery stores/small businesses), so she doesn't have to travel far.

I'm not sure where these buildings are.  But I feel in general, all my answers have revolved around healthy and affordable grocery stores, small businesses, affordable housing, and more gardens/green space.

Affordable housing, small businesses (shopping), and healthy/affordable grocery stores!  I used to live right near the 46th El Station and it was so convenient having easy access to go downtown.  But I didn't like the Shop N Bag grocery store and most of the businesses are around 43rd - 45th and Locust and south of Locust.  There is so much potential around 46th and Market!
replies: Also, there is a community garden right next to the station that could be developed! More trees and greenery all around!

response: Make public transportation more efficient and reliable.
Yes\nThe trolleys move very slowly and stop at every single block above ground.  A couple stops can be eliminated and people can get used to walking one extra block.

I definitely think public transportation can be improved in terms of efficiency and speed.  South Philadelphia is a relatively difficult area to reach from USW.  The best way is to take the bus, but I feel the trolley and subway lines are faster.

More housing for young professionals along the trolley routes would be great- especially affordable studios.  I'm not sure where this would fit though, as there are already so many houses and small businesses lining Baltimore Avenue.  I do feel that one side of the street has more businesses than the other, I'm sure there are plenty of spaces not being used right now.

Groceries, Clothing, Drug Store, Electronics, Postage/Parcel\nAlthough there are a bunch of great small businesses on Baltimore Avenue, I would definitely love more shopping options.  Healthy and affordable grocery stores; drug store/postage/electronics for convenience; and clothing stores so I don't have to go downtown if I don't want to.

I don't know much about zoning, but for student housing, it seems like RM-4 makes sense for the amount of students living around UPenn and Drexel.  I think building up makes more sense spatially than building out.

First of all, I am from Boston. And although it may have the appearance of being (ok, actually it is) cleaner, it is not necessarily safer or any more interesting or "cool"- it really depends on what neighborhood you live in.  There are a lot of great things about USW.  Some of my favorite places include the shops on Baltimore Avenue (Dock Street Brewery, Vientiane, Vix Emporium, Fu Wah Mini Mart, Green Line Cafe, The Gold Standard, and more) the Last Word Bookstore, Fiume, Lil Pop Shop, the Vietnamese restaurant around 43rd and Locust, and the Second Mile Thrift Store.

I did not grow up in USW, so I do not have a personal stake in this issue, but I do believe these school closings have had a massage effect on the community.  With schools closing, residents need to seek quality (public) education elsewhere and that may mean moving out of the district or city altogether.

I know a big issue in Philadelphia is the "brain drain"- the fact that we have so many universities around the city, but many students move out upon graduation.  I wonder if the population of the USW district accounts for university students and if the shrink is due to graduates moving out of the district or city.
[[[39.95448616307835, -75.18169122314453]]]\nI don't drive in the city, but I suppose the most congested would by along the Schuylkil Expressway, near 30th Street Station.

Trolleys\nThe trolley I take almost every day to work and to get to wherever I need, because the stop is closest to my house and I can easily transfer to the El, which I also use rather frequently.  I use the buses occasionally to get to places that aren't as easily accessible via trolley or subway, such as getting from West Philly to South Philly.

Yes, almost every day\nI think the trolley surface line to work everyday.  I could also take the El, but the trolley stop is closer to my apartment.  The trolley line is much slower than the El, so although I don't have to walk as far, I sacrifice speed.  Also, the trolley line gets diverted all the time due to work on the rails and that can be frustrated to deal with all the delays.

[[[39.95757840774416, -75.22185998535156]]]\nI think around 50th and Market St. might be a good place for a store with healthy food options.  Although the area is not too far from a Fresh Grocer and the Mariposa Co-Op, the demographic that shops at Mariposa is vastly different from the demographic of 50th street strip between Baltimore Ave. and Market St.  Mariposa is also extremely expensive.  I am only able to shop there, because I use SNAP.

I can't really tell what is what from the map, but I would say that the best healthy food access is probably closer to the UPenn and Baltimore Avenue area and gets scarcer as you get further West/Southwest.

I think the largest contributing factor to this number is the University of Pennsylvania and Drexel University.  These universities have taken over a large part of the area, which I think has both positive and negative effects on the community that has been here since before these institutions were built.  But definitely UPenn especially I would say is a huge contributing factor to employment and professionals.

[[[39.9477469, -75.22677399999998]]]\nI wouldn't say there is a certain place that I spend a significant amount of my time at in West Philly.  But since I live right near Baltimore Avenue, the Mariposa Food Co-Op and the Baltimore Avenue Pet Shoppe are two businesses that I frequent for daily needs. In general, I would say Baltimore Avenue is a great street to live by.  There are great restaurants, Clark Park, and the Baltimore Avenue Stroll in the summer- almost everything I need is right there!

Kingsessing\nI have been to several recreation centers in this area including Kingsessing, Laura Sims/Cobbs Creek, Miles Mack, and Wright, but that is only because I currently work for Parks and Recreation.  I don't believe I would have ever set foot in a recreation center otherwise, especially because I am not a native Philadelphian who grew up in the area.  Recreation centers play an important role for a lot of youth in the community, because of summer camps and after school programs, but I do believe programming could be increased for adults and other current residents to increase community involvement.

I think the most beautiful place in University/Southwest District is the Mount Moriah Cemetery.  I had never been there until this past summer, when I volunteered as a SERVEPhilly VISTA to do a clean-up one day and I couldn't believe this existed in West Philly and that I hadn't known about it.  It is an old, overrun cemetery with so much history, as so many Civil War veterans are buried there.  There are monuments, including a flagless flag pole, marking the original place where Betsy Ross was buried.  There are so many treasures to be found, because the place is so overrun by plants that much of the headstones are completely covered.  There is a group of people in the community that has been working to revitalize the cemetery, but I don't believe their man power alone is enough to tackle the massive amounts of overgrowth, especially when it grows back so quickly after one Saturday of mowing.  I would love to see something done about Mount Moriah.
replies: Stunning! Such a striking photo. Who knew this was out there?\\ I've never been here at all--a great find!\\ I've passed this- and always wanted to visit, but felt like it might be like trying to walk Cobb's Creek... something best done in a group- armed with dogs....now I want to explore it though... with dogs.\\ It's definitely worth a look- watch out for ticks! \\ Where exactly is it?

response: Liberty place, Macy's, Urban's Outfitters, Apple,Restaurants: Distrito Baltimore Avenue Dollar Strolls during summer months are great to sample.

It is unfortunate that we have to close these schools.  I don't know anyone attending any of these school listed since I have kids of young ages.  However, there are a number of excellent public schools in this area such as Penn Alexander (PAS) and Samuel Powel.  Samuel Powel is at its capacity in term of enrollment.  Penn Alexander is similar to Samuel Powel at its elementary school.   I believe if we can copy their success to other failing schools, perhaps we can save other failing schools and re-gain the confidence of parents who will be willing to send their kids to their neighborhood schools again. However, this will take a great leadership from the School district to take this reform. Money is always good, but I don't believe that is the only element to make a great neighborhood school.  We will need committed school district leaders, committed principals & teachers, and committed parents. Great schools will bring back the neighborhood.  The recent imposed lottery policy on PAS enrollment has already making people wanting to move to suburbs. This is a step back.

Desirable public school accommodation for their kids. Parents are facing either private school or have to take chances with lottery on charter school and recently with outstanding public schools  City should add additional space and resource in schools that are working and yet they just took a step backward by limiting the number of students that can enter. This leaves many families without choices but to move to suburbs.
Trolleys\nthey have their own tracks, however it also causes problem when there is a stall on the track.  I also use buses often but the traffic is terrible.
Yes, from time to time.\nby car or trolley.  If we have a real-time display of arrival at the stop, that will be great for people without smartphone.

[[[39.9477469, -75.22677399999998]]]\nThis would serve this neighborhood since the closest one is Mariposa which is a co-op and located at Baltimore between 48th & 49th streets.  This location will supplement the farmer's market on Sat at Clark park,
Yes there are lots of good places nearby where you can get healthy foods
I think lots of people work for the University or Penn Medicine.
Clark Park is so fun and good for kids to play at.
[[[39.943695107874426, -74.98067575073242]]]\nCenter City has lots of things to do and see.
None\nI didn't know about any of them.

None of these\nI have not spent time in any of these; some of them I have not heard of, and I generally don't expect anything created by the universities to be open and welcoming to the public. Also, I just don't hang out in the university area much, so they're a bit out of the way for me. But maybe I'll try going with my daughter to the Penn Park running loop; she might find it appealing.

A redesigned 40th Street trolley portal with trees, seating, and a cafe\nThese are such different-scale projects; it's hard to choose between them. For the cost of a riverfront park & trail, how many intersections like 48th & Baltimore could be made pedestrian-friendly? I am choosing the portal project because so many people move through that area every day, so it would make a big difference, and the paved area there is so ugly and depressing at present. BUT, I think one of the most important criteria for prioritizing improvements is reliable future maintenance. There no point in building stuff that no-one is going to maintain. Ideally, the 40th St portal project would be designed in close co-operation with the team of neighbors who currently maintain the plantings along either side of the tunnel, because Septa is always struggling financially, and I would not expect them to have either the finances nor the trained landscape personnel to maintain the area. City planners should support neighborhood initiative.

[[[39.886816566720206, -75.26099877929687]]]\nI don't think I would use a bikeshare personally; I have my own bike. But having a bikeshare pod at the Heinz wildlife refuge could be appealing for a lot of folks who would enjoy exploring the trails that way.

I avoid business districts with chain stores. The higher the proportion of chains, the less likely I am to shop at any business in the area. I think chains are less likely to care about the neighborhood and reinvest there, and make it harder for local businesses to make a go of it. I do think that creating housing upstairs form retail strips is a good idea.

I do most of my shopping locally on foot, by bike, or on the trolley\nI don't own a car, although I do use the CarShare sometimes to access things in the suburbs or other parts of the city. It would occasionally be useful to me to be able to access suburban shopping areas along Baltimore Pike - if there was a connection between the end of the 34 trolley, and suburban bus routes running out that direction, I would use it.I don't feel the need for more shopping. I can mostly get what I need. I hate to see basic functional neighborhood services displaced by upscale boutiques and big boxes, so I'd like to see few zoning options for big boxes. Encourage the local shopping districts that are accessible by foot, bike, and transit. The city should support local folks trying to start local businesses, including small spaces that would provide a transition step for folks who make things by hand at home, or sell on the street, and would like to move indoors. Shared retail spaces that could include sales counters for half a dozen or more such micro-entrpreneurs.

[[[39.95685470344009, -75.19995170211791]]]\nI can't seem to answer the question without placing a pin, but what I really want to say is that I prefer living in a neighborhood that's a mixture of single-family homes (often with 3rd-floor apartments), houses that have been divided into apartments to acommodate folks with smaller households or smaller budgets, and small-to-medium-size apartment buildings. It allows income diversity & age diversity. I don't see a need for a single-family-only zoning in this kind of dense urban community.But I placed my pin in memory of the Black Bottom community that was destroyed in the building of the science center district.

How it would affect neighbors would depend on what kind of industry moved in, and whether the space was designed to interact with and be part of the neighborhood, or a fenced secure zone like the DuPont facility on the other side of the Grays Ferry bridge. Another security-fenced anti-neighbor space would NOT be an asset - either for the immediate neighbors, or for trail users. It would be good if the space could attract businesses which would actually hire folks who live in the neighborhood, rather than depending primarily on drawing commuters in from elsewhere. Manufacturing or light industrial would probably be better for that than research.

I'm less interested in how it looks than how it functions for residents. Is it welcoming, does it feel like home rather than an institutional space? It needs to be designed to support residents interacting and building community, not separate them from each other. It needs to interact with the surrounding commercial/institutional street community, but it needs to have some privacy, communal privacy for residents as well as nuclear household privacy. There needs to be space for residents to gather that isn't taken over by folks on the street. It should have some outdoor space for relaxing & play. Perhaps if the residences fronted on the street but had a shared interior green courtyard, with back porches looking out onto it.

Redesigning Myers Recreation Center to include more space to walk, sit, and for kids to play\nI would prioritize Myers Rec because it serves a large area (I'm guess it serves a larger area than Comegys, although I could be wrong) and because folks in that area have little access to good green space & play space. I would prioritize that over, for instance, the river trails, because I think the river trails will attract primarily a more privileged group of the population, who are less in need of support.

More physically separated bike lanes on city streets, More bike parking in the neighborhoods, A riverfront trail from Bartram's Garden to City Center\nI already bike a lot - anywhere within comfortable range, unless I need to move large stuff or other people. So I'm not the person who needs to be encouraged to bike more.I think bike lanes are often a good thing, but until drivers are better educated to share the road, I find that bike lanes can sometimes be a problem - an excuse for drivers to harass me when I'm making a left turn, which of course I can't do from a right-side bike lane.Parking is sometimes an issue, although not usually a big problem for me.I would enjoy having better access to the riverfront trail system, and having it connect through to southwest Philly would provide that. Connecting all the way through - from southwest across the river and upstream to the already-developed portion from Center City up - is the key there, though.

Removing the right lane of parking on Chestnut Street from 40th to the river to create separate bus and bike lanes, Increasing financial incentives for employees in University City to take transit, Other (explain in comment)\nI definitely would NOT support limiting bus stops to adjust to congested car traffic; that seems like a step in the wrong direction.Has anyone surveyed folks who work in the area about their commute to work? It would be relatively easy to start with the major employers. Seems like any decisions should be made with that feedback of what would make it possible for these folks to bike, walk, or take transit to work rather than driving.

Not Sure\nI certainly think it's worth trying; I don't have a sense of how many people would actually use it. I would not use it, personally. I generally take the trolley to 30th Street Station. The only reason I would ride my bike there would be if I wanted to take my bike on a train, so I wouldn't ever have a need to leave my bike at the station.I do wish I could take my bike on the trolley, but that's another issue altogether.

Can't we do both - re-zoning to create more residential space, and improving sidewalks etc for them? I didn't realize there was a zoning barrier to use of the apartments above commercial strips. Why would we not want that space usable to bring more people into the neighborhood? Also, greening makes commercial streets more inviting to pedestrians. More trees!

Yes\nI've seldom ridden up the Schuylkill Trail. The few times I've ridden up towards Manayunk I've enjoyed it, but I have to ride through too much street traffic to get to the trail. If I could get on the trail closer to home, I would go for more long recreational bike rides. And probably stop somewhere for lunch or at least a snack along the way. I could take my daughter; she's less comfortable riding in traffic than I am.

[[[39.950538413523404, -75.18598275756835]]]\nI haven't been to the new rec trail area created by Penn. Why? I haven't gotten the impression that local residents are welcome, I suppose. I tend to assume it's just for students. And I don't know how to get into it. The universities are often not very welcoming, eg USP's fenced-off section of Woodlands Cemetery (which includes my favorite persimmon tree, and I'll bet the students aren't harvesting the fruit, either).

More support for local small businesses, so folks don't always have to go to the big box, and so it's easier for neighborhood businesses to get started and keep going. More support for elderly and other low-income homeowners to be able to afford quality maintenance on their homes. Block captains could be trained to facilitate building connections between elderly or disabled residents and able-bodied neighbors who could help them with errands and small maintenance chores. We need to reconstruct neighborliness, people helping each other, rather than assuming every challenge needs to be solved by professionals
Not sure; I'm really unhappy about those schools closing - and I don't know that area well enough to have a sense of what the neighbors there need.

It's ridiculous that most recent developments on 46th just north of the station (supermarket & housing) are both designed for car access rather than walking from transit. It would be great to have residential development that's a bit denser, that uses the space between houses for play space & green space rather than for cars. If it's not too noisy, a block of 3-story housing could be created in the vacant land just southwest of the station, designed to be a mix of low to middle income. Have the units face inward to a common space for folks to gather & socialize, play space for kids, maybe a community garden, etc. Create minimal car parking on the outer edges, but design it so the main entry is for pedestrians. Get the car shares to set up a pod there for new residents & actively market there.

Why does he keep driving? Perhaps his problem is not in USW, but in Radnor. Can he get to the train station easily? Does he really need to have a car with him all day when he's here? Could his office join the car share and arrange a pod or two outside their office so employees could use that when they need to drive to a meeting or such? What can we do to create bigger incentives for suburban commuters to leave their cars at home when they come into the city?

No\nI think the main slow-down for trolleys is competing with traffic. I think stopping at every corner is valuable to give access to trolleys all along the neighborhood. The trolley is already so much quicker & easier than driving into Center City (which I would never want to do, even when I've owned a car).

I think we should encourage everything but driving privately-owned cars. Encourage car-sharing by helping local car shares with parking places. But primarily, design to prioritize transit, bikes, & pedestrians. I wish I could get to Mt Airy & Germantown more easily; lots of folks in my neighborhood have friends and connections in that area, and existing transit options (trolley to regional rail, or trolley-subway-bus from Erie Ave) are limited and slow. I've also wondered why there's no bus connection continuing west from the end of the 34 trolley line, towards Lansdowne, Clifton Heights, etc. That would be useful for shopping.Recent efforts to make some of the intersections long Baltimore more pedestrian-friendly have helped. More could be done with traffic calming on residential streets. Oakland CA did some interesting things a couple decades ago to break up certain smaller streets and concentrate through traffic on larger routes; I don't know how that as worked out, but it seems that it would fit in well here since we already have so many streets that are not continuous. Planted bump-outs at corners would slow traffic, improve pedestrian safety, and create opportunities to capture run-off, which the Water Department is working on. They could create obstacles for bicyclists, but I think they'd be less of a bike hazard than parked cars on corners, which we have to deal with all the time. The multiple-bike-parking space in front of Mariposa Co-op is great. Some short streets are much wider than necessary for the traffic they carry (eg Florence 49th-51st); perhaps they could be narrowed with some kind of planting strip, depending on where utilities run underneath.

A lot of the old houses have been divided into apartments; certainly some of that has been done more skilfully than others, but that basic plan seems to me to have worked well, including the traditional 3rd floor 'mother-in-law' apartments. This kind of smaller option seems to have really been discouraged in the recent past by Penn's support for employees buying in the neighborhood, which encouraged sale of undivided houses and drove up prices. I do think that both new construction and re-use of existing spaces could support these kinds of living spaces. The Apple Lofts project sounded like a step in the right direction.How about the empty buildings & lots along the 5000 & 5100 blocks of Baltimore. Also, since the recent fire I've been thinking about how the 4900 block of Baltimore has gradually replaced 3-story buildings with residences above commercial space, with single-story commercial. That's good residential space lost.I also wish there could be some sort way to adapt zoning to encourage car-free living, car-sharing, etc. As long as multiple residences have to incorporate off-street parking, it's difficult to work that into a neighborhood like Cedar Park. There are certainly problems with crowded street parking, but I think we should find ways to encourage fewer cars rather than more parking. That in itself makes the neighborhood much more workable for people, especially families with young children.

Other (Explain in Comment)\nI'm actually fairly content with my shopping options. Another local hardware store on Baltimore Avenue would be great, but it's a short bike ride from my house to Monarch at 45th & Walnut, and that works for me. I go up to Penn to use the copy store. I like going to Center City for clothing when I'm not in the thrift shops; I'm happy to go outside my neighborhood for specialty/ethnic groceries (Italian Market, various local Indian groceries, Chinatown, etc). What I do NOT want is chain stores & big boxes in or near residential neighborhoods. I want to support locally owned small businesses, and I think zoning can help with that by keeping larger stores further away.

If you mean housing exclusively for students, then I would pick one of the RM categories. If students are going to be grouped together intensively, then a dense housing pattern, close to the college or university, which intrudes as little as possible on the nearby neighborhoods of mostly longer-term residents, would be best. Students should have a range of options including more supported dorms with services supplied, and more independent single or group apartments, so they can try out a range of living options on their own or with friends. I also think it's good for students to be encouraged to move into real neighborhoods, but to be encouraged to do so individually, or in pairs or threes at the most. If they want to live in the neighborhood, the housing patterns should be encouraging them to become part of the neighborhood, get to know the other residents, interact, so we can learn from each other.I don't think it works well for student housing to take over large sections of neighborhoods, as they do for a few blocks west of 40th Street. Sort of like the current trend towards mixed-income development, rather than segregating communities by income.

I'm not sure about the past 18 months; that's an awfully short time frame. Four Worlds Bakery on Woodland is probably a bit older than that, but fairly new, and their bread, croissants (and pizza when they make it) are fabulous.The community farm that UNI runs at Bartram's Garden is definitely worth checking out - so is all the rest of Bartram's, but it's definitely a lot older. However, we recently opened our Green Room, designed to be a more hands-on, interactive, place for visitors to ask questions & learn more.Crossroads concert series at the Calvary Center (48th & Baltimore) has also been around for several years, but it's one of my favorite things about our neighborhood.

My friend's daughter attended the Montessori program at Wilson. I considered sending my daughter there, but then it disappeared. We've mostly homeschooled. Most of the people I know here have sent their children to St Francis de Sales parish school, to Powelton or other magnet schools, more recently to Penn Alexander, or to private schools outside the neighborhood. Or they've homeschooled.

I think density has been reduced since UPenn started supporting employees to buy houses in the neighborhood; I saw a great many houses that had been available for rent go up for sale, and it seems to me that those houses then tended to have fewer residents. If I recall correctly, though, that began more than 10 years ago. Still, many people I knew who rented here, when they wanted to buy a house, had to leave the neighborhood because prices had gone up too much. And others, who were in a position to buy, found it hard to find a place for rent big enough to house a family. I would have had to leave too if we hadn't been willing and able to find an affordable house that needed massive work, and devote years to doing that work ourselves.I don't think that accounts for the neighborhood southwest of 52nd, though, and I can't really speak to what might be happening there.

[[[39.94961723917511, -75.20074563598632]]]\nI go out of my way to avoid the mess at the east end of Baltimore & Woodland, joining 38th Street. It wouldn't make me quite so mad if the folks who designed that snarl had just admitted that they were going to inconvenience the entire neighborhood so Penn could expand the Vet school - the fact that they claimed they were going to improve traffic flow just added insult to injury. It would not be nearly so annoying if two of the lights - which seem to exist solely to accommodate pedestrians, could be changed to turn red only when someone needs to cross. The light for traffic entering Baltimore Avenue after the turn off 38th - and the light for traffic leaving Baltimore, BEFORE the actual turn onto Woodland opposite the VA service drive.

Trolleys\nI use the 34 trolley most often because it runs within a block of my house and heads in the direction I'm most likely to need to go, center city and 30th Street for regional rail. If I need to get anywhere else in Philly I'm likely to need the El, the Broad Street line, or regional rail - the trolley gets me to all of those.Second most often is the 64 bus, which also runs a block from my house, and gets me to the Italian Market and other South Philly/south Center City destinations.I have tried taking the 42 bus to get to Upper Darby - it's the most direct route from where I am to where I need to go - but it runs too infrequently and often seems to run late. Fortunately, I can bike there instead.

Yes, from time to time.\nTo Center City, I take the trolley. I'm happy with the trolley routes; the only thing I'd like to change would be to have them (at least the 34, the one I have experience to comment on) run more frequently on weekends. Also, it would be great, when the trolleys are diverted to 40th Street, to have trolleys run more frequently than normal, especially if the weather is cold - it's not a pleasant place to wait, and building a shelter for that kind of crowd doesn't seem feasible.I also take the 64 bus quite often when going to the Italian Market of the south side of Center City, like Fabric Row. For that area, I also ride my bike, which is fine except that the Greys Ferry Bridge is not great to bike across, the traffic moves fast and the bike lane is full of broken glass. Years ago I used to commute by bike every day to Center City - pleasant in the morning, too dangerous in the evening on any westbound street north of Bainbridge.

[[[39.94043771714364, -75.21263318634033]]]\nBecause this corner is a major point for folks moving from one Septa route to another, I think it would be convenient to a lot of people, beyond those who live in walking distance. It could be designed to be accessible mainly by foot & by transit, with only a small car parking lot. And the immediate neighborhood doesn't have any good groceries close by.

The area immediate west of Clark Park is yellow on your map, extending over to St Bernard where I live. I would say it's green. I live practically around the corner from Mariposa Co-op, which is now open to everyone to shop, and plenty of folks I know who live around Clark Park, even east of there over towards the 40th Street trolley portal, consider Mariposa to be within comfortable walking distance for grocery shopping. Plus of course the Clark Park farmers' market.On the other hand, I'm surprised that so much of the area west of 50th Street is green. I haven't noticed a lot of good sources of healthy food and fresh vegetables in that area. There is a supermarket, but not the healthiest selection of produce on the admittedly few occasions I've been in there.

It's hard to pick one favorite space.Clark Park, the neighbors who gather there are the most beautiful sight, folks coming from so many different journeys into this one space to play, unwind, celebrate, and support local farmers.Mount Moriah Cemetery - it would be great if a way could be found to preserve it as a cemetery while still preserving the wildness that has reclaimed it. It's inspiring the way neighbors have gathered together to care for the grounds.Farm 51, the Pocket Farm on Kingsessing, Warrington Garden & so many community gardens throughout the neighborhood.Cobbs Creek, a wonderful green ribbon, I wish the bike path could be continuous for a much longer distance.
